PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.
Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker--
—Dandy Andy!
—We knocked off the Fourex Cup, too. You should have picked it up-nine wins. The legislation we are debating--
—Like you, 125 to 1.

—He got up, too-a winner. The honourable member would not even be in the market. He is hardly a statesmanlike character whose name is on the lips of all Australians. The legislation we are debating here today is the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill 1988. This is a non-controversial Bill which seeks to make a technical alteration to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act because of the change in status of Australian Airlines from a statutory authority to a public company. The coalition parties do not oppose this Bill. The principal Act which this Bill amends was the subject of parliamentary debate in about October last year. It is an Act that imposes a charge on Commonwealth authorities for the use of either an explicit or implicit Commonwealth Government guarantee on its borrowings. An implicit guarantee is apparent from the very fact that all Commonwealth authorities such as Australian Airlines are wholly owned by the Government. If they were to run into financial strife, lenders to these authorities could be assured that the Government would back those authorities with the necessary dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: What was noteworthy about that legislation passing through Parliament was that it was just 12 months after the Government first passed legislation on charging for the use of explicit guarantees. The natural consequence of that ill-considered and what seemed to be hastily prepared legislation was that authorities stopped requesting Government guarantees and all of a sudden the Government's revenue estimates fell. We all know that the one thing that really brings a gleam to this Government's collective eye is the raking in of more and more revenue. Therefore, the Government brought to Parliament legislation which would allow it to charge for the use of implicit as well as explicit guarantees. The Opposition supported that Bill to the extent to which the charge truly reflected the cost of the Government guarantee and required a publicly owned authority properly to appreciate the commercial costs of its borrowing programs.

This brings me to the topic of Australian Airlines-the specific reason for the amendment proposed by the Government. The Opposition has little doubt that the commercial future of a publicly owned Australian Airlines is bleak, to put it mildly. We have continually argued for the only sensible course which will avert this from occurring-that is, the sale of the airline. Therefore, we move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House endorses the sale of Australian Airlines, and therefore supports the Prime Minister's statement that ``I believe that an Australian Airlines, whether totally in private hands or an Australian Airlines with a significant private holding, with therefore corres-pondingly diminished demands upon public resources, could perform the function of Australian Airlines at least as well as they are now and, I would say, arguably, better'' '.

That is a remarkably candid statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I note that the Minister at the table, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), is reading the Prime Minister's words on privatisation with the due care and attention that all members of the Left faction give this question. As I said, it is a remarkably candid statement by the Prime Minister. We have moved this amendment, quoting his words in favour of the privatisation of Australian Airlines, to ensure that those members of the Australian Labor Party who stand with the Prime Minister will vote with us on this amendment, endorsing his very words. Even at my most persuasive I know that I would find it hard to engender a degree of support from members of the Left faction to vote with us on this issue. But before the House in the next hour or so there will be a vote on an amendment on which we can see whether the Prime Minister has lost touch not only with all average Australians but also with the parliamentarians in this chamber. The Left, the Centre Left, the Right-where will they go? I could quote some further words of the Prime Minister. Honourable members should listen carefully and see whether they can comprehend them. The sentiment is there supporting the words we have put down in the amendment. The Prime Minister, on the occasion that he used the verbiage in the amendment, went on to say, in what could be described euphemistically as classic Hawkespeak:

I think there is a case, a very strong case, for arguing that given the demands that there are and will increasingly be upon government, for instance in the provision of facilities and income for the aged, that I find it difficult to justify as a matter of priority the utilisation of scarce public resources to provide a funding base for running an airline as compared to the provision of those same resources for those things which I say only government can and ever will provide.

That is, as The Macquarie Dictionary now terms it, and contains within it, classic Hawkespeak. I am very grateful to the editors of The Macquarie Dictionary for citing me as the derivation of the term Hawkespeak. I have been an interested student of the tortuous language that pours from the mouth of the man who, at least until the end of this year or perhaps a few months earlier, will remain in the office which he currently holds. As I said, that is classic, convoluted Hawkespeak. The material in the amendment, however, is not. It is saying to this chamber, `Are you prepared to stand by the Prime Minister and support him in his words on the privatisation of Australian Airlines, not simply as a political act but because the economics of the situation, the sound business sense, compel you to support the sale of Australian Airlines?'.

The sentiments that exuded through the convoluted tautology which I quoted are sentiments, nevertheless, which my colleagues and I in opposition have been calmly laying the groundwork for over the last few years. I use the word `calmly' quite deliberately, for that is in complete contrast to the Government's hypocritical approach to privatisation. That approach has taken the same course as was taken in the days in the early 1980s when the then Labor Opposition hysterically opposed the coalition's rational poli-cies of financial deregulation and, therefore, effectively slowed down needed reform. When that Opposition reached government and had to show responsibility beyond its facile rhetoric, it was forced to change its tune and adopt at least some of our more sensible policies-much to the chagrin of the left wing, I should add. We in the Opposition have always supported free enterprise over government ownership. The associated incentives that that involves will, in the main, deliver society the greatest potential. But not the Prime Minister. He likes to make bets both ways. We will be supporting him in this amendment that I have moved on the statement, but there were different statements from the Prime Minister in his darker days. Honourable members heard me quote the Prime Minister just before, obviously in favour of privatisation. However, on 21 November 1985, notably just before the last South Australian State election, he said:
They know, as anyone who thinks about the issue of privatisation knows, that it would mean higher prices, higher costs, higher taxes and higher fares.

What socialist piffle. What did the Treasurer (Mr Keating), that leading light in the field of deregulation, have to say in this House on 23 May 1985, bearing in mind that yesterday at a Press conference the Treasurer in a few short but well chosen words because he has been keeping very quiet on the issue of privatisation--

TALK.START.PARA: —He has bigger things in mind.

—He has much bigger things in mind and he is having a look at the factions and seeing where they will line up at the demise of the current Prime Minister. Whenever he is pressed at a Press conference he says, yes or no or words of two syllables very quickly in favour of privatisation, but only as recently as 23 May 1985 he had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: No matter where one looks, whether it be at TAA or the other authorities, there is no case for the Opposition's argument in economics, except simply to indulge ideologically in a Thatcherite, vandalistic splurge to try and destroy these authorities.

That is good, tough stuff from the Treasurer, but he has bigger things such as the assumption of the prime ministership in mind. Economic theory has changed. He is now in favour of privatisation of Australian Airlines and I am sure he will be inveigling the Opposition to support the Prime Minister's words in this amendment that I have moved. The Treasurer ought to cringe when he hears the quote sent back to him these days. As I have said, we all know that he is one of the major players pushing for privatisation, but in the inner sanctums of the Go-vernment, with hardly a word said publicly. Honourable members will recall that this is just what occurred on the ID card. It was said that it was central to the proper and effective control of taxpayers' money for strong economic argument in favour of the ID card. When did honourable members hear the Treasurer come out powerfully day after day? He says, `Oh, cut it out mate. See you later, mate, as I am off on that issue. I am not going to upset the Left. I have got the Right and part of the Centre Left behind me. I have got to keep them in tow. I am not going to disturb them'. The same principle applies on the question of privatisation. He is slinking away when the heat is turned on on an issue that he is fighting for in the inner sanctums of the Government but is craven publicly with a yes or no and a couple of well-chosen words of two syllables, in two lines, in two sentences, and no more.

TALK.START.PARA: —It smacks of hypocrisy.

—Indeed, I get the feeling that he is distancing himself from the Prime Minister and behind the scenes factional power plays regarding his ambitions and they demand silence wherever possible. But the Treasurer really knows because he has worked for it and in fact his Press comments yesterday confirm in softer Hawkespeak terms-do honourable members remember the phraseology the Prime Minister chose to use instead of the word `privatisation'?-that he is going to campaign in favour of privatisation on the basis of optimisation of resources.
—Optimisation.

—That is the way. Why use one word when you can produce three? `Optimisation of resources' is the phraseology of the current Prime Minister. The Opposition has never said that we should privatise for its own sake. We have always said that we would sell a public asset only if there were a clear public benefit in so doing. Public and consumer benefit is our paramount consideration. That means that we are particularly watchful of the need for deregulation or, to put it in simple terms, we are ever watchful of maintaining a competitive environment and to avoid exploitive monopolies. Australian Airlines' position is a case in point here. Is it not ironic to note that the present Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris) when in opposition said in this House in 1981:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the policy of the Labor Party to ensure that TAA remains a 100 per cent government owned enterprise.
He went on to say:
Converting TAA into a public company will simplify its sale and it meets the prime demands of this Government's-
that is, the Fraser Government's-
backers, the multi-millionaire proprietors of Ansett.

They were the reasons the Minister gave a few years ago for opposing privatisation. It is somewhat ironic because, firstly, the Government only recently introduced legislation to convert Australian Airlines into a public company, as witnessed by the legislation we are debating here; and, secondly, it is ironic when one realises who are the multimillionaire backers of Ansett and whose well known friends they currently are. It is the two-airline agreement and the neglectful public ownership of Australian Airlines that has contributed to a significant lack of competition in the domestic airline industry. Up to 60 per cent of the market is now dominated by Ansett Airlines of Australia as the capital starved Australian Airlines limps along, to misuse a phrase.
What does the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) think, the man who the Prime Minister says is `so completely master of his portfolio in all respects'? In 1984, as Minister for Aviation he said:

This Government will retain TAA in full public ownership as a statutory authority in that it can then remain an arm of government policy to ensure that the best interests of the consumers are serviced.

How can that be? As the Prime Minister says, how can public ownership be justified in this case? Because of it Australian Airlines is now in a position where it does not know where to get the money to fund a needed capital expenditure program in excess of $1,000m over the period to 1991. The airline must re-equip its fleet with efficient aircraft to maintain competitiveness.

Senator Evans's recent Caucus discussion paper on Australian Airlines notes that its net impact on the Budget since 1981-82 has been payments of $115m. No dividends have been paid since 1981-82, although one of $13.3m is expected in the current fiscal year. More telling than that is a debt to equity ratio as at 30 June 1987 of 86 : 14. That compares with what it is understood the airlines own management considers to be a commercially appropriate gearing ratio of 70 : 30. What that all means, Senator Evans's paper tells us, is that to remain competitive an appropriate borrowing program and the payment of reasonable levels of dividends during the period 1990-91 require injections of equity capital of $250m in 1988-89 and $50m in 1989-90. We know that the Treasury is now flush with funds-all taxpayers in this country have become aware of that as more and more is taken from them-and it is quite conceivable that without trying the Government could have a Budget surplus next year of well over $2 billion. There need be no change in policy at all; it will occur simply by the massive increase in revenue derived from taxpayers through tax creep-I am not talking about the Treasurer-bracket creep.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fringe benefits tax.

—Fringe benefits tax has brought in significantly more than anticipated, the honourable member is absolutely correct; but in overall terms of total take that actually is relatively small beer compared with the amounts this Government is ripping off ordinary taxpayers, with the most significant increase coming from the pay as you earn taxpayers. Anyone on average weekly earnings working overtime pays half his money to the tax man. There is no incentive for it at all. This Government is now so flush with funds that it could in fact be tempted, and the Minister at the table will argue that this be done, not to privatise, not to give tax cuts and to give the money it now has, that it has drained out of people, to Australian Airlines. If the Government walks down that route it will destroy the opportunity in this forthcoming financial year, 1988-89, to do substantial restructuring of the Australian economy, and I trust the Australian people will condemn the Government for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasury is flush with funds, and it is quite conceivable that without trying the Government could have that Budget surplus that I mentioned of well in excess $2 billion. In fact I would say that without any policy change at all the Budget surplus could be around the $3 billion mark. It would not be surprising to see the Prime Minister rolled by the left wing of his Party, as he has been rolled on the appointment of Bob Hogg, and forced to use part of the extraordinary amount of revenue that has been taken from ordinary working Australians for injection into capital deficient authorities such as Australian Airlines, and not take the opportunity that is before him. It would be the wrong course. Such a surplus, or in fact a bigger one, contributed to by a reduction in wasteful expenditures, is important on macro-economic grounds to reduce the enormous accumulated public debt of this country and indirectly facilitate the reduction of our foreign debt difficulties. Instead, not surprisingly we have seen very little action by this stumbling Government in the area of proper micro-economic reforms, which were to be the hallmark of this third term of the Hawke Government.

Honourable members will recall that the Government alleged that its first term was to rectify the ills of the previous Government, and the second term was to put down the appropriate macro-economic settings. What rubbish! It lost our country's AAA credit rating for the first time in our history. This was the stuff and nonsense that were being put. But the third term was to deal with micro-economic reform. How much do we hear of that today and how much progress has in fact been made? It is an area where for effective reforms the sale of this airline is absolutely necessary. Not only is it capital deficient, but its operations are hamstrung by the restrictions on executive remuneration, its participation in the non-commercial government superannuation scheme, and its need for industrial relations co-ordination with the Government.

In order to provide effective competition for Ansett Airlines of Australia, which Senator Evans's paper notes has already `established a dominant intra-State position with virtual monopolies in its nationwide regional feeder networks', deregulation is called for. The end of the two airlines agreement is part of the solution. An endorsement of the Prime Minister's call to sell Australian Airlines will be another.

In conclusion, I put to the House that there is the strongest argument for privatising Australian Airlines. That has been accepted not on simple grounds but on sound economic grounds which sit well with our own philosophy on this side of the House. After the convolutions of recent years elements of the Australian Labor Party have come to agree with us, and the need for the privatisation of Australian Airlines has been endorsed by some statements of the Prime Minister. In order that this House can stand by the Prime Minister's latest call in favour of privatisation of Australian Airlines, I remind the House of his words and that I have moved:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House endorses the sale of Australian Airlines and therefore supports the Prime Minister's statement that ``I believe that Australian Airlines whether totally in private hands or an Australian Airlines with a significant private holding, with therefore correspondingly diminished demands upon public resources, could perform the function of Australian Airlines at least as well as they are now and I would say, arguably better'' '.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to the contribution of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). Members on this side of the House listen regularly to the attempted contributions by members of the Opposition on economic debate. But in the five years we have been in government members of the Opposition largely have been spectators on economic debate, they have not been contributors. Again today we find their attempt to contribute to economic debate has been without substance and without purpose. There is no consistency. As the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, would recognise, whether it is a question of looking at the relationship of taxes to expenditure activities, whether it is a question of looking at the efficiency of government expenditure or whether it is having a set of policies that have to be in place to enable a government or an opposition to be credible, on all those counts the Opposition fails.

SPEECH.PARA: If we were to do what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has been saying and look at his organisation as a business arrangement and business prospectus, it would fail. One could not sell shares in the Opposition. If the shares had a par value of 50c, they would not attract an offer. The Opposition has a credibility problem and a liquidity problem. I would like to deal with those issues but I wish to point out some other inconsistencies in the Opposition's position.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has made great focus this morning on the role of Australian Airlines, its shortage of capital and the two-airline agreement. We need to remind the House and the Australian community that it was members of the Opposition when they were in government who brought in the two-airline agreement. We were the inheritors not only of the $9.6 billion deficit but also of the two-airline agreement. It was this Government that had the courage to face up to and to dispense with the two-airline agreement. Members of the Opposition introduced the two-airline agreement when they were in government because that was how they wanted to organise the airline industry. We have taken the difficult decision and reorganised the airline industry.

The other thing that has to be pointed out in this debate, because the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has focused intensely upon it, is the asset backing of Australian Airlines. Who was in government for many of the years when asset backing was deficient? Members of the Opposition were in government and they did not do anything about addressing the fundamental question of Australian Airlines and its asset backing. They did not address it with Qantas Airways Ltd either. They ran away from that question. They cannot now say they will remake the world and remake history. It is just not possible. We will not let them do it. We will remind them of their record. The Australian community will not let them do it either because there is a credibility problem.

When one talks to Australian Airlines and to Qantas Airways Ltd about their asset backing and one goes back through the figures, one sees that the figures demonstrate that when honourable members opposite were in government they were incapable of making those business decisions. We have inherited that difficulty and we are trying to come to grips with it. We are trying to make Australian Airlines into an effective public company. We have done much along that path but it is not good enough for members of the Opposition to say, `We have this idea of privatisation. Because it works with Margaret Thatcher it will work with us and we will impose that upon a number of public authorities. That will solve all the problems. Incidentally, while we are about that, this Government is awash with revenue because it has made some tax changes but we do not want to make any of those tax changes, we would not want to go down that path'.

Members of the Opposition have stated on record in this House and out in the community that they do not want these base broadening measures in the tax system. They oppose the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the assets test, all measures designed to broaden the base of tax, to increase our revenue base and to limit our expenditure activity and target it more effectively. The Opposition is saying it does not want any part of that rational economic management. What it wants to do, depending on which audience it is addressing, is to make a selective promise that will attract the votes it wants to win government. The trouble is, its record catches it out. The $9.6 billion deficit we inherited in 1983 was the big problem but we have caught the Opposition out subsequently. We are not really sure where the Opposition stands on economic policy. As my colleague the Minister for Housing and Aged Care pointed out earlier, it is no good talking about consumer matters when the Opposition does not have a consumer policy.

The substance that has to be put before this chamber and the Australian community is that, when the Opposition puts up a series of propositions in this House, it will be tested-not only in the ballot box but also by the media and by the Government. On those tests the Opposition is failing. One of the commitments that were expressed here this morning was that we might be able to fund Australian Airlines from the increase in revenue that the Government has developed. However, that revenue would not have been available to the Opposition, because it would not have addressed the tax system.

The next proposition, which I find equally extraordinary, is that this Government is a high-taxing government-a high taxer of the pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayer. I remind the Opposition and the Australian community that this Government reduced the top rate of marginal tax from 60c to 49c in the dollar. As well, the other areas of taxation in that bracket were reduced. The Opposition cannot get away with that proposition.

The Government has also improved the company tax system. There is now full imputation of dividends to try to make the economy more competitive and effective. Today, when talking about micro-economic reform, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said, `We are not going down the path of micro-economic reform'. Where was the reform in the business sector when the Opposition was in government? What existed was a recognition that tax lurks, tax privileges, and bottom of the harbour schemes, were the order of the day. There was not a recognition, however, that something ought to be done to modernise the economy. That question was not addressed; it was too difficult. It was considered too difficult because the political mates of the Opposition in the background would not permit any modernisation.

Today the Deputy Leader of the Opposition mentioned financial deregulation. All honourable members are aware of the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. But when it got to the tough issue, when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) as Treasurer got to the barrier with financial deregulation, he fell over. He was not a starter. He was not a starter because basically some of the troglodytes in the National Party of Australia and members of the Liberal Party of Australia would not let him start. When Labor came to government, we implemented the Martin report, which examined the implications of the Campbell report, and the financial system was deregulated effectively.

In recent times the Opposition has been shrieking about doing away with the 13.5 per cent ceiling on housing interest rates. That is easy. We will go out and inform the 880,000 householders who have such loans that the world will be made difficult for them. That is what the Opposition is on record about in terms of financial deregulation. The Opposition wants the bank ceiling lifted. The Government will not stand for that. The Government stands for an effective housing policy and fairness in the system. The word `fairness' never crosses the lips of Opposition members; it is as if the word did not exist in the lexicon of political language. But it does, and record of the government provides substance for it.

I should continue this story because I find, when I analyse the record of the Opposition, that it is damning on many fronts. The record of what the Government has achieved and attempted to achieve will stand the test of any social democratic country. Let us examine a further damning situation. Earlier I spoke about the Opposition being unwilling to provide an injection of capital into Australian Airlines or Qantas. Those enterprises were starved of capital in the same way as the housing industry was starved of capital. The housing industry experienced the lowest level of starts for a period of 20 years when 105,000 people were ruined and put out of their homes. The Opposition did that in the name of the notion that we all still remember, because it echoes around the political museum of the Liberal Party: bearing down on inflation. Certainly the Opposition bore down. It bore down on the ordinary Australian community. During the last year of the Leader of the Opposition's term as Treasurer in the Liberal Party-National Party Government 200,000 jobs were lost. We should remember that. Today the Deputy Leader of the Opposition said that extra revenue was available. That is so, because we have broadened the base; we are getting people to pay tax who have never paid tax before. That is the first thing.

Second, we have got into work people who have never actually worked before. I remind the Opposition that since 1983 a million new jobs have been generated, an extraordinary achievement in a work force of only 6.5 million. They are paying tax, and they are people who, under the Opposition's arrangements, would not have been participants in the economic process; they would have been the losers. We all know how much time the Liberal Party and the National Party have for losers. The members of those parties are themselves losers. They recognise what losing is all about, but they have no pity for others who lose. The Government made some changes. The first change was to get the country going again; we got the country back to work. We have got the country back to efficiency. We have got the country performing in international terms. It is no good Liberal members coming into the House and saying, `You will not face up to this question or that question'. The record of the Liberal-National parties in government is a sorry one, and is summed up in the $9.6 billion credibility gap.

Secondly, Liberal members come into the House and take as a proposition the fact that the sorts of changes in revenue that this Government has brought about will be wiped away. The Liberals want to wipe away the base-broadening measures because they cannot sell them to the sectional interests to which they are trying to appeal. They cannot sell them so they will not face up to those issues. Having ducked away from that, Liberal members say, `We have got that revenue anyway, despite the fact that we have not changed the tax system. What we will now do is spend the extra revenue that we have not got from anywhere'. I ask the House and the Australian community not to believe that sort of story. The electorate did not believe it in July 1987 nor will the electorate believe it today. It still does not jell.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disneyland.
—Indeed, it is Disneyland. It consists of a series of propositions that do not link up. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is on record in the program The World Today on 8 March as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: There's far, far more revenue now. When I say more achievable it makes Mr Howard's proposals-which I believe to be right at the last election, even more credible now. And in terms of the revenue that the Government has coming in from its high rates of taxation it's virtually awash with revenue.

I again put the proposition to the Opposition. The revenue has come from the base-broadening and tax reforming measures introduced by this Government. Yet the Liberals would do away with those reforms. Well, they have a problem. The problem is that they will not have that revenue if they follow through their arguments. They cannot address the important issues of Australian Airlines or Qantas as to how to provide them with assets, because there will not be that revenue to provide. The argument we have heard from Liberal members today will not suffice. It is incorrect for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to talk about surplus Budgets when Labor inherited a $9.6 billion deficit.

Let us again consider the Liberal Party's business perspective in relation to Australian Airlines. What will its wages policy be? Will it involve incentivation? Will that be its wages policy? We have to ask the question as to what its wages policy is. The Liberal Party has no consumer policy, no wages policy and we now know it has no tax policy. There are all kinds of problems in developing policy. As the Liberals have no economic policy or industry policy, it is realistic to ask: other than having picked up something from the stop Press on Margaret Thatcher, where do the Liberals stand? They have one or two slogans about privatisation but where do they stand in terms of a cohesive address to these issues?

Opposition members cannot come into this House and pretend that they have not a history. Secondly, they cannot pretend that they can put up one policy without its being linked to others. That is what the Government does. The difficulty of being in government is that one has to sit down and make decisions, put policies together, make them cohesive and come up with a reasonable proposition. The clear record shows that that has worked. We have got people back to work, we have got the economy growing and industry performing. Industry is performing in the export sector and also in the manufacturing sector. Industry is also performing in terms of manufacturing investment.

Opposition members cannot be selective in any economic debate because the world is not selective in such debate. A big world out there is watching. It is a deregulated world-a world that was deregulated financially by Labor. It is a world in which the dollar was floated by the Labor Government, a world in which economic growth was achieved by Labor, and a world in which manufacturing industry is being revived by us. We have a wages policy that has worked. All those things fit together. People are watching the Opposition and they have not seen a lot that is convincing. Certainly nothing that has been said today has added to that conviction-except that we now know that the work has not been done by the Opposition and its policies are not cohesive. We are talking of Australian Airlines as a public company which has been freed up by this Government in the context of an airlines agreement which has been wiped away by this Government because it was unnecessarily restrictive. It was a view of the world that had more to do with the 1960s than the 1980s, and we recognised that. Australian Airlines and Qantas are out there competing in a very competitive environment. We pay attention to that.

Let me deal with another of the issues raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, that is, the question of the asset base of these organisations. There are a number of propositions we might consider. This Government is considering those options. I might add that we are not looking at privatisation as a simple slogan. We are asking about the kinds of decisions that have to be made to make these organisations operate effectively, given the demands upon the Budget. There are in the papers put out by Senator Evans's office propositions concerning the capital shortage of Australian Airlines and Qantas. I recognise that problem, as do my colleagues in my Party. We have this problem first of all because of the legacy brought about by the fact that asset backing was not provided in the past, but we need to address that matter now in order to make Australian Airlines as competitive as possible with Ansett. We must also include Qantas; we must make it as competitive as possible with an organisation such as Singapore Airlines, let alone Continental Airlines, United Airlines and British Airways. We need to put them in that circumstance.

It is true-the figures are on the record-that $250m will be put into Australian Airlines as a first injection, and in the order of $650m into Qantas. It is also true that in relation to those proposition papers the people on this side have had a series of positions to put. Some say there ought to be no move towards privatisation; some say we might well consider that move. Having looked at the record, and if we are to face a budgetary decision, if we are trying to make decisions about spending in particular areas, a 49 per cent sell-off of Australian Airlines and Qantas and the possible merger of those two organisations to make them more competitive are propositions that I would look at, as an individual member of parliament. As a member of this Party I would have to say that that would be on my own agenda. Deliberations about that are going on within the Government, and they will continue.

Having put that on the record, I must say that we are looking at this matter in terms of the business criteria involved-how we can make these organisations more efficient and more competitive. We have certainly done something in the statutory area in terms of changes to the legislation; we now have to do something in terms of the assets area. We also have to do something in the industrial relations area. I again remind the Opposition that we have a policy there, but I come back to what we are going to do about the asset backing of Australian Airlines and Qantas. These are questions that this Government has sought to address realistically, given that we have a budgetary target.

We have the proposition of $250m coming from the private sector. Mind you, we on this side would say that if there were to be a move that way, we would not want to relinquish the sort of control we believe is essential in terms of airline management, whereas the Opposition seems to be prepared to go much further than that. I do not think the Australian people are prepared to let the Opposition go that far. It seems to me that a merger of Australian Airlines and Qantas would be feasible, to enable them to operate more effectively, but it also seems that a 49 per cent sell-off is a realistic proposition and one that we ought to look at. Clearly, though, there would need to be some provisions in relation to the Trade Practices Commission about ownership and market concentration.

I, as an individual, say that those are propositions that ought to be seriously addressed, but they are matters for further debate and this Party is debating them. It is continuing to debate them bearing in mind that, first of all, we are about making the economy more efficient, we are about industry reform, we have a Budget that is now in surplus and we have in place an industrial relations policy which is working. We also have a situation in which industry in Australia is back at work. We have to say that. Despite what else can be said, Australia is back to work. In 1982 Australia was going out the door. Australia was heading towards becoming one of the underdeveloped countries of the world. Industry was going out the door. People were going out the door. Australia is back at work; business is back at work. People are back at work and the economy is on the move.

This side continues to face a series of issues, and we will continue to debate them. One of those is the effectiveness of industry operation. The airlines industry is but one of the many industries concerned. The motor vehicle is another. We are examining the efficiency of a whole lot of industries, but I suggest that, much as I respect the Deputy Leader of the Opposition as an individual, he cannot come in with the series of propositions he put today without going over the Opposition's history and the logic of his argument. On those grounds the Opposition's argument is not credible. I do not say this in the context of some election campaign; I am simply saying it in terms of a calm debate here, because the policies do not link. The Opposition cannot talk about allocating Budget expenditures from increased revenue when it has forsaken that increased revenue because it will not go for the base broadening measures we have gone for in the tax area. It cannot do that. Opposition members cannot add a proposition that says, `Oh, you are high taxing PAYE taxpayers', when they were the people who went out of office with the 60c rate still in place. The marginal tax rates were very high.

This is an interesting debate because it causes us to focus on the fundamentals. I think that that is always attractive to members of this House, but it is also interesting because it reveals that after five years members of the Opposition continue to be spectators in the economic debate instead of real participants. In the meantime this Government participates in the economic debate and has contributions to make. The record shows that those contributions have worked.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to be my lot quite often to follow the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) in debate, but today was the first time that I have heard that honourable member sound forth, as do many of his colleagues, about how the efforts of this Government are leading the world in some respects. While I appreciate some of the things that he said, it would seem to me to be almost diabolical to think that what was being done by the Government at the moment was taking us into the realm of world leadership. I do not think that we are anywhere near that level. I wonder whether, if he went onto the highways and byways of Australia, had a yarn to some businessmen and made a close examination of some of the very real difficulties that Australia is facing at the moment-not the least of which is in its export efforts-some of the aspects of his speech would really hold true.

SPEECH.PARA: One point that he did make in his speech was that this was a quiet debate about a number of varying principles that are taking some precedence in our community at the moment. I think we have a tremendous opportunity in this debate to focus on the whole issue of privatisation. I am delighted to speak in this debate and, indeed, to support the amendment that has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), to the motion for the second reading of the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill, particularly as it concerns Australian Airlines and the lack of foresight of the Government at this stage to take the bit, go forward and sell that airline. I know that there is a lot of debate going on on the Government benches, but one would hope that the calm rationality that the honourable member for Stirling talked about this morning might prevail among some other members as well, and that they would see the very real need-in fact, the crucial need-for the Government to address matters such as the privatisation of Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd.

In terms of privatisation, an awful lot of red herrings are being put around the community at the moment. The real facts are that nowhere is the Government's presence more disruptive or disturbing than when it supplies goods and services that could be offered much more effectively and efficiently by the private sector. Public corporations which restrict competition are the most obvious source of the over-extension of Government authority. Government intrusion into the marketplace is also seen in over-regulation of supposedly private enterprise. I suppose that the most striking example in Australia today is in the domestic airline industry. Admittedly, public enterprises exist to provide revenue to the Government. They are there to ensure the security of certain vital sections of the economy and to perform social functions such as health and welfare services. But public enterprises are also justified on the ground of protecting the public from exploitation and providing other goods and services which the public sector has no incentive to supply. But the real point is that in practice public entities are usually ineffective, as they distort price systems, allocate resources inefficiently and impose wasteful burdens on the national Treasury. That is exactly the situation that faces Australia at the moment in terms of Australian Airlines.

Absence of a profit motive and access to the public treasury contribute to the problems of public corporations. Lack of competition is an especially vexing aspect of government intrusion into business, as it also means a limited choice for the consumer. In many areas the existence of a public corporation blocks the development of a wider range of goods and services that better meet consumer demands.

The issue that we are debating today in terms of the Australian Airlines situation is not so much public versus private enterprise, but monopoly versus competition. That is the reason that the Opposition parties have taken this particular line in identifying Australian Airlines as one of the prime targets of privatisation. It is true, as the honourable member for Stirling has said, that the very structure of what was known as Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) over the years has been less than correct. In the 1940s, when the airline was first established, the capitalisation of the then Trans Australia Airlines was insufficient. That situation went from bad to worse under successive governments so that it now needs an injection of some $250m. Let us not forget that this proposed injection of $250m is not the first time that the public purse has had to help out Australian Airlines or TAA, as it was then called. There has been an injection of public funds before, simply to prop up its superannuation scheme. I wonder whether the Australian public realises what is going on. I wonder whether people would be particularly happy if they knew that their hard earned tax dollars were subsidising the cost of air fares for people who use the Australian air services.

As I have said in this House before, only 16 per cent of Australians have travelled in an aeroplane. It is a pretty small section of the community that utilises that service. If we have a user pays principle, that is well and good, but the plain facts are that in Australia over the years we have not had a user pays principle in the operation of the government airline. Now we have a little bit of light on the hill down the track, but it will not be until the 1990s that we get a truly competitive, user pays principle applying in the airline industry. One of the things that we must be aware of is that if some people argue-and they do-about the high cost of air travel in Australia, the cost of that air travel must, in part, be pointed back to the structure of Australian Airlines.

The Independent Air Fares Tribunal was established some years ago under the coalition Government to make sure that people were not overcharged and to set the prices of air travel in Australia. But what happened? Air fares in Australia had to be set to cover the operating costs and everything else that was involved by the least efficient carrier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cost plus.

—Yes, cost plus. The plain facts-it was not too much its own fault-were that Australian Airlines, or TAA as it was then, was the least efficient operation. Those fares were set to cover the TAA situation. One might ask what happened in the case of Ansett Airlines of Australia. Since the takeover of Ansett Transport Industries one of the things that I find very hard to gain any knowledge of is the profit made by the Ansett Airlines division of Ansett Transport Industries. I defy anybody to go through an Ansett annual report and dig out or verify the profit of the airline operation. There are all sorts of figures floating around-for example, that last year Ansett made anything from $60m to $120m profit, or somewhere above or below that amount. While Australian Airlines is going through a bit of a purple patch at the moment and is producing profits, the plain fact is that Ansett Airlines is laughing all the way to the bank.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody on this side of the House is going to argue about a private enterprise being efficient and making a profit. I put on the record that I have a great deal of admiration for Ansett Airlines. In terms of its domestic operations, it is one of the best in the world. The expansion of the Ansett organisation has been spectacular. It is now perceived as being one of the world leaders in aviation business. But that has been done at a very real cost to the Australian travelling public. Ansett has benefited so well from our system in recent years. One could perhaps argue that that is well and good. But the travelling public of Australia have been very restricted. They have been paying fares that I believe have been far too high. Most importantly, as I said before, that competitive edge-the provision of new services-in the Australian aviation industry has been stifled because of the situation that exists now.

A number of people in our community have already expressed very great concern about the recent takeovers by Ansett of some of the lesser carriers. The one that has caused most concern in this House-particularly to members of the National Party of Australia-is in regard to the future of East-West Airlines. Ansett has already said that East-West Airlines will be its low fare carrier, specialising in the tourist industry. That could well happen. But at this stage we have no real evidence that we are going to see any dramatic reduction in the cost of getting around Australia, whether it be for domestic or international tourists, or perhaps for somebody in business who wants to save some money and take advantage of a lower fare regime. We have no vision of when such a regime might come into operation. It could be more than a decade down the track. That is the point that worries me.

I believe that the Government and its various factions should be looking very closely at trying to get their act together on what the future of Australian Airlines is going to be. If cool heads prevail on the Government side there is no option other than to look towards the privatisation of Australian Airlines so that we can get ourselves back into the mainstream of the world aviation business. We have argued in this place before about the effects of deregulation in the United States of America. A lot of red herrings are floated around. In a recent debate one member of the Opposition said that deregulation in the United States had been a terrible thing, that safety standards had gone out of the window and all the rest of it. That does not really stand up to the statistics. The United States has had a safer air regime since deregulation there. Fewer people have been killed in air crashes in the United States in the last 10 years of deregulation than ever before. In the United States suddenly air travel has become available to the public. I mentioned a moment ago that only 16 per cent of Australians had ever flown in an aircraft. The principal reason that that figure is so low is the cost. As has been proved in the United States, people will fly if the fares are right.

We can look beyond the United States to other highly protective regimes such as the countries of the European Economic Community. The countries of Europe have had very high air fares. But what is happening now? We are seeing a breakdown of that as well. Already there has been major deregulation on routes such as London to Amsterdam. The fares have dropped dramatically. One of the major achievements of the Japanese Government in recent years has been the privatisation of Japan Airlines. Japan Airlines was a big and cumbersome government instrumentality that had protection on its various routes, was designated virtually as the sole international carrier and, although it was a very fine airline, bumbled along. Only 12 months ago Japan Airlines was freed from the restrictions of government. What has happened? All of a sudden, Japan Airlines has become highly profitable. It has been allowed to finance its own aircraft acquisitions and to diversify into various industries. It now has a huge hotel and resort division. It is going into all sorts of technical areas which are proving to be highly popular. In terms of research and development the airline is one of the leaders of Japan.

It might be difficult, too, to compare the Japanese national railway system with that of Australia, but the railway system in Japan has been the other interesting example of privatisation. Twelve months ago Japan National Railways (JNR) was privatised. The railway system was split into six networks, all but one of which have proved to be highly profitable. JNR has been able to diversify its activities and get into all sorts of other areas, which is resulting in a better and cheaper service for the user. In the first 12 months the only division of Japan National Railways still not to show a profit is the freight division, but it looks as though it will probably come into the black during the next 12 months.

There is room for the privatisation debate to be extended in Australia beyond just Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd, which are currently taking the headlines. I believe that everybody in this place, no matter what party he represents, should be thinking very carefully about the effect of the intrusion of government into so many areas which exist to serve the public, and to serve the public at the right price. We should be prepared to be flexible enough in our thinking to study fully so many of the sacred cows we have been taking for granted that could go out into the private sector and deliver a better and cheaper service. That is really what government is all about. We are here to serve the best interests of the people. I doubt whether some of the things we have been doing traditionally over the last 10 or 20 years have been in those best interests. While the revolutionary fervour regarding privatisation is abroad, certainly on this side of the chamber but also in a fair section of the Government, let us make the most of it and see whether we can meet our true commitments to providing services that are efficiently produced and economically priced for the people of Australia.

With those words it gives me very great pleasure to second the amendment of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong. I sincerely hope that Government members, or the two Government members who are in the chamber now, are prepared to consider the amendment and take its spirit to heart. In the interests of all Australians, we might be able to get away from some of the ideological rhetoric and get down to the business of providing cheap, decent and profit- able services for the people of Australia-I know that it might hurt some of the Government members-even if it has to be through the private sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), a member of the Liberal Party of Australia, said that we needed to get away from the ideological battles on this issue, yet his whole argument was based on ideological statements and suppositions. When one is dealing with the concrete world of the real economy one has to ask whether the performance of the private sector, which the honourable member eulogised and supported throughout his speech, has been as laudable as he claimed-indeed, whether it has been even reasonable. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and to this chamber that the investment performance of the private sector in recent times, which is the key issue, has been very poor. It has been poor in circumstances in which it should have been much better, that is, in circumstances in which the wages of workers have been reduced, and profits have increased substantially, in real terms. In that context one might have expected an increase in investment and in the investment performance of enterprises in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: So before we eulogise the private sector we have to ask whether all the theoretical nonsense put forward, the ideological claim, about the wonderful performance of the private sector and the supposedly bad performance of the public sector-I will come to that point in a little while-has any substance in reality. If one looks at the performance of the private sector and at investment patterns in a number of countries one sees that there are serious problems in private sector investment in the Western world at the moment, and in Australia in particular. This is occurring in a context in which it is not justified. It is not justified because, on the one hand, there has been increasing profitability and, on the other hand, there has been an increase in the wealth of individuals who own companies through the imputation of company dividends, where companies do not pay tax on the wealth they accumulate and through other tax measures. Why is enough of this accumulated wealth not being reinvested, especially in manufacturing but in industry generally? That is an issue which those people who begin with the premise of eulogising the private sector ought to be able to answer. They have not been able to answer it. They ought to look at whether they are just simply making ideological or theoretical statements about the supposed role of the private sector as distinct from the actual concrete performance.

A similar thing in reverse terms applies in relation to the public sector. We hear many attacks on the Australian public sector. There have been claims about inefficiency, claims about how it can never deliver the goods and claims about its profitability in the case of public enterprises. Most of the claims that are made are false and are not based on fact. Anyone who has travelled around the world and who compares the performance of the Australian public sector with many of the other public sectors around the world will see something which is not admitted by our opponents, but which we ought to look at in cold terms. The Australian public sector's performance stands up. The Australian public sector has been positive in its performance. There are some exceptions, of course there are, but in overall terms when we compare the efficiency of private and public sector operations in Australia, especially the efficiency of private and public companies, and even if we use criteria of the levels of return, the fact of the matter is that many Australian public corporations have performed very well. The problem is-we readily admit this-the restrictions which in the past have been imposed on public corporations. These restrictions were imposed on Australian Airlines, Qantas Airways Ltd and on many of our other corporations. As a result of those restrictions those corporations have got themselves into trouble. That will be a key part of the privatisation debate which seems to have been initiated here in this chamber today. Let me make it perfectly clear that it is not enough to make wild statements about inefficiency of enterprises, we have to support those statements with the evidence and the history of those corporations.

If we look at Australian Airlines and compare it with Ansett Airlines of Australia we see that Ansett has not had any of the restrictions which have been imposed on Australian Airlines in terms of its borrowing capacity. Imagine any company, whether public or private, that has severe restrictions placed on its capacity to expand and on its borrowing capacities. Obviously it cannot compete in a proper fashion. This is what has happened in the past to Australian Airlines and to Qantas. As a result of these restrictions and other rules and regulations that are imposed on those enterprises in terms of their performance, their situation has deteriorated. Leaving aside Australian Airlines for the moment, if we look at the other major public corporations we see that in some cases their performance has been excellent, in other cases it has been good and we have had problems in only a few cases. In the case of Australian Airlines, as I said, problems have been imposed by undue and unnecessary restrictions on capital raisings, on its borrowing capacity and on its capacity to expand when required. There have been excessive regulations in the requirements of those enterprises. We all recognise that. That is something that is accepted on this side of the House-the need for more flexibility and the need for public enterprises to be able to go out and compete in the general environment. But to accept all this is a very different proposition from accepting the selling off of enterprises.

The amendment moved by the Opposition is that Australian Airlines should be sold off. Listening to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fadden, one would think that this was a panacea for the problems of Australian Airlines, that this was going to solve all its problems and was going to create some wonderful environment for airline flight in Australia. This is just utter nonsense. The fact of the matter is that the problems that have arisen in the aviation industry are much more complex than that. They do not have to do with the fact that there is one publicly owned airline. That is not the cause of all the problems. Some of the problems have been caused by the nature and operation of the two-airline policy-everyone admits that-the way in which it was imposed and the rules and regulations that went with it. But that is very different from saying that what is required is to sell off Australian Airlines because if Australian Airlines is sold off what will be the positive benefit? First of all we have to ask: Where would the money be coming from in terms of purchasing the shares in Australian Airlines? Obviously if Australian Airlines is worth a few hundred million dollars, or perhaps more than $1 billion-which obviously it is-those who are buying it will have to borrow money. If they borrow money from overseas, what happens? It means that our overseas debt will increase.

TALK.START.PARA: —Gross debt.

—Our overseas debt increases. The honourable member should just follow the argument because he needs to learn a lot about this privatisation issue. If our overseas debt increases, how does that help the economy? I thought that the whole purpose of what we are trying to do at the moment is to reduce our overseas debt. One might say, `All right, it is not going to be taken out of overseas debt, it is going to be taken out of Australia'. Well, if we take out $1 billion from the Australian capital market just so that people can buy shares in Australian Airlines so as to privatise it, that means that all that money which could have gone into investment, new enterprises and new jobs is not going to go into that investment but will go into effectively moving an existent operation from the public sector to the private sector. We still have that same operation but we miss out on all the money which could have been used for investment in other purposes. What is the net benefit? Further, if Australian Airlines needs a $250m capital injection, whoever buys it will still have to put in that capital injection. So that capital injection still has to be found, whether it is in the private or public sector. Can anyone explain to me how all this makes economic sense in terms of taking all that money out of an existent operation to transfer it from the public to the private sector? What will it achieve? It is clearly a situation which obviously needs to be argued out a bit more than what we have heard from the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me ask those opposite the following question: `Why not sustain Australian Airlines as a public enterprise and give it the power to really compete?'. That is the question that needs to be asked. I believe that if Australian Airlines were put into that position, not only would it be able to compete, and efficiently, but also it would be able to make a reasonable profit and deliver a service to the Australian people at a reasonable price.

Contrary to what the previous speaker tried to suggest, the cost of airline flight in Australia has in no way been caused by the fact that we have a public corporation in Australian Airlines. The cost of fares has a lot to do with the cross-subsidisation problem because people flying on longer routes have to be subsidised by people flying on shorter routes. That is not something which we would want to take away. This is an important matter in a continent like ours where we have places such as Perth which is far away. You would know about that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Surely we do not want to get rid of this cross-subsidisation situation and say to the airlines, `Well, if it only costs a certain amount to fly somebody from Canberra to Melbourne, that is the price he will pay'. Forget about the poor fellow that has to try to fly from Perth to Melbourne or from Perth to Sydney. Obviously, we would not want to get rid of that situation because we would then be in a very serious position in relation to the servicing of this continent. It is time we recognised that we have a vast continent with few people, and infrastructure, including airline infrastructure, is very important, just as telecommunications are very important. I am surprised, for example, that the members of the National Party of Australia are going to support the proposition put forward by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. If we sell Australian Airlines it will not be very long before the cross-subsidisation policy will disappear and country people, people in the far regions of Australia, will have to pay exorbitant fares to fly on airlines. If that is what members of the National Party want they do not represent the interests of the country people. They ought to reject the proposal put forward by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. It is all right for the Deputy Leader, coming from Kooyong in Melbourne. It will suit his purposes to be able to fly from Canberra to Melbourne at a cheaper rate, but what about the poor fellow who is living in a country town in the far reaches of Australia? What effect will these arrangements have on that person?

Another important reason why public enterprise ought to be involved in the aviation industry is that in such a vast continent physical infrastructure, including airline infrastructure, is a key issue. We are not a very small country where one can fly wherever one wants. Airlines are a key part of the infrastructure because of the size of this country and the geographical distribution of the people. It is because of that that we have a public interest in the outcome of the airline industry and that public interest needs to be supported. That public interest should be supported by ensuring that there is a public company that can compete with the other airlines.

What will we get with the forthcoming deregulation of the airline system? If people want to establish airlines they will be free to do so and to compete with the government airline. But if we get rid of the government airline we might end up with two companies supposedly in competition with one another. What will happen if they collude? A previous speaker in this debate talked about the airline industry in the United States of America. The US has more than 200 million people. Obviously it can sustain a number of airlines. It can ensure genuine competition among a number of airlines. Do honourable members think that if we had two private enterprise airlines-since obviously Australia is not big enough to sustain five or six airlines-we would be able to ensure genuine competition between them? I do not believe so. But if we have a publicly owned company, whose charter it is to compete on a proper basis with private airlines, we can ensure that any attempt at collusion is broken and we can achieve the very goals we are aiming for, which are cheaper air fares and a better service for the Australian people.

If there are people who want to get involved in establishing alternative airlines they will have their chance in a little while when the deregulation policy goes through. Why should they want to take over Australian Airlines, a publicly owned enterprise whose purpose is to keep the others honest, to ensure that there will not be any collusion? That will be the situation in a deregulated environment. I put it to the people who are thinking about selling off parts of Australian Airlines that, leaving aside the fact that the economic arguments for privatisation are foolish and ought to be rejected, firstly, there are social arguments for our being involved as a government through the public sector in the airline industry; and, secondly, we can ensure that competition among whatever airlines are going to exist under the deregulated environment is genuine by ensuring that at least one of the carriers is a public enterprise. It is a very similar situation to that of the banks. The Commonwealth Bank plays a very important role within the banking system. If the Commonwealth Bank were sold off we would be in a position where the other banks could collude, and that collusion could be the destruction of the banking system in terms of its delivery of services.

I support the Bill. I totally reject the amendment moved by the Opposition and I suggest that it is time for us to rethink much of the ideological rubbish that has been put forward as fact by those supposedly supporting the privatisation of government enterprises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are times when I feel rather sorry for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He has to put up with the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), who comes in here today to debate the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill and says that public enterprises should not be eliminated, that Australian Airlines should not be sold. Yet two weeks ago he voted for the legislation to sell 50 per cent of Australian Airlines, and so did other members of the Left. One gets very confused. I am sorry for the Prime Minister. I know the problem he has with members of his Government-we read about it daily in the Press-about whether the Government is going to privatise certain public interests throughout Australia. I do not think the Prime Minister will have any trouble with privatising Australian Airlines. I believe that he will succeed because people like the honourable member for Calwell will come into the House and vote for what the Government puts up.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears to me that the Government intends to go ahead with its privatisation policy. Not only is the Government talking about selling Australian Airlines, it is also going to have a go at Qantas Airways Ltd, the Australian National Line and Australian National, the railway. It is this Government's policy to proceed along those lines. The Australian Labor Party will meet at its conference in July and we will see how good the honourable member for Calwell and other members of the Left are. Will they be able to convince the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and other people on the Right or the Centre Left that they should not privatise public utilities? The outcome will be interesting. While all this proceeds, the Australian aviation industry does not know where it is going. It does not know where it is going because of the attitude of certain members of the Government. Does Australian Airlines proceed to invest? Does the Government continue to back it up financially so that it can operate efficiently? What is the attitude of Qantas? Does Qantas intend to pick up and put down here, to travel the domestic, the interstate, routes of Australia? Where does it stand? What is the attitude of Australian National and the Australian National Line? That is what really matters.

Let me finish this point by commenting on the comments of the honourable member for Calwell. He began by criticising the poor investment of private enterprise in industry and its expansion in Australia. There is only one reason why it is so poor, and I will tell honourable members why. It has not got confidence in this Government or the confidence to borrow money and to invest it in industry expansion in this country simply because of our national debt of $105 billion. With our inflationary trends, interest rates and the balance of trade, that have not been helped by yesterday's announcement, is it any wonder that private industry has not got the confidence to go ahead? It has to be given that confidence; that is important. There are Ministers of the Government and members on the Government side who are genuinely trying to get Australia back on the road. I believe the Treasurer is genuinely trying, but there are certain principles of policy that must be met, and this country has to get back to work. Only one thing will get us out of our economic problems and that is efficient productivity in industry.

I know that this is a wide-ranging debate, simply because of the amendment that has been moved by the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). We on this side of the House support the amendment because it is important. The fact is that the legislation before the House supports the levy that is being brought about by the legislation that we passed here a few weeks ago. We have to look at the privatisation of public utilities in Australia in a sensible light. I concur with the honourable member for Calwell that we have to consider cross-subsidisation, particularly with airlines and transport generally, but this can be allowed for. The Government may not want completely to sell out Australian Airlines. It has taken the proper step, the step which we took when in government in 1981. But this Government put the legislation aside and said it was not needed. Now it has brought in almost identical legislation. We allowed for the little investor. If the Government is concerned about who is going to buy 50 per cent of the shares that are for sale in Australian Airlines, it should always be concerned to ensure that the person to whom it gives the opportunity to buy shares is the little Australian investor, the working man out in the field. He may have only a little to spare, and if he has $500 or $1,000 to buy shares in a public utility, he should have that opportunity. Do not always think that it is the Japanese or some other overseas investor who will get the opportunity to buy up our interests. Do not forget that it is this Government's Treasurer who has opened up the door to foreign investment in this country. There are now far more Japanese, German and American funds coming into Australia to purchase real estate and shares than ever before.

I am sorry that because of the action that this Government has taken, which I personally and the other members of the Opposition certainly do not condemn, but which is a reality, its policies are going to be torn apart. They will be retarded simply because the philosophy of the people on the Left-I am sorry the Government has the Left-and possibly the Centre Left does not concur with the attitude of certain members of the Right. No leader of any political party, particularly when in government, can lead a government that is divided into two or three sections. That is exactly what is happening today with this Government. The Prime Minister has to contend with this. Instead of being able to focus his attention on those matters of basic national interest to Australia, he has to divert much of his time to try to quieten down the people who are opposing him within his own political regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will take the soft options.

—What the honourable member for Wide Bay says is right. Let us look quickly at the history of Australia. This is our bicentennial year. Ever since the turn of the century governments have had a responsibility to establish public utilities and services. It has been necessary over the past 100 years or more to cater for the wide geographical situation that demands this type of attention. Commonwealth and State governments have had to attend to this and have had to provide, from the public purse, the services that were necessary to cater particularly for the widespread country areas of Australia. This has been done. We have done a very good job as far as transportation by our railways, roads and airways is concerned. We could all criticise them, but I will not because I think that the Australian taxpayer realises that we have built Australia up to the crescendo we are now at, where we can compete with the rest of the world in industry and transport. We have to if we are going to export.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard debated in the House this morning that the airlines of Australia have to compete with overseas airlines that are bringing people here. Qantas cannot be protected forever. Ansett does not want to be protected because it has the get up and go attitude built within it. Australian Airlines has to compete with Ansett, and that is what is concerning the Government. These services have been built up within Australia but we have now reached the stage where whichever party is in power has to look at privatising part or all of the public utilities that we have.

A while ago I mentioned cross-subsidisation. Built into the policy of the Party that I represent here would be a commonsense attitude to the necessities arising to cross-subsidise some parts of public utilities. It might be in the telecommunications area, in Australia Post, in Qantas, in the Australian National Line or in Australian Airlines, but that attitude is there to ensure that certain people in this country are not being disadvantaged. But where we can, we have to look selectively, on a proper basis, to see what part of the public utilities can be privatised and given out to the Australian people who have the money to invest in something within Australia.

The Commonwealth Bank of Australia is in competition with other banks. I do not worry much about that, but there would be nothing wrong with selling off an interest in the Commonwealth Bank to its staff and other people. Why should that not happen? Why should Australian Airlines be a public utility? Why should it be half-owned by the Australian people? This Government is destined, due to its policies, to build up its social security payments to what it believes are the underprivileged people of Australia. If that is its policy, we accept that. But if the Government is going to continue with this, even with its high taxation methods, even with its new initiatives on capital gains, fringe benefits and the tax on superannuation, even with the legislation that was before the House yesterday, even with the benefit of those extra billions of dollars-I think the honourable member for Kooyong said this morning that there should be a Budget surplus at the end of this financial year of $2 billion-it will find that it will probably not be able to commit itself to spend what it wants as far as social security is concerned.

If the Prime Minister and the Treasurer wish to sell part of the public utilities in Australia so that the Government does not have to prop them up, that would appear to me to be a natural way of looking at policy over the years to come. So it is that if Australian Airlines is to compete with Ansett within Australia it has to be made efficient. The Government has to provide it with the money.
