It has to give the airline's board the initiative to create the efficiency to supply a service that is efficient and economic for the Australian travelling public. Those are the two basic things the Government must look at-providing services, and that they be economic services at reasonable prices for the consumer. That is why the amendment is before the House today. I solidly support that and I ask the Government to consider it seriously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The last couple of contributions I have sat through from the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) and the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) have tended to concentrate a great deal on the question of privatisation, whether Australian Airlines should be retained in public ownership or whether it should be privatised and parts offered for sale to employees or to the general public. Obviously, it is a subject that has exercised the minds of a number of people in recent weeks within this place and certainly without. Many comments have been made, and a number of journalists have been kept fairly busy trying to suss out the real situation or the real attitude inside the Federal Government towards privatisation. They are probably still guessing, and the resolution of that will come towards the middle of this year. It is a subject I will return to shortly as part of my contribution this morning. However, we need to re-establish just what we are talking about within this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill provides for a technical amendment to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 which will be required as a consequence of the passage of the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill 1987. I would like to take up just one point in the contribution by the honourable member for Lyne on that issue. I think the honourable member was a little confused about what the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill 1987 actually does. He talked about the fact that this Government and the honourable member for Calwell had voted to allow 50 per cent of the airline to be sold through the passage of that Bill. That is not true. That Bill simply created Australian Airlines as a public company and removed a number of the statutory controls on that company that presently exist. Of course, the Bill comes into effect on 31 March this year. It will improve the efficiency of Australian Airlines by removing a number of controls that presently exist and the necessity of having to seek support from government or the imprimatur of government and Ministers on some day to day decisions the airline has to make. This is an issue I debated during the passage of the Bill and I do not propose to touch on it any further except to say to the honourable member for Lyne that he is a little confused as to the content of that Bill as it was debated, and what it means.

The amendments we are talking about in this Bill will ensure that the Commonwealth borrowing levy will continue to apply to Australian Airlines and its wholly owned subsidiaries even after the airline itself has converted to a public company through the passage of the earlier Bill. People have to recognise that the Commonwealth borrowing levy is actually imposed on borrowings by all Commonwealth semi-government authorities and government owned companies other than those engaged in business and financial intermediation. This Bill will ensure that revenue of the order of $1.3m, based on 1987 figures, is raised through this levy and that the changed legal structure of Australian Airlines will not be affected in any way by the imposition of this levy.

Having said what this Bill seeks to do, I think it is political in the extreme that the honourable member for Kooyong, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), put forward an amendment to the motion which obviously seeks to embarrass the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and this Government about the debate that is presently under way within the Australian Labor Party on the whole issue of privatisation, and specifically the question of Australian Airlines. What has to be said, and it has been said by the Prime Minister and others on this side of the House in this place, is that we within the Labor Party are not afraid of debate on issues of major concern and significance to the Australian people. We provide for that debate within our party structure. We provide at the most basic level, within local branches, the opportunity for people to express a view-they are, after all, the average persons within our respective electorates. We then convene State conferences of the Party to consider measures of State significance, philosophical issues that the Labor Party believes as a party it must fairly represent. Finally, of course, every two years the Labor Party has a national conference where issues affecting the national platform and policy of the Australian Labor Party are debated, in some instances changed and in others simply left as they are.

The issue of privatisation of publicly owned instrumentalities, including Australian Airlines that we are considering during the debate on this Bill, is one that has captured the imagination of many people, to which I have already made reference. But I do not think that the honour- able member for Lyne has correctly represented the Government's position at this time. In fact, I think he has somewhat misrepresented not only the Government's position but also the position of the Australian Labor Party. It is often the wont of the conservatives in this country to point the finger at the left wing of the Australian Labor Party and suggest that anything that faction might care to raise as an issue is lunatic, is on the far-out of Australian politics and therefore has no credence. I refer the honourable member for Lyne to statements that have been made variously by people within the Australian Labor Party including John MacBean, the President of the Labor Party in New South Wales, certainly not a left winger, and a number of other notable people about the issue of privatisation. I point out also to the honourable member the position that was unanimously adopted by the administrative committee of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party on the question of privatisation-that was opposition. If the honourable member had any knowledge of the operations of the New South Wales branch of the Australian Labor Party-as he comes from New South Wales I am sure he does-he would quickly see that the views expressed in the resolution of opposition are not those of a lunatic left fringe within the Party but indeed a consensus position arrived at by all members of the Party in New South Wales.

Australian Airlines as it stands today has to be commended. I say this especially with reference to a media release issued on 24 February 1988 headed `Profitable First Half Year for Australian Airlines'. In that Press release Australian Airlines announced a consolidated group profit from all sources of $42.5m for the first six months to 31 December 1987, which represented an increase of 32.3 per cent over the corresponding period in 1986. That says something about the operation of a publicly owned company. We have heard people say that one of the basic rationales for having Australian Airlines privatised is that it gives the company the opportunity to bring in whiz-bang people from the financial sector or from the business community who can do a better job than those already employed by Australian Airlines. The profit levels that have accrued to Australian Airlines in the first half of this financial year, I suggest, give the lie to the concern that people have put forward and suggest also that publicly owned companies can operate just as efficiently by remaining publicly owned as they can if they are privatised or sold.

There is no question that some of the service being offered by Australian Airlines has been rationalised. Throughout Australia, since the inception of airline services a number of ports serviced by various airlines have been rationalised. However, that is simply a matter of economics and a question of a public enterprise and a private enterprise-Ansett Airlines of Australia-responding to market forces. Trans Australian Airlines, as it was then, now Australian Airlines, responded to those market forces in the same manner as the Thomas National Transport Ltd group did through Ansett Airlines.

The total furphy that publicly-owned airlines or publicly-owned enterprises cannot function as efficiently as those in the private sector skirts around the basic issue. This probably says something about those who are at the moment on the board of Australian Airlines, in particular the General Manager. I defy anybody from the conservative side to suggest that James Strong has done anything but a marvellous job for Australian Airlines since taking up his position. I should think also that, although there would not be too many members on this side of the House who applauded his appointment initially, they would have since acknowledged the effect that his appointment has had.

We also have to look at some of the questions that surround Australian Airlines, and the removal of government controls that have been implemented, to get a real feel for this headlong rush towards privatisation, of selling to shareholders of a particular company or to the general public, and to determine why it might be beneficial. We have to examine the statement of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) in October last year when he announced the Government's decision to remove a whole series of controls over such matters as all but exceptional significant expenditure decisions, detailed terms and conditions of borrowing and leasing arrangements, investment of surplus money, choice of auditor, dividend recommendations, and the provision of insurance against risk. All those matters are simple business transactions that take effect whether a company is a public company or a private company.

Additionally, as I indicated earlier, the Government introduced the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill 1987 whereby a public company has been created and many of the controls lifted. The Government, through its structural adjustment committee of Cabinet, is giving consideration to removing a number of broad controls that also exist over Australian Airlines, as they exist with a number of other public enterprises. This action will free the company up and, at the same time, will retain it in public ownership.

We are talking about such issues as borrowings being subject to Loan Council considerations, and the remuneration of board members and senior executives being determined by the Remuneration Tribunal. Obviously that matter is of concern to those who are with Australian Airlines at the moment. Further issues include industrial relations arrangements being subject to Government oversight and coordination and restrictions on superannuation arrangements. All those issues have been or are being addressed by the Government.

So far as the financial situation is concerned, the honourable member for Lyne commented that a public company requires an injection of government finances all the time to keep the company afloat. Again that is a slight misrepresentation of the facts. Interestingly enough, the last capital injection into Australian Airlines was of the order of $115m in 1982-83. That injection was made not by this Government but by a conservative government led by Malcolm Fraser and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). I wonder whether that decision was taken on the basis of that Government's having to do something about a public company or whether at that stage the consideration was: `Yes, this company is in a little trouble'-as it was in the early 1980s-`so why do we not flog it off now? We are the great believers in privatisation and private enterprise'. Why was it not done then if the Opposition is so gung ho about the issue now?

I hope that, if any Opposition member follows me in this debate, he might care to answer that particular question. This Government has not made an injection of finance since 1982-83, which indicates that this Government is not lending to Australian Airlines in any way at all. The Government acts as a guarantor of borrowings of the company in a truly deregulated, normal and commercial sense, which is advantageous. I see nothing wrong with that practice. The two-airline policy was, again, of the making of the conservative parties in this House. The Australian Labor Party did not put that policy in place. The Government did not enshrine the policy of only two airlines operating in Australia. Yet the Opposition talks about having to sell off the company that the Australian people already own. By virtue of the fact that we can act as guarantor for the finances of that company, it has been kept afloat and a monopoly situation has been prevented from developing in this country, with Australian Airlines going under and being subjected to total dominance by companies such as the Ansett group of companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —What absolute rubbish! The same guarantee applies with Ansett.

—I suggest to the shadow Minister at the table, who endeavoured to interject a moment ago, that he provide clarification of the position that the Opposition will adopt once the deregulation of the airline industry takes place in 1990. He is holding up the amendment of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, but a simple sentence such as that does not carry much weight in the absence of a firm policy. We would like to know what that might be.

SPEECH.PARA: To summarise this legislation, what we have witnessed is concern being expressed yet again by the Government that for a publicly-operated company to be able to continue to compete effectively and efficiently in a truly deregulated and competitive environment and at the same time remain under public control requires the removal of some government controls and regulations. This Bill seeks to do that. It is complementary to a Bill that was debated in this House recently, and passed. With the creation of Australian Airlines as a public company on 31 March we will see a more viable, stronger airline being able to compete effectively with the Ansett group and, at the same time, being part and parcel of the Australian scene in terms of being publicly owned. I advise the honourable member for Lyne that it will take a lot more than some of the arguments he put to me to convince me that there is a need to step back from the position that exists currently within Australian Labor Party policy about the public ownership of Australian Airlines.

However, I might be persuaded by or entertained to consider the proposition that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West), my neighbour from the Illawarra, is presently running with; that is, looking at the viability of combining both Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines in such a manner that an overseas carrier could operate as a domestic carrier in the deregulated environment that will come in 1990. That proposition may have some attractive features, but again I remain to be convinced about it. However, the Government should address it, which I am sure it will, in the proper forums that exist-through the Government's committee structures and so on. I am sure that, once that consideration has taken place, without the glaring headlines and the criticisms of the Party for discussing issues of great significance for the Australian public, the Government will have achieved an effective policy that will clearly reflect the desires, wishes and requirements of the Australian public. I join with my colleagues in rejecting the attempt by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to politicise statements attributed to the Prime Minister about privatisation, particularly as they affect Australian Airlines. I suggest that as time goes by we will see the wisdom of the decisions that this Government and this Party ultimately will make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Opposition amendment in relation to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill, which in part is in the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House endorses the sale of Australian Airlines, and therefore supports the Prime Minister's statement that ``I believe that an Australian Airlines, whether totally in private hands or an Australian Airlines with a significant private holding, with therefore correspondingly diminished demands upon public resources, could perform the function of Australian Airlines at least as well as they are now and, I would say, arguably, better'' '.

I agree with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), which is rather unusual because there are not many issues on which I agree with him. I wish to give five reasons as to why I agree with him. If one looks at the situation of Australian Airlines now, after many years of government control, one finds an organisation that is really struggling to compete. First, if one looks at the corporate structure of Australian Airlines compared with that of its competitor, Ansett Airlines of Australia, one sees a glaring difference. Ansett has a broad corporate structure with airline passenger, airline freight, road passenger, road freight; general trading; manufacturing; hotel, resort, and restaurant operations; insurance interests; furniture insurance; furniture removal and other associated companies. By comparison, Australian Airlines, the Government controlled airline, has a very narrow corporate structure with airline passenger, airline freight, Hertz Rent-a-Car and two tourist resorts-hardly an equal competitor.

The second reason why I support the Prime Minister's statement and support the amendment is that, if again one compares the two companies, one sees that Australian Airlines has fared very badly with its network base, that is, its feeder aircraft system which is very important to any domestic carrier. Ansett Airlines controls Air Western Australia, Air New South Wales, Skywest New South Wales, Skywest Western Australia, Kendall Airlines, Lloyd Airlines and, through a parent company, Bodas, controls Aeropelican. Australian Airlines has a fairly sad record. Two years ago it bought Air Queensland for $9m. That has gone broke and the company has closed it down.

The third reason why I support the Prime Minister's statement and support the amendment of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) is the government constraints that exist on Australian Airlines. If one listened only to the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin), one would think that there were virtually no constraints now on Australian Airlines. The fact is that Australian Airlines still needs Loan Council approval for major equipment purposes; the Government still has discretion to alter profit objectives, and as a Federal organisation Australian Airlines is excluded from some intrastate routes. The remuneration of board members can be influenced by tribunals, and the broader government policies on industrial relations may hamper operations of Australian Airlines. This was tellingly revealed in the briefing document that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) gave to Caucus. He raised several points. They were that during lengthy disputes Ansett has achieved an earlier return to work, while Australian finalises Government approval, that the negotiating status of airline management is diminished through unions' knowledge that Government approval is required; and that the arrangements reinforce the Public Service image of the airlines and, most importantly, they restrict the ability of airline management to respond directly to industrial issues. These are the constraints still on Australian Airlines by virtue of its public control.

The fourth reason that I agree with the Prime Minister's statement and support the amendment is that an examination of the structure of the two airlines is also telling. Australian Airlines has nine government appointees who are appointed for five years at a time with average length of service 3.8 years; three out of nine have a strong background in aviation or transport. When one compares that with its competitor, one sees that it does not have those government constraints. Ansett has 11 directors with average service of 9.2 years, 2 1/2 times that of Australian. Some nine out of the 11 directors have a strong background in transport or aviation. There are seven alternates who stand in for directors. These people have an average length of service of 6.1 years-still vastly greater than Australian. Five of those seven have a strong background in transport or aviation.

The fifth reason that I support the Prime Minister's statement and the Opposition's amendment is on the basis of efficiency: I have listened to every Labor member talk in this debate and query whether there is any evidence that efficiency in a public company is different from that of a private company. The honourable member for Macarthur called it a furphy. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) made several statements which I shall mention in a moment. But the efficiency of the two airlines has been looked at. The May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation in an appendix put in a report by the firm of accountants Travers Morgan Pty Ltd. It looked specifically at the relative efficiency of the two airlines, and specifically at five measures. In those five measures Australian came out on top in only one. The five measures were aircraft utilisation, in which Australian because it was strapped for cash used its aircraft more than Ansett. But in regard to the other parameters, such as unit cost, which is cost per passenger kilometre, Australian Airlines cost 10.5 per cent more for every passenger kilometre travelled. In regard to passenger revenue yield, the revenue per passenger kilometre saw Australian 15 per cent lower than Ansett. In terms of labour productivity Australian was 8 per cent lower than Ansett. In profitability Ansett was 9 per cent, Australian 5.1 per cent. Those differences will not be changed by altering a few of the controls that government has over the public airline and leaving the majority still intact.

The honourable member for Calwell raised several points to which I should like to respond. First, he spoke of the poor performance of private sector investment and challenged the Opposition to provide some reason for this. It is true that private sector investment as a percentage of gross domestic product is at its lowest level since the 1950s. The honourable member for Calwell raised two points. He said that the profitability of companies was up and the wealth of individuals was up. He said that those who eulogise the private sector should answer why we have a low private investment performance. I shall give him two answers. The first is that in the 1985-86 figures for company after-tax income-the most recent figures we have-the level is still below any year in the 1970s. With company tax increased by this Government, investment will continue to remain low.

The second reason why investment is low is found when one looks at rates of return of business, which perhaps are a better indicator to private sector investment. Statement No. 2 of the 1987 Budget Papers conveniently omitted the fact that rates of return for private companies are much lower than they were in the 1960s or in the early 1970s and the risk now is much higher than it was previously. This is the reason why the private sector is not investing.

The honourable member for Calwell mentioned that the Opposition was making wild statements about the inefficiency of the public sector. He said any comparison showing that the public sector was less efficient than the private sector was false, had no substance in reality and was not based on fact. I suggest that the honourable member should go a little further and read something other than his Australian Labor Party briefing notes. He may care to read anything by David Davies of Duke University, Peter Forsyth of the University of New South Wales, Richard Hocking of the University of Melbourne, Michael Kirby and Robert Albon of the Australian National University-not writing Labor Party briefing notes, but writing in the Economic Record or the US Journal of Law Economics-who, writing over a period of 18 years, have examined the relative efficiencies of Australian Airlines and Ansett. These two airlines, in economic terms, are called twins-they are very rare in the world-where there is one public and one private company operating within similar environments with similar constraints. Every writer in the economic literature over a period of 18 years has come to the same conclusion-that is, all other things being equal, a public company is less efficient than a private one. There is very good economic evidence for that.

The honourable member for Calwell also put forward a curious argument against the privatisation of Australian Airlines by saying that if it were privatised the private sector would have to borrow $1 billion overseas, and this would increase our foreign debt. To use his own words, `Explain to me how all this makes sense'. Well, I will do that gladly. The $1 billion that is raised to pay for Australian Airlines will be paid to the Government. If the Government obtains $1 billion for Australian Airlines it will decrease the Government's own borrowing requirements. Part of the reason our foreign debt has increased so much is that, because of the level of borrowings onshore of the Australian Government, the private sector was forced to go offshore. If the Government receives $1 billion to add to its surplus this will reduce the Government's borrowing requirements and contribute to reducing our foreign debt. Secondly, if the Government brings in an additional surplus it will reduce pressure on exchange rates. For those two reasons it makes good sense.

Two speakers on the Government side spoke about capital injection. I was interested to hear the honourable member for Macarthur talk about the Fraser Government's $115m capital injection. I tend to agree with him. I had a debate in the House with the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) some time ago when the honourable member chided the Fraser Government for not injecting enough money, and suggested that the Hawke Government had done a wonderful job. What actually happened was that in 1961 an initial capital injection of $15m was given, and that was sufficient for many years. Australian met its requirements through borrowings, and it had no trouble with the Loan Council. It only became a problem in the late 1970s, and when it did become a problem the Fraser Government instituted an inquiry, which reported in 1982. That inquiry mentioned the need for further capital injection; $25m was given as an interim measure, and then a further $90m was given eight weeks into the Hawke Government's term. I imagine that with that $90m injection they just changed the Minister's name on the letterhead. The honourable member for Macarthur said that the Hawke Government had not made any further capital injection into Australian Airlines. Quite true, but I cannot see how he sees that as a benefit. Australian Airlines is now totally strapped for cash. It needs a major capital injection if it is to continue and compete equally.

The honourable member for Macarthur said the two-airline agreement was introduced by a Liberal government. Yes, sir, that is correct. People on the other side seem to mention this as though there was something wrong with it. The two-airline policy was introduced at that time to remove a competitive advantage. With respect to airlines, there is an enormous barrier to entry for new players, and it is quite reasonable, when there are these enormous barriers to other entrants, for government to come in and try to level the playing field. One existing airline must not have the ability, because of these barriers, to stop others entering. Also, one airline run by the Government may in fact have an unfair competitive advantage over a privately run firm. Again, to stop this happening is a reasonable role for government to play. The two-airline policy was appropriate in the 1950s. It is not appropriate in the 1980s and it will be abolished.

Finally, I support this amendment and I support the Prime Minister's statement. He is absolutely correct on this, and unless this Government has the courage to fully free Australian Airlines from all the constraints placed on it-this will happen only by allowing it to compete as a private company with Ansett Airlines-we will have a one-and-a-bit airline policy and the Australian public will be the sufferers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start my contribution today by welcoming back to the chamber the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris), who has been ill. In some comments I made to the House recently I wished him a speedy recovery; we are glad to see him back. We are glad to see him back to talk about aviation matters not only because he has recovered his health but also because in his absence we have had an absolute cavalcade of Ministers purporting to speak on aviation matters, and I can assure the Minister at the table that they also will be glad to see him back because they made an absolute hash of it while he was away.

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill, presented on 7 October last year, seeks to amend the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act 1987 to reflect the fact that the Government has now converted Australian Airlines from a statutory authority to a public company. The wording of the Bill introduced on 7 October last year reads, in clause 4:
This Act applies to borrowings of money, otherwise than from the Commonwealth . . .

What this Bill really seeks to do, and it is what the previous Bill sought to do, is ensure that statutory corporations borrowing funds other than from the Commonwealth pay the levy so that they do not bypass the financial markets, which in any event had regarded those statutory authorities as being such that the Government would stand behind any borrowings.

The first question this raises is what the relevance of this is in so far as the competitive marketplace is concerned between Ansett and Australian Airlines. The first observation to be made is that the effect of this Bill is to penalise Australian Airlines to the extent of the borrowings that are not made from the Commonwealth. We have the two airlines competing with each other, both in the process of borrowing money from sources other than the Commonwealth. One of them, Australian Airlines, is required to pay this levy; the other, Ansett Airlines of Australia, is not. We have a situation where the playing field is not level. It is not only in this Bill that we see the Government taking action that penalises Australian Airlines compared to Ansett. We saw it recently in a Bill we debated in the House on the superannuation associated with Australian Airlines. In that Bill, the Government required that, for those employees of Australian Airlines who were still part of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, Australian Airlines should bring to account those funds it was required to bring to account so that the Commonwealth would not be forced to pay out those additional moneys for Australian Airlines to honour its obligations under its superannuation requirements. That meant that Australian Airlines was required to bring to account an additional $4.9m. Comparing the superannuation funds of Australian Airlines and Ansett, which are essentially the same except for those employees who remain in the Commonwealth superannuation scheme, this had the effect of putting Australian Airlines at a $4.9m disadvantage against Ansett. So we have two recent examples of Government actions that are putting Australian Airlines at a competitive disadvantage with Ansett.

We do not have any objection-and we did not state any objection-to the Government introducing this levy or asking Australian Airlines to account for this superannuation amount. But we point out that, by virtue of its current policies, which maintain Australian Airlines in the public sector while Ansett competes from the private sector, this Government is penalising Australian Airlines and putting it at a competitive disadvantage with Ansett. It seems odd, to say the least, that at a time when the Government is considering what it should be doing with Australian Airlines, at a time when it has this raging internal debate on privatisation, at a time when the factions of the Australian Labor Party are trying to establish their position on privatisation, it should introduce two separate pieces of legislation, within a few months of each other, both of which put Australian Airlines at a competitive disadvantage with Ansett.

One must ask the question: is this just another one of the things that happen when a government is in trouble as this Government is in trouble? It is now demonstrably clear that the Government is completely out of touch with the Australian electorate. Is it one of the things that happen when governments are out of touch and floundering around-to legislate to put Australian Airlines at a competitive disadvantage with Ansett on two occasions-or is it part of the scenario that will be used at the Australian Labor Party (ALP) conference in June? Will those people who attend the conference be told, `Look, we have to privatise Australian Airlines. One of the reasons why we have to privatise Australian Airlines is that it is operating at a competitive disadvantage with Ansett.'? What is the Government all about regarding these two recent pieces of legislation?

This brings me to the whole question of the financing of Australian Airlines. We all know that the Government has created an advisory group to advise on future financing options for Australian Airlines. That advisory group was due to report in March. Today's date is 16 March. One wonders why the Government is not waiting for the report of the advisory group before it goes ahead with this amendment. I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the House that the composition of the advisory group is very interesting. It is chaired by Mr Harris, the new Chairman of Australian Airlines. I wish Mr Harris much success-as I have on previous occasions-with his administration, even though in recent times the Government has lumbered him with two pieces of legislation, both of which will put him at some disadvantage in competition with Ansett. Mr Harris will lock in Australian Airlines to the decision made by the group in its recommendations.

Mr Kelty, the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), is a member of the group. One could reasonably expect that, when this group reports, Mr Kelty's views will be very strongly taken into account by the Australian Council of Trade Unions. We know that no decision can be taken by this Government without reference to the ACTU and without getting its blessing. Mr Kelty's views on the future financing options and the recommendation that the advisory group makes to the Government will lock in the ACTU. Dr Wilenski, the head of the Department of Transport and Communications, is a member of the group. No doubt the way that Dr Wilenski feels will lock in the Department of Transport and Communications and, with it, the two Ministers in the other place and the Minister at the table. Mr Redlich is a member of the advisory group. He is a former President of the Labor Party in Victoria and no doubt will be in a position to ensure that those fractious members of the Labor Party in Victoria, particularly some members of the left wing, are also locked into the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Peter Redlich, the President of the Labor Party, who was Clyde Holding's partner in a legal practice?
—He is the one.
—He has just been made chairman of the Victorian TAB.
—He is the one. My friend the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has pointed out that Mr Redlich has extensive--
—Mateship runs strong.

—Mateship runs strong in the Labor Party, in Victoria as elsewhere, but I will come to that in a moment. I am delighted that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), is in the chamber. I have much pleasure in supporting the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill that he put forward today, stating that the House endorses the sale of Australian Airlines, and which includes some statements of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In supporting the amendment one has to ask: What will happen to Australian Airlines if it is not privatised? The answer is well known because the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) has put out a policy option paper describing the situation. It is well known that Australian Airlines will need a capital injection of $250m over the next few years. In fact, Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd between them will need, in order to re-equip their fleets and remain competitive in their respective markets, about $1 billion over the next few years. The source of that information does not come from some reporter who is writing things up, but from the Minister.

Where will that money come from? It can come only from one of two sources. It can come from the Treasury or from the private sector. The Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) have frequently said that there will be no more money for Australian Airlines to re-equip its fleet. The Prime Minister does not talk so much about privatisation; he uses that word that he says he does not use, but he also uses another phrase, too, that is, `optimisation of resources'. The Government has made it very clear that it would prefer to see the money that is to fund the fleet development for Australian Airlines coming from sources other than the taxpayer. It is clear that at least the senior members of the Government are setting themselves up to argue at the ALP's National Conference in June that, firstly, Australian Airlines is not able to compete on equal terms with Ansett and therefore it should be privatised and, secondly, there is simply no money in the Treasury to re-equip the fleet for Australian Airlines. That is an additional reason why the ownership of Australian Airlines should be transferred from the public sector to the private sector. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has made clear in his amendment to the Bill that that is our policy. It is clear from the Prime Minister's statement, as quoted in the amendment, that the Prime Minister supports that proposal.

I point out to the House that the Government is acting with some hypocrisy in this matter. After all, the coalition brought in legislation in the early 1980s to convert Australian Airlines, or Trans Australia Airlines as it was then, from a government statutory authority to a company. That legislation was repealed by this Government in 1984. A few short years later it has reintroduced legislation, similar to that passed by the coalition in the early 1980s, that converts Australian Airlines into a public company and will have the effect of eliminating a large number of the government controls that exist on the operation of that airline.

I again ask why the Government does not wait for the report of the advisory group which is presumably due fairly soon. Perhaps the Minister for Transport and Communications Support, who is at the table, when he responds to this second reading debate on what is essentially a matter to do with airlines, as I presume he will do, will be able to tell the House when the report of the advisory group is due. Let me make it clear again that the coalition would transfer ownership of Australian Airlines from the public to the private sector. That was the policy we brought forward at the last election. We believe that the privatisation of Australian Airlines would bring benefits to consumers and would allow the travelling public to have access to the airways of Australia with relatively lower fares and relatively better services.

One cannot make remarks about the privatisation of Australian Airlines without saying a few words about the extent to which the coalition would be prepared to see one airline or another trend toward a monopoly situation. I make it quite clear that there is no way in which the coalition would condone a monopoly situation arising in our domestic airlines. What we would do to make sure that that situation did not arise would be to use the Trade Practices Act to ensure that the travelling public of Australia were appropriately protected.

While touching on government policy on airlines, I would like to say a few words about what has happened in recent days regarding the possibility that the former Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, who resigned from this House a few weeks ago, will become a consultant to Qantas Airways Ltd. The Prime Minister said in answer to a question that was asked yesterday--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. I appreciate the honourable member's interest in matters other than those relevant to the Bill before the chamber, but the Bill is a very narrow Bill. It is a technical amendment to one of our Acts. It has nothing whatsoever to do with the matters the honourable member is raising. I suggest, Mr Deputy Speaker, that he be brought back to the issue before the House and not raise the matters he is proposing to raise.

—With respect, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Bill we are debating is a Bill to amend the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act, which includes in its schedule all the airline activities associated with the Commonwealth. I therefore submit that a few short remarks on the Qantas situation are in order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, as I said, the Bill is a very narrow Bill. It is a technical amendment to the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Act and has nothing whatsoever to do with the matters the honourable member wishes to raise. I ask that he be directed to refrain from making the kind of remark he wants to make.

—The Chair appreciates the point of order raised by the Minister. However, the debate this morning has been very wide ranging. Accordingly, the Chair must rule that the honourable member for Deakin is in order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am sorry that time does not allow me to develop this point to its full extent. In regard to the Government's dealing on airline matters, the Prime Minister knew some weeks ago that Mr Young had been offered a job with Qantas. He did nothing about it. At that time, Mr Young-

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a new point of order. I read to you from the Bill. The Bill deals specifically with Australian Airlines. I refer to the schedule, clause 3 of the Bill. It does not refer to other airlines. I understand from your remarks that there may have been a wide-ranging debate, but I take the point of order that the Bill is narrow in its compass and deals specifically with Australian Airlines. If the matters being raised deal specifically with Australian Airlines, I understand that. I again ask, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you rule the honourable member out of order on this matter.

—The Chair appreciates the point which the Minister raises. I do not think the Minister has been in the House this morning to listen to the debate, which has been very wide ranging indeed. Practically every airline throughout the world has been spoken about this morning. So I feel that I have to rule that the honourable member for Deakin is in order.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I can understand the sensitivity of the Government on this matter. The Minister has made a very strong effort to curtail my time. Government members are sensitive about this matter because undoubtedly a conflict of interest has arisen. I commend the amendment to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) for his good wishes on my return to duty and for the concerns he expressed for me during my absence. I did read them, but I will join in discussion on those matters another day, a day to which I look forward with some relish. As I was saying to you in my points of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Commonwealth Borrowing Levy Amendment Bill is a very narrow Bill. Whilst the debate may have been wide ranging, I thank all of those who participated in it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am utterly fascinated by the new-found concern of the Opposition for the welfare of Australian Airlines and of air travellers. Having spent some years in debate on the other side of the chamber and having opposed the policies then pursued by those who now sit in opposition, I am utterly fascinated by this new-found concern. Talk about a rebirth! They are born again consumer advocates. Suddenly honourable members opposite are interested in the role of public sector enterprises and their financial viability. If those who now sit in opposition, including the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), had had those views in 1981 there would not be a two-airline agreement in existence today. Had they supported the amendment we moved in 1981, the existing two airlines agreement would have terminated in January 1987. It would not be there. So I find a great deal of hypocrisy in the words expressed by the honourable member for Deakin. They ought to be discarded from the outset for what they are-a piece of hypocrisy that represents a complete reversal of attitude by the Opposition.

It is to the Opposition's eternal disgrace that for decade after decade the people of this country were denied the kinds of air services they could have had, the level of competition that ought to have existed and the presence of a strong, viable public sector operator in domestic airline services because of the Opposition's policies, because of its two-airline agreement and because of the way it treated Australian Airlines. We should not forget, Mr Deputy Speaker-you would recall this, as you were here then-the non-commercial dividends extracted from Australian Airlines by the Fraser Government. When the honourable member for Bennelong, the current Leader of the Opposition, was the Treasurer, the Government subjected that airline, that public sector enterprise, to continual criticism, destabilisation, attacks, and charges that the organisation was technically bankrupt. It imposed upon it a superannuation burden which the airline still has to cover today. So whatever problems Australian Airlines may have developed when this Government came into office, they were problems created by the present Opposition.

To listen to the criticism today about this Government's policy towards Australian Airlines makes one realise what hypocrisy and cant are coming from those who now speak on aviation policy for the Opposition. I can best summarise this by referring to the words spoken by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) in this chamber a few years ago. He said that, as a former Minister for Transport and former Minister responsible for Australian Airlines, he had to say that, in his period of government, those seven dark years of Fraserism, Australian Airlines was forced to fly with one wing tied behind its back. So let us not hear any more of this mock concern for the position of Australian Airlines from the Opposition. The Opposition ought to think back with shame to the way it managed the organisation when it had the responsibility of government. I thank those honourable members who have participated in the debate. For the reasons I have outlined, the Government rejects the amendment that has been moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Peacock's amendment) stand part of the question.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
