QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR M. J. YOUNG: EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Will he confirm media reports that he contacted Mr Frank Lowy of the Channel 10 group and Mr Dick Pratt of Visy Pty Ltd Board regarding employment opportunities for Mr Young? What other companies or persons did he contact?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no difficulty at all in terms of what I have done in this matter and whom I have contacted. I believe, however, that should any contractual relationship occur between Mr Young and either of the two people I have contacted that is a matter properly to be disclosed, if they wish, by the people concerned and Mr Young. I make it clear that I have absolutely no problem, no difficulty, at all, where a contract is entered into between Mr Young and either of the two people whom I contacted, if they wish to disclose that fact. That is a matter for them. I respect their rights. I repeat: I have nothing of concern in this matter, nothing at all.
—But you are Prime Minister.

—I know I am Prime Minister and a very good one whose record will stand against the right honourable member's miserable performance and those with whom he is associated, a record that will stand examination at any time. I repeat: I answered honestly in this Parliament, as I always do, that I had contacted two people. I make no apology for that at all. I would do it again. A situation exists now, as I understand it, where there is no contract between the people I contacted and Mr Young. If such a contract does emerge I have absolutely no concern, no problem, about the names being exposed publicly, none at all. It is proper, there being discussions between the two gentlemen and Mr Young, that they should conduct them and if they wish to disclose that fact that they do so. I will put no bar at all, and I will attempt to use no influence at all--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all very well Opposition members laughing before they have heard the end of the sentence; it is an indication of their stupidity. They should exercise a little good sense and let me finish the sentence. I will attempt to exercise no influence at all to prevent them from disclosing those facts.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, concerns the first home buyers scheme. I draw the Minister's attention to the article in the Australian newspaper yesterday regarding the Government's first home owners scheme. The report mentions the likelihood of payments exceeding the Budget estimate this year. In my own electorate over $10m has been paid out to first home buyers, which is very good. Can the Minister outline the current situation with regard to the take-up of the first home owners scheme? Can he indicate the impact of the growth in housing starts that has occurred with the decline in interest rates in recent months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can well understand why so many people are rushing to live in the electorate of the honourable member for Burke. The real situation with the first home owners scheme, as I have been advised by my Department, is that there is no basis for that small article in the Australian yesterday. The 1987-88 expenditure to the end of February was approximately $140m, which is slightly below the Budget estimate at this time. Any extra demand which may come into the scheme for the rest of the year will certainly be accommodated by the improved accountability processes we have brought in.

ANSWER.PARA: The first home owners scheme is one of the most popular and effective programs introduced by any government in Australia's history. Last week, I point out to the House, $1 billion had been handed out to first home owners since October 1983. The billionth dollar was handed over to a family from Mount Druitt in the western suburbs of Sydney. That family, I think, was from the electorate of the honourable member for Chifley. That is a family on below average weekly earnings with two children, and is one of 67,000 households in New South Wales that have benefited to the tune of a total of $250m. The housing future of the people of New South Wales looks pretty rosy when we combine that with the effect of the New South Wales Labor Government's promise to abolish stamp duty after the next election. That success in New South Wales is indicative of the situation right around Australia.

As I said, $1 billion has been expended on the first home owners scheme and that covers 270,000 Australian households. When we combine that first home owners scheme with other forms of housing assistance provided through the Commonwealth and the States, more than 500,000 households, or 1.4 million individual Australians, have been assisted into housing in the period of this Labor Government. To put it simply, roughly the entire population of South Australia or of a city the size of Perth has been assisted into housing.

The Prime Minister the other day in Port Adelaide said that the first home owners scheme was one of the greatest achievements of this Government. That is certainly the case. It shows the priorities of this Government despite the harsh world conditions and despite the financial restrictions that have been placed on the Government in having to get this economy back on the tracks and moving forward. We have proved in the most tangible and concrete way our priorities for assistance to first home buyers. I highlight also that we are not content with that; we are about to initiate a major campaign to increase public awareness. Two weeks ago I launched a first home owners scheme leaflet in 18 languages so that people from non-English speaking backgrounds could also have maximum accessibility to the scheme. If we compare that to the record of the Opposition on housing, when we came in there were 105,000 starts; this year there will be probably about 140,000 new starts, with a few more next year. That is the reality of it.
To make a final point about the first home owners scheme let me read from a letter I received in my office yesterday. The letter said:

I would like to take this opportunity to express my sincere thanks for your assistance. I am a supporting mother and although I work, getting the deposit together seemed like an impossible task. Thanks to the help of your scheme I was able to use the $3,000 for the deposit on an old home. The continuing allowance has covered the rates each year. Your department has given myself and my children a chance we would not have otherwise had. So sincerely thank you.
That thanks, I am sure, comes from 270,000 other households who have been helped by the first home owners scheme.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR M. J. YOUNG: EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. I give him a further opportunity to confirm that one of the people he contacted with a view to obtaining a job for Mick Young was a senior officer of the Westfield-Channel 10 group, as leaked by his office last night. Is the Prime Minister aware that senior management of Channel 10 is on the record as wanting the Government to increase the television reach rule from 60 per cent to either 75 per cent or 100 per cent in order to create a national television network? How can the Prime Minister say, as he did in this House yesterday, that he saw no conflict of interest between seeking a favour from Channel 10 by employing Mick Young and that organisation's national television aspirations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will appreciate, from the answer I have already given to the question from the Leader of the National Party of Australia, that I do not intend to say to whom I spoke. If they wish to disclose it I have no concern about that being done, none at all. Having said that, let me address myself to the part of the question that I can respond to without in any sense being in conflict with what I have said.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware, as is the honourable gentleman, that within the television industry generally there is a view, I think not confined to Channel 10, that the 60 per cent rule is not the most appropriate. The honourable gentleman will be aware that in the first place the Government proposed a higher figure, but due to the total inability of the Opposition to begin to formulate anything resembling a policy in this area, and due to the total conflict of positions on the other side of this chamber and of the other House, a 60 per cent figure was finalised.

It is no secret that within the television industry generally, and I understand this includes Channel 10 and its proprietorship, there is an attitude that that 60 per cent is not a sufficiently high figure. But that comes as no surprise. Indeed, I repeat what I have said already: the Government, in considering this earlier, had talked about a higher figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns the issues of social justice. What has been the effect of the family allowance supplement on the living standards of families earning below average weekly earnings (AWE)? How does this compare with their experience under the Fraser Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is about the living standards of low income people during a time of considerable wage restraint. Indeed, if the Opposition had been in government in the period we have been in office, that wage restraint, or at least the wage restraint argued for at hearings of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, would be very much greater than it has been. Nevertheless, the Government has had a policy to restrain wages.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time the Government has recognised that those people within the work force who are more disadvantaged ought to be protected. Indeed, at the beginning of the Government's term, when an accord was negotiated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, there was an understanding that the Government would look not only at real incomes in terms of wages but also at real incomes in relation to taxation, and at what could be done with what was called at the time the social wage.

Let me come to the facts. At present some 11 per cent of all full time wage and salary earners are on 50 per cent or less of average weekly earnings. A person supporting a spouse and three children and on 50 per cent of average weekly earnings experienced a 1.5 per cent average annual increase in disposable income under the Fraser-Howard Government. As a result of the family allowance supplement, the real disposable income of that family has increased on average by 3.6 per cent each year under this Government. That family disposable income on present values increased from $260 per week in March 1983 to $307 per week in December 1987.

Forty-four per cent of wage and salary earners are on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings or less. A family with three children and on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings under the Fraser-Howard Government had a stagnant disposable income, which increased by only 0.3 of one per cent. Under this Government the family income at present values has increased from $343 to $378 per week, a real increase of just over 10 per cent.

The success of the family allowance supplement is even more remarkable given the decline in the terms of trade. At a time when this Government has had to deal with an inherited deficit, at a time when it has had to deal with the massive problems of the current account and the position Australia is in and therefore the living standards of low income wage earners, the Government has in fact provided real increases for those people, and I am talking here about the 40 per cent of people in the work force whose income is either at or below 75 per cent of average weekly earnings.

For people in electorates such as mine and in the western suburbs of Sydney, the family allowance supplement scheme is a revolutionary and highly significant reform. I think one of the problems in this Parliament is that too many people on the other side of the House have very little feeling when debating wage cuts; they argued for no wage increase in 19 out of 20 cases. When they put that view they forget about the average factory worker in an electorate such as mine, where a worker in a textile factory, for example, earns between $300 and $340 a week. I am not sure how many members of this Parliament could live on that income. The adult base rate for a worker at one major footwear producer is now between $260 and $290 a week, with overtime averaging $50 a week. Almost all of these workers who support a spouse and children will be eligible for a payment under the family allowance supplement.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I know members of the Opposition do not like the facts, but they are going to cop some. These families, renting privately and with three children and a spouse relying on one breadwinner in the footwear industry, could therefore be better off by around $61 to $64 a week as a direct result of the family allowance supplement, or more if their children are in the 13 to 15 age group.

ANSWER.PARA: What this Government has been arguing about in terms of economic policy is directing all of our energies and efforts to creating the wealth that will provide the basis for long term higher living standards. But despite the restraint that necessarily has had to be imposed, we have been delivering the most significant real increases to low income working families in the post-war period.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PECUNIARY INTERESTS OF MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it not a fact that the Government has justified its requirement for declarations of the pecuniary interests of members of parliament on the grounds that a public, as distinct from a private, judgment should be made as to whether or not conflicts of interest exist between private interests and public duties? Is it not a fact that the Prime Minister, by refusing to disclose the facts and circumstances regarding his job hunting exercise for his former colleague, refuses to apply to his conduct on this occasion, regarding a potential conflict of interest, the same standards as are required of all members of parliament?

—The reasons for this Government's decision in regard to the statements of pecuniary interests of Ministers and members of parliament are quite clear, stand in their own right and will be adhered to. In regard to the second part of the honourable gentleman's question, the answer is no.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PROPOSED SENATE SELECT COMMITTEE INTO AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Could he explain to the House whether he supports the proposed establishment of a Senate select committee into agricultural and veterinary chemicals?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Calare for his question, and I understand any concern he may have, given statements made about him by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia. I spoke with the Deputy Leader last night and I have since had a chance to review the proposal, and I take this opportunity to set the situation out very clearly.

ANSWER.PARA: I have looked at the correspondence between my colleague the honourable member for Calare and the President of the National Farmers Federation, in which he says that the Opposition supports such an inquiry-the inquiry being the one that the honourable member has referred to. Last week the Deputy Leader of the National Party issued a Press release claiming that the Opposition had never supported such an inquiry, that is, the proposed Senate inquiry into agricultural and veterinary chemical usage. The Opposition is making some attempt to divorce itself from farmer organisation complaints about the proposed inquiry. In doing so, I must say, having had a chance to look at the Press release and the letter, the Deputy Leader of the National Party has maligned the honourable member for Calare in his capacity as chairperson of the Caucus primary industries and energy committee. In the Senate on 15 December 1987 Liberal Senator Austin Lewis gave notice of a motion calling for a select committee into agricultural chemicals to look at:

. . . regulation by governments of the sale and use of agricultural chemicals in the beef industry, the use of such chemicals by governmental instrumentalities and questions of compensation and assistance for growers.

This motion was designed clearly to find guilty parties connected with the beef residue problems. The proposal was backward looking and because it would achieve nothing for the beef industry the Government decided to support an alternative inquiry sponsored by the Australian Democrats who were determined to have some form of inquiry. The final details of this inquiry have not been set out yet and I will be speaking with the Democrats in the near future to do that, but at least any inquiry will look towards the future of chemical usage in this country. I make the point that at no stage did the Government initiate such an inquiry. In the simplest of terms, the Democrats proposal was the best option and the Government had little alternative but to support it. This was all initiated by the Liberals in the Senate.

I would like to place on record my appreciation of the work done by the beef industry and all the State governments and people concerned with it to correct the residue problem. If farm organisations have any concerns about the proposed inquiry, they should address them to the people who started it, Opposition members, and particularly the Deputy Leader of the National Party, who does not seem to know what went on in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask him why he apparently misled the media and the Australian public when he said on Monday that he knew nothing about the Qantas Airways Ltd job and had nothing to do with it, yet in Question Time yesterday he told Parliament that he was informed at about the end of February by Mr Young that consultations had taken place between Qantas management and himself.

—The answer is so obvious that I thought it would not have escaped my friend who asked this question. I have made it clear that I had nothing to do with Mr Young's consultations with Qantas Airways Ltd. I knew nothing about them occurring until he told me. As a matter of obvious logic, when he told me I knew about them.

—I address my question to the Minister for Employment and Education Services. Can the Minister inform the House of the current situation with unemployment in Australia, especially the Government's performance with respect to young Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. He and other New South Wales members of this Parliament, particularly on this side of the House, should be able to take particular pride from the February unemployment figures released just a few days ago which showed such an excellent performance by the Unsworth Government in this quite critical area. It is interesting to see the way New South Wales has led the country in this area. It is important to note that unemployment in New South Wales last month dropped to 7.1 per cent, which was down from almost 9 per cent 12 months before. I do not think anyone could deny that that is an excellent result. In fact New South Wales has led the country with a 5.4 per cent increase in the number of jobs created during the past 12 months. That is an excellent result in anybody's judgment. It compares particularly well if one looks at the quite pedestrian performance at the other end of the country by the Tasmanian Liberal Government, which has been running the highest unemployment policy in the nation.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no doubt that, if a fiscally irresponsible Greiner government were to be elected on Saturday, the results for this nation would be absolutely disastrous. Fortunately, that is not about to happen. There is no reason why the people of New South Wales should believe any of the outlandish promises made by Mr Greiner, nor should they move away from the excellent record in this area of the Unsworth Government which will continue to be the Government after Saturday.

To get back to the honourable member's question, I want to refer to the quite significant achievements of the Hawke Government which now can boast the lowest unemployment rate in this nation for almost six years. We have seen, I think it is fair to say, the most far-reaching reconstruction of the Australian economy since the post-war period. Like Chifley, this Prime Minister has provided the sort of visionary leadership that has led to the creation of one million jobs in this nation during the past five years. That compares very favourably with the last year of the Fraser-Howard regime when 186,000 jobs were wiped off in this nation-lost. This Government has created, on average, 200,000 jobs in every year of our term on the treasury benches. That is an incredible record by anyone's judgment, whether one looks overseas at any of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries or anywhere else in our region. This Government's performance in this area stands unsurpassed.

Honourable members on the other side ought to look at this nation's economic management under this Government and take a real lesson from it because there is no doubt that we have achieved this in spite of a very dramatic and difficult turnaround in the terms of trade, difficulties that have been created as a result of the stock market crisis last October and, of course, notwithstanding the constant carping and criticism that has come from the other side. It is interesting to review the comments made by the shadow Minister, who claimed in his woolly mutterings over the January figures that the unemployment figure was stuck, as he put in, at 7.4 per cent. That has been proved quite wrong and I can confidently tell the House that we predict that the Budget time forecast that unemployment would be around 8.25 per cent has been exceeded. I am confident that the figure at the end of the financial year will come in well below 8 per cent, a very good result for this Government and the nation. Of course, all of our achievements would be put in jeopardy in the unlikely event that Greiner and the New South Wales Liberals were elected on Saturday.

I turn to the second part of the honourable member's question where he sought information on the Government's good record on youth affairs and youth unemployment. Last month's Australian Bureau of Statistics figures confirm the trend in declining numbers of teenagers without jobs. The number of teenagers looking for full time work as a proportion of the total teenage population dropped to a healthy 7.3 per cent in February.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an abuse of Question Time.

—Honourable members on the other side do not like hearing this because when they went out of government the figure was well over 12 per cent and we have brought it down to 7.3 per cent in five years-a very creditable effort on the part of this Government. We have encouraged kids to prepare themselves for the work force. We have not simply labelled them as dole bludgers, we have not simply taken the negative attitudes that members opposite have taken. We have ensured that school retention rates have gone up from the quite pathetic 36 per cent under the former coalition Government to well over 50 per cent now. We have ensured that the entire youth area has been given a high priority. On this particular issue Opposition members should hang their heads in shame.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that at the time the Prime Minister contacted certain companies regarding employment for Mr Young it was his intention that Mr Young remain Federal President of the Australian Labor Party?

—I could have no intention because whether Mr Young remained the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party was a matter for the decision of Mr Young. At the time, that was his position. Subsequently, for reasons which he has announced and which I respect, he decided not to continue in that position.
—I direct my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Will the Minister inform the House of the result of the tender process for the redevelopment of the Australian Embassy in Tokyo?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contract for our Tokyo embassy redevelopment, including the sale of 6,150 square metres of land surplus to requirements, together with 16 adjacent staff apartments, has been awarded to the MITA consortium, which will pay 57.573 billion yen, approximately $A640m at an exchange rate of 90 yen to the Australian dollar. However, the final amount that Australia will receive will depend upon the exchange rate at the time the contracts are finalised in a few weeks time. So I am pleased to report that I think we have the maximum possible return to Australia in an extremely difficult Tokyo property market.

ANSWER.PARA: The contract includes the provision of a new four-storey chancery building with basement car parking, 43 new staff apartments, a new residence for the ambassador, and associated recreation facilities for the staff to be built on the remaining 12,000 square metres of land. In addition, the successful tenderer has agreed to provide a new building as a temporary chancery for the estimated two-year construction period, together with temporary residential accommodation for the ambassador and his deputy.

A matter of importance for our relationship with Japan is that the consortium has agreed also to preserve and enhance the traditional Japanese gardens, including the historic well and other environmental features. Further benefits include the undertaking by Itoh, a major member of the MITA consortium, that it will import an additional 1.5 million tonnes of coal from New South Wales during the next two years. This additional tonnage is over and above its normal purchase of 1.6 million to 1.8 million tonnes of coal from New South Wales each year.

I am also pleased to note the involvement in the MITA consortium of the Australian firm of Lustig and Moar, which, I understand, has an equity holding in the development and is also in a position to ensure maximum use of Australian materials in the total project. In summary, I feel very strongly that the rationalisation of our property holdings in Tokyo has resulted in a most satisfactory outcome, and that when the embassy is built, Australia will have an embassy building in Japan that properly reflects the importance of the relationships between our two nations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the guidelines issued by the Government after the Combe-Ivanov affair. I quote those guidelines:

QUESTION.PARA: Ministers should seek to avoid granting special privileges, advantage, or access to any lobbyist by virtue of that lobbyist's particular background, for example, as a former parliamentary representative or senior office holder or employee of a political party.
Given that Mr Young appears to satisfy all three criteria, does the Prime Minister now agree that his job-seeking efforts on Mr Young's behalf constitute a breach of his own Government's guidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I do not agree. First of all, I do not accept the description that the Leader of the Opposition has given to my actions in this matter. But putting that aside, my answer is that I do not accept they are in breach. Let me make it quite clear that I do not accept the proposition that my action in contacting the two businessmen on behalf of Mr Young amounted to a breach of the Government's guidelines for Ministers regarding their dealings with lobbyists. In no way is that the case. Certainly those who have written to that effect in the Press are manifestly wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: In approaching the two businessmen concerned to facilitate possible employment for Mr Young, it was by way of general testimonial of Mr Young's undoubted abilities. I doubt whether there is anyone in this House who would question his abilities. What work would be available for him would be entirely up to the companies concerned. The obvious point that I hope would not escape even the Opposition is that, to the extent that Mr Young may subsequently engage in lobbying activities, the guidelines will be scrupulously followed and he will not be given any specific privilege, advantage or access by virtue of his background as a former Minister.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to my colleague and friend the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Now that the Minister has completed his round of consultations with Aboriginal groups, will he indicate whether and when he proposes to proceed with the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Caucus committee chairman for his question. I shall be discussing this proposal with him in more detail later today and in the future. On 10 December I announced to the House a proposal to establish a new commission. I announced also that I would be visiting communities throughout Australia. Some comments have been made by a number of people concerning the success of those consultations. Therefore, I take this opportunity to bring to the attention of the House the detail of those consultations.

ANSWER.PARA: A thousand separate Aboriginal communities and organisations were contacted in terms of delivering videos, explanatory notes and material to them. During the lead-up to my visits, 453 preliminary meetings were conducted in 415 locations, which enabled Aboriginal people to consult among themselves on the proposals before my arrival. Between 23 January and 10 March, in the company of Mr Charles Perkins, I attended some 46 meetings throughout Australia involving an estimated 6,000 Aboriginal people representing more than 1,200 community groups and organisations. During that time we travelled about 50,000 kilometres.

I take the opportunity to draw to the attention of the House these details because there has been a number of Press releases issued by certain people-and unfortunately by Opposition members-who have suggested that these consultations were not serious and were in fact not aimed at achieving an agreed position between myself and the Government, and the Aboriginal community. I put that suggestion to rest. I think the shadow Minister would do well to look back over his Press releases of the past couple of weeks. He will be proven, like a lot of other people, to be inaccurate in the assertions he has made. Other people who have been responsible for very misleading and distorting Press releases, I will deal with at a more appropriate time. During the debate there will be ample opportunity to put to rest a lot of the lies and misrepresentations that have been made.

During my visits to these various communities, we received overwhelming support for the concept in principle. In terms of the word `principle', communities have asked many questions and sought clarification on a number of issues. They have made suggestions also about the way in which we could modify the proposal. It is our intention now to enter into a second stage of consultation, which will be concluded over the next three or four weeks. That will allow the community to come to grips with proposals being put forward by other organisations around Australia. The questions that seek information will be answered. I am confident that at the end of these consultations we will have overwhelming support for and total commitment to this proposal, which seeks to advance the lot of Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. In view of the fact that the Government is considering a casino licence in Canberra and that strict control laws would be required, is it a fact that the Casino Control Committee has held an investigation and issued a violation report following a game of blackjack played in the early hours of the morning at the Perth casino? Was the inquiry about a gambler who requested that the casino change the rules of the game, and was the Prime Minister that gambler?
—The answer is: I do not know.
—On a point of order, Madam Speaker: will the Prime Minister provide the House with an answer today?

—That is a supplementary question. The honourable member was not called for a supplementary question. I suggest to the honourable member that, if he wants to take a point of order, he should do so and not ask a supplementary question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. As it has been claimed recently that age pensioners have seen little improvement in their rates, could the Minister outline government initiatives in relation to older people in the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of assertions have been made that during this Government's term in office there has not been a real maintenance of the living standards of aged people. I say quite to the contrary that this Government has given very high priority indeed to ensuring that not only are the living standards of aged people maintained, but that as far as possible within the severe constraints that exist there is some improvement in those living standards. Despite a number of tight Budgets and significant cuts in social security, pensions have been maintained and indexed twice yearly and are now close to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. That has been the case notwithstanding a cost of $1 billion each year in maintaining the indexation of pensions according to the consumer price index (CPI). Pension payments have increased by 8.3 per cent in real terms during the life of this Government. Maximum rent assistance has increased by 50 per cent from $10 to $15 a week, and the separate income test for rent assistance has been abolished, allowing thousands more pensioners to qualify for this form of assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: The income limit for the pensioner health benefit card is also raised according to CPI rises. From January this year pensioners whose income rises above the limits by no more than 25 per cent can keep their pensioner health benefit card for three months. The carer's pension introduced by this Government means that older people who need constant attention can remain in the comfort of their own homes and familiar surroundings amidst the security of supportive friends and relatives. The Government, aware of the danger of poverty traps which reduce incentives to self-sufficiency-and a degree of self-sufficiency is important for many aged people in the community as it is for others-has increased the amount that pensioners may earn before their pension is affected. From July last year single pensioners have been able to earn $40 a week up from $30 a week and married pensioners $70 a week while still receiving their full pension entitlement.

It is relevant to that reform in terms of the eased income tests in relation to the age pension that the Government also introduced a very innovative earnings credit scheme to allow pensioners to earn extra income without losing any of their entitlement. The scheme works by allowing pensioners on the maximum rate to accumulate credit for the difference between the allowable extra income and the amount actually received. For example, if a single age pensioner receives income from interest payments of $15 a week, he or she has an earnings credit of $25 a week. This can be accumulated to a maximum of $1,000. So if the pensioner has built up a credit of, say, $700 he or she can take a casual job for three weeks at $200 a week and still receive the full pension and fringe benefit entitlements.

If one takes the social security record of this Government in regard to aged people and puts it together with programs such as the home and community care program, with the co-operation between this Government in easing fringe benefit limits and States such as New South Wales, which have provided the full range of fringe benefits to aged people, one sees that this has been a period in which, despite all the difficulties, substantial attention indeed has been given to the care of the aged.

While the Government has that record, a record of which it can be proud, in respect of the aged, we do not simply remain there. We have had in train a social security review, arguably the most important review of social security in the postwar period. As part of that review we are looking at the income security arrangements for aged people, and towards the middle part of this year Professor Cass will release her report which will be relevant to the development of a comprehensive retirement income policy.

We have had this lot on the other side of the House now for more than five years. Whereas this Government during its period of office has systematically sought to review areas of policy with a view to making immediate changes that touch on living standards, introducing reforms such as the family allowance supplement, we have also been looking towards the development of future policy. Professor Cass's work on social security review will go down as one of the most important contributions to social policy in the history of this country. It is extremely important and very relevant. Unlike the report of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty of the late 1960s and early 1970s, the Government is not shelving, as the Fraser Government did, a report, putting it away and doing nothing about it. This Government in its terms of office while receiving the reports has been systematically seeking to ensure that they are implemented to achieve improvements in living standards for low income people in the short term, but to build the basis of a much better social security system in the long term.

DEBATE.TITLE: REPORT ON IRON AND STEEL INDUSTRY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Speaker, the primary objective of the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Australian Iron and Steel Industry was to examine whether Commonwealth expenditure on the steel industry plan has been spent effectively and efficiently, as measured in terms of overall plan performance, adherence to commitments, the role of the Steel Industry Authority (SIA), industry improvement and the future of the industry beyond 1988. The report concludes that the steel industry plan has made a positive contribution to the recovery of the steel industry, in particular by underpinning the industry's decision to embark on a major capital investment program. The report also makes a number of recommendations which focus on improving specific problem areas relating to plan administration and development of the steel industry more generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members may be aware that the Steel Industry Authority is presently conducting a review of the steel industry plan, to be completed by 30 June this year, which will examine the extent to which the plan has achieved its objectives and what, if any, special arrangements are required for the steel industry after the plan's scheduled expiry on 31 December this year. As part of the review the SIA will be addressing those issues identified by the parliamentary Committee as impacting on the steel industry plan. It would not be appropriate, therefore, to respond at this stage to the specific findings and recommendations of the parliamentary Committee's report. The report will provide a valuable and timely contribution to this review process. At the completion of the review I will respond to the specific findings and recommendations of the parliamentary Committee's report. I commend the Committee on the preparation of an excellent report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The response given by the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) to what might be loosely described as the Martin benefit report is wholly inadequate, and therefore the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) ought to be taking a special interest in it. The Minister's statement effectively ignores the urgency of the recommendations within the report. Instead, the Government is choosing to sit on its hands until after a report is received some time after 30 June from another government instrumentality, the Steel Industry Authority. The report we are discussing today was finalised in November last year, so one can imagine the time lag that will follow from the 30 June report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report recommends the immediate implementation of an effective anti-dumping mechanism and suggests ways of attracting greater union commitment to the steel plan. It points out that while the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and the Government have adhered to their commitments the unions are no longer meeting theirs. The unions have failed to adhere to agreed dispute settling procedures. As a matter of fact, industrial disputation has reached pre-plan levels at Port Kembla. The report-this is a monument to the Government-concludes:
Much progress must also still be made by unions regarding productivity, further increases being imperative if Australia is to attain long-term industrial competitiveness.

That is in the Government's report, and the Government is doing nothing about it. The Minister's response has also failed to address the pressing need for an effective fast track anti-dumping mechanism, particularly if the Australian dollar rises in value against the Japanese and American currencies. These issues need to be addressed now and not after the June report-in other words, in another six months time. It matters little whether or not the Government likes the recommendations; they must be put in place in order to assist recovery in the steel industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment and Education Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present for the information of honourable members the report Local Employment Initiatives: A Strategic Approach. I seek leave to make a statement on the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to draw the attention of the House to the report prepared by the National Advisory Group on Local Employment Initiatives (NAGLEI) on a new locally based approach to unemployment. NAGLEI was set up in June 1985 by the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). The group was asked to provide advice on the potential and relevance of local employment initiatives (LEIs) to create permanent employment opportunities in Australia, having regard to the Government's other social and economic objectives, including the need for continued expenditure restraint.

SPEECH.PARA: NAGLEI was established in direct response to the widespread concern over the effects of unemployment, together with the experience of other countries in tackling this problem at a local community level. Impetus for the task also came through Australia's involvement in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development cooperative action program on local initiatives for employment creation. The group was chaired by a senior officer from the Department of Employment, Education and Training and comprised: State and local government representatives, peak union and employer representation, and a number of individuals with specialist expertise in the field. The report was released in December 1987, accompanied by a comprehensive series of research papers.

The advisory group found that during the past four years local and regional groups had been active in creating local employment opportunities and in attempting to `clawback' jobs in the wake of major industrial rationalisations and downturns in the rural sector. These groups act as intermediaries, facilitating the development of new local enterprises. Some of these groups have arisen directly as a result of external assistance such as in the steel industries assistance scheme. Others have been motivated by a concern to do something positive about the unemployment affecting their communities and have drawn financial support from a range of sources.

Some State governments have also established programs to develop this type of activity. Nationally, more than 60 of these intermediary type organisations, having the potential to develop further in the employment area, have been identified in the report. This figure has undoubtedly grown since the survey was undertaken. The experience of these organisations is that there is a severe lack of appropriate finance, technical expertise and organisational support available to assist new enterprises to establish themselves in the marketplace.

The national advisory group believes that there are potential benefits which could accrue if a strategic approach is taken to resourcing and facilitating this activity. Additionally, the Group concluded that the greatest potential lay in directing support towards those enterprises which operated under both the economic objective of competing in the open marketplace and making a profit, and the social objective of maintaining long term, viable jobs.

The thrust of the report is to put in place a national strategy of support to LEIs which builds on existing activities and promote the involvement of communities in generating employment initiatives which relate best to their local situations, while at the same time overcoming the major impediments to small enterprise development, namely, inadequate training and support, and restricted access to establishment capital.

The strategy is two pronged. Firstly, it recommends establishing a network of up to 20 intermediary organisations in selected regions to stimulate and facilitate local employment initiatives in those areas. The report recommends that these organisations should include representatives of government, business groups, unions and education institutions and operate with the support of a National Local Employment Initiative Corporation to provide training, policy and expert advice. Secondly, it recommends the establishment of a specific financing body-the Local Initiatives Finance Trust-which would provide far greater access to finance for fledgling enterprises. It is proposed that the finance body attract private investment from the marketplace by issuing government-backed, indexed bonds which would provide funds for tailored loan packages requiring repayment in a manner consistent with the cash flow demands of the particular new enterprises. It would also provide training and technical assistance in the financial area.

The report emphasises that the financing body should not offer grants or subsidised loans and the loans it provides would not be handouts or cheap money. The report is currently the subject of a comprehensive Australia-wide consultation process involving Commonwealth departments, State governments, local governments, employer and employee organisations, community organisations and other peak groups. The national program of seminars will provide valuable feedback to enable the Government to formulate its response to the report later in 1988 when the consultation process is completed. I strongly commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This is the first opportunity that I have had in this place since the report of the National Advisory Group on Local Employment Initiatives was released in December last year, firstly, to welcome it and to congratulate the national advisory group on its work. In my view and in the view of the Opposition it is an excellent report which is deserving of very serious consideration. Secondly, I welcome the fact that the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) has made a statement. The fact that the House has given me leave to speak gives me an opportunity, albeit brief, to say something about this important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: This report entitled Local Employment Initiatives: A Strategic Approach is presented against the changing trends and the changing background of job creation not only in Australia but in the Western world. It is recognised by the Minister that the greatest amount of job creation in our country is coming now and will certainly come in the future from small business and at the local level. That is certainly true in the private sector. We should not be surprised to find the same trend lines in the public or what I might call the community sector. Members of this House will have anecdotal examples, perhaps drawn from their own electorates, of people who are taking their destiny into their own hands; people who are voluntarily coming together to make work, to create jobs and to find jobs. Many of these local initiatives are supported by State governments, local governments, service clubs, the community youth support scheme or other organisations of a more formal nature that are already established in the community.

We can see a parallel success in job placement. In the community sector there are schemes such as Bridging the Gap, Co-scope or DOME, organisations which are very successful at a local community level involving volunteer commitment in filling some of the gaps left by the Commonwealth Employment Service-some would argue that they are doing a better job than the CES, although I recognise that in this short contribution that subject should be spoken about on another day-and finding jobs and placing people in the work force in cases where the Government schemes have been unsuccessful.

This report recognises the importance of local employment initiatives. It recognises that they will have an even bigger role to play in the future in creating jobs and finding work for our unemployed fellow Australians. It importantly identifies the problems being experienced by local employment initiatives. There are problems relating to the fact that they do not have much money or expertise, even though there is a lot of enthusiasm and will, and they often battle for support to buttress their activities. There are 52 recommendations contained in this report as to how local employment initiatives might be assisted in the context of an overall national strategic approach.

I recognise that the Government has not made any decisions and that there is to be widespread national consultation. But I want to bring to bear the old adage, `Beware the person who says, ``I am from the Government and I am here to help'' '. The message I want to convey to the Minister from the Opposition ranks is that the success of local employment initiatives now and in the future relates to their individuality, uniqueness and grassroots local nature. The Government, in its consideration of this report, must actively guard against the dead hand of centralised bureaucratic control and rigidity as it may impact upon the activities of these local employment initiatives.

I am optimistic that the Government is well placed to make the right decisions in the next few months. The Minister has cited the fact that the advisory group concluded that the greatest potential lay in directing support towards those enterprises which operated under the economic objective of competing in the open marketplace and making a profit and the social objective of maintaining long term, viable jobs. The report emphasised-again this was recognised by the Minister-that the financing body, the Local Initiatives Finance Trust, should not offer grants or subsidise loans. The loans it provides should not be handouts or cheap money.

In recognition of the convention that operates in this place, I do not have time to go through each of the 52 recommendations. I hope that there will be a more fulsome debate when the Minister brings down his final consideration of this report. I underscore the fact that the advisory group seems to be aware of the nature of the current success of these employment initiative programs and of the dangers inherent in any possible move by government or bureaucracy to control, centralise or bring to bear a rigidity which currently does not exist in terms of these grassroots local organisations. There will be widespread consultation in respect of this report. We await the Government's further decisions with interest. The Minister and the Government can look forward to a constructive Opposition response from us for as long as the Party opposite remains in government. I foreshadow that when we are in government after the next election we will look very positively at this report with a view to acting upon it.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Prime Minister to maintain the integrity of his own guidelines regarding public duty and conflict of interest.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Question Time today gave a classic demonstration, not of the working out of the Westminster principles relating to prime ministerial duty, but of how he is failing the very guidelines and principles he so resolutely propounded only four or five years ago. I start my remarks by reminding the House of something the Prime Minister said in this very place on 11 May 1983 when he was speaking to the Hope Commission report. I hope that every member of the Parliament ponders these words because within them is writ very large the dilemma in which the Prime Minister now so clearly finds himself as the knives within his own Party, in the person of his Treasurer (Mr Keating), are already being sharpened. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers' doors should be and be seen to be open without the need for leverage by a party insider and it was not appropriate that a former party official, by virtue of that status, have special advantages or access to government denied to others.

If ever there were words that utterly condemned everything that the Prime Minister has done in relation to the grubby Young affair, those words perfectly demolish and indict the behaviour of the Prime Minister. If ever there was a person who was a party insider, it is the former member for Port Adelaide. If ever a person was given privileged access, it was the former member for Port Adelaide. Yet, let alone the Prime Minister having any kind of concern or remorse about what he has done, he defiantly, arrogantly, contemptuously and improperly said in the Parliament today that if he had his opportunity he would do it all again. In other words, he would again and again use the coercive power of his great office.

It is a coercive power. Let nobody be in any doubt that the Prime Minister of this country holds enormous power. He knows that, but what he does not know is that it carries enormous duties and responsibilities. One of the great duties and responsibilities that it carries is that at all times, without exception, the Prime Minister of this country must put duty above mateship. He must, on all occasions, do that and he must wield and exercise this great coercive power in a beneficial fashion. If the Prime Minister said in the Parliament in a beneficial fashion that he would again be on the phone to people in the business community trying to organise jobs for unemployed young people in the western suburbs of Sydney he would have the applause of the people on this side of the House. But instead, what he threatens is to get on the phone. Is he going to get on the phone to get a job for Barrie Unsworth next Monday? Is he going to get on the phone to get a job for any other Minister? What is he going to line up for the Deputy Prime Minister, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen), if the Prime Minister still holds his own position when the Deputy Prime Minister retires at the end of this year?

This Prime Minister appears to be monumentally incapable of understanding that what lies at the heart of the criticism that he now receives from the Opposition and from the media almost universally around Australia is that he has abused the privileges and the powers of the great office that he holds. That is what he should be condemned for. He simply cannot understand that there is any remote possibility of a conflict of interest. Does he seriously imagine that any business executive in Australia receiving a phone call from a Prime Minister would ignore it? He would have us believe that it was in the nature of a testimonial. What a lot of absolute rot! Mick Young has been one of the most public figures in Australia over the last five years. Are we seriously to accept from the Prime Minister that the only reason he rang a couple of people was to tell them a bit about Mick because they might not have known what Mick was really like? What absolute nonsense!

The Prime Minister rang those people to heavy them to give Mick a job. It was as simple of that. He did not care about the consequences to his position. He did not care that at some time in the future one or other of those companies may want the Government to make a decision of particular benefit to it. Let me make it clear that I make no attack upon the chief executives of those companies. They are not in the dock. It is the Prime Minister who is in the dock on this issue. They have done nothing wrong. They have reacted, I imagine, in the normal way. People do not get a telephone call from a Prime Minister every day. They normally sit up and take notice of that. They normally say, `Maybe I should do something to oblige him'. Does the Prime Minister not understand that that can create a potential conflict of interest? Was that not what he had in mind when he wrote those post-Combe-Ivanov guidelines, when he said that there should be the avoidance of any conferment of privilege? Did the Government not have that sort of thing in mind? Of course it did.

When the Prime Minister shouted from the rooftops to the former Federal Secretary of his own Party, at a time when he was applying higher standards, that not only should right be done but that also it should appear to be done, he was stating a very sound principle. But why is it that now, in 1988, he will not abide by it? Why is he defending the conferring of a special advantage or access to government denied to others? Does he seriously believe that everybody who wants a job with the companies that he approached has the same privilege and access Mick Young received on this occasion? Does he really imagine that his Government may not be potentially compromised and that, if at some time in the future one of these companies wants the Government to do something to help it, quite legitimately, it will not compromise his Government and it will not compromise him? Or is he so insensitive to the principles that govern prime ministerial conduct? Apparently he is.

Today, at the end of Question Time, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), the shadow Attorney-General, sought to have tabled in the Parliament a document that had come into the hands of the Opposition from the Casino Control Committee of Western Australia. The document is dated 12 December 1986 and sends a copy of a violation report issued to the chief executive officer on 17 November 1986. It reads as follows:
The decision to allow the Prime Minister to play one box at a blackjack table is a clear contravention of the approved rules of the game.
The Treasurer breaches the tax rules and the Prime Minister, apparently, breaches the gaming rules. Of course he did not want that put into Hansard. The document goes on to say:
Rule 4.8 of the Rules of Blackjack states: `If there is only one player at the table, that player shall wager in at least two boxes'.
A casino licensee shall ensure that any authorised game conducted in the licensed casino is conducted in accordance with the approved rules of that game.
A casino licensee or a casino key employee or casino employee who contravenes or fails to comply with, a provision of this Act or any direction or notice commits an offence.
It is of particular concern to the Committee that [there was a refusal] to rectify an acknowledged breach of the rules when it was brought to his attention by an on-duty Government Casino Inspector.

The Committee has determined not to institute proceedings for a breach of the Casino Control Act on this occasion. However, it wishes to advise that any future breaches may not be viewed as leniently.

Whilst I do not claim any great proficiency in these matters, I understand that wanting to play only one box means that one wants to increase the odds. It is perhaps not surprising that the Prime Minister, this great sportsman, should want to increase his odds, particularly at present. So we await with some interest the response of the Prime Minister to that particular exercise which related to events on 16 November 1986. Apparently it is all right-of no great account-that the Treasurer does not put his tax return in on time. Perhaps the answer to this will be that it is of no great account that the rules of the game have been bent at the Prime Minister's request. We shall await with very great interest the response of the Prime Minister to that particular exercise.

Let me return to the whole question of the Mick Young imbroglio in which the Prime Minister has found himself. What the Prime Minister has done in relation to Mick Young is to debase the power and the influence of his office in a manner in which it has not been debased before during the five years that he has been in power. On three clear occasions he has breached the duty that he owes to this Parliament and to the Australian people in relation to the Mick Young episode. He did not worry that, when he found out that Mick Young was going to be appointed a consultant to Qantas Airways Ltd, at the same time he wanted him to continue as Federal President of the Australian Labor Party. He simply refused or was unable to recognise that a conflict of interest could exist. He was so careless with the truth that as recently as Sunday he was saying that he knew absolutely nothing about Mick Young's appointment as a Qantas consultant. Yet yesterday when he was finally forced to apply his mind to the facts and circumstances of the matter, what was he doing? He was finally having to admit that he was told about it at the end of February. He gave some dissembling reply in the Parliament today to the effect that it was obvious that there was no conflict in the account. There was a conflict. He was prepared to say anything to the journalists of Australia as recently as the weekend and it was only when he was forced to face the reality of what the situation really was that he had to own up. He knew that his mate, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) up there in the Senate, would give an accurate answer on the subject, a meticulously boringly accurate answer, and he had to be absolutely certain that his reply completely tallied.

Here we have a situation in which not only was he careless about the truth and indifferent as to what he said, but he does not see any problem in ringing anybody to heavy him to give a job to an ex-political mate of his. He does not care that it may establish a potential conflict of interest; he does not care that it breaches the doctrine that he laid down in such a sanctimonious fashion. Members of his own Party more than I will remember how sanctimonious the Prime Minister was about David Combe and on that occasion with very good reason because Combe and Young behaved disgracefully in relation to those episodes. It will never be forgotten by this side of the Parliament that the Prime Minister was prepared to maintain in his Cabinet for four years the former member for Port Adelaide who leaked information that could have damaged Australia's national security. That will never be forgotten on our side of the House and it will always be to the condemnation and the shame of the Prime Minister that he was prepared on that occasion to pathetically, wimpishly and hopelessly forsake the prosecution of his duty because of a sense of mateship and a mistaken sense of loyalty towards the former member for Port Adelaide.

One of our columnists in the Age, Michelle Grattan, reminded us this morning that Mick Young once wrote a book called, I Want to Work. Perhaps after all of this there will be a sequel, I Want to Perk. The real sequel perhaps to this grubby little episode will be how, in the full light of day and in front of the bar of Australian public opinion, this Prime Minister can really ask the traditional Labor voters of Australia, the swinging voters of Australia and the rest of the Australian community to accept the proposition that it is perfectly all right for the Prime Minister to use and abuse the coercive power of his great office, not for the benefit of the general public of Australia-that is the duty he has sworn to pursue-but rather to pursue the selfish interests of a Labor Party mate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have found out why members of the Opposition decided that they would run this little episode today. It links directly in to their efforts in the New South Wales election to distract attention from the debate over policies that is taking place there. That sleazy little document was read by the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who is here, at this table, doing a backbencher's job. The great document that Greiner has been wandering around briefing the Press is going to be dumped this week. How long has that document sat in the hands of members of the Liberal Party of Australia? How long has the knowledge of it been hanging about for them to be able to release it in this place? Of course, they are waiting for the opportunity to table it on what they consider to be the most politically damaging occasion for them to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The document is a rap over the knuckles to a casino operator for not upholding the rules. That is the great document which members of the Opposition have tabled here and on which they wish to build a case. That is adjournment debate stuff for the Leader of the Opposition. That is not even for his frontbencher, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), or even for his new frontbencher, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). It is to get the new member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) to test his teething problems in the House at adjournment time; but it is not for the Leader of the Opposition. Normally leaders of the opposition reserve that type of activity for their underlings, but this Leader of the Opposition has no political commonsense when it comes to dealing with those sorts of cases.

He wishes us to judge him on his remarks about his capacity to convey to this Parliament and to this country issues of great principle and concern with the Prime Minister's conduct of his office. He wishes us to come in here and listen to him debate these matters. He wishes the Parliament to heed him on these matters. What does he do? He walks in and devotes half his speech to this tawdry little document, this tawdry little rap over the knuckles for a casino operator in Western Australia. Does he not do it with such wonderful unction? He says, `Of course, I know little about these matters. I and the little puritanical and wonderful honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) know nothing about these matters'. The Leader of the Opposition says pompously, `I am given to understand that this is regarded terribly seriously by those who play the game'. What an asinine performance. What a pathetic little job to be produced in this Parliament on behalf of Greiner.

We all heard Greiner at the end of last week say, `Oh, we have got one or two things for the Liberal Party to raise in Parliament to make sure that nobody looks at my unjustified $1.4 billion worth of promises that I do not want anyone to hear about. Don't you worry about Barrie Unsworth's campaign next week, it is all going to be obliterated by what we are going to run in the Federal Parliament. We are going to get in there and we have got some really nasty stuff on the Prime Minister'. Now we hear it. Now we have heard the really nasty little stuff from members of the Opposition which was introduced at the end of Question Time with a smutty little smirk on the face of the honourable member for Flinders, acting his proper backbencher's role in introducing this sort of topic to get somebody a bit embarrassed, somebody a bit on the hook. They then build a gigantic case of abuse of office on the basis of a rap over the knuckles for a casino-what do you call him?--

TALK.START.PARA: —Croupier.

—A casino croupier. The honourable member for Adelaide does know about it. He knows that the correct term is `croupier' and he advises me correctly on that matter. He obviously is precisely the right sort of person to drop this document in an adjournment speech. How pathetic. It must be said that the only reason why it is possible--
—You are a Minister; get on with it.

—I do not particularly want to deal with it. The honourable member is heckling me. I quite agree that it is totally inappropriate for the Leader of the House to be dealing with this particular issue. I am obliged to deal with it because the Leader of the Opposition decided to introduce it. Yes, I agree that it is beneath the dignity of people on the front bench of either side of the House to have to deal with this sort of stuff. Unfortunately, we are obliged to deal with it because it was introduced into this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition comes in here with unction on other grounds. It must be said that the only reason we would be discussing here the sorts of rules and principles laid down for the approaching of Ministers by former members of parliament, party officials, or whoever, is that we established guidelines. That was the principal difference between this Government and the Opposition. No guidelines were established when we came into office. We were confronted as a government, not unreasonably, with a plethora of ex-Liberal Party staffers, ex-Liberal Party members of parliament-we have all been approached by them as Ministers-subsequently having set up lobbying or similar types of organisations and requesting us to make decisions on behalf of their clients. I am not attacking lobbyists. Lobbyists perform an important function in facilitating communications between groups and Parliament. The point about lobbyists is that there ought to be an appropriate course of action to determine how they should be dealt with as they approach Ministers.

What was the response of the Opposition when we introduced those particular propositions against which now the Leader of the Opposition is attempting to judge us? The Opposition spokesman of the day said, `This is unnecessary. They ought to be permitted self-regulation. You should not have introduced this in the form of a statement', which was the way it was introduced. `You should have prepared a Bill for us so we could amend it to make absolutely certain that this was not imposed upon Ministers but was an act of self-regulation by the lobbyists themselves'. The Opposition did not want introduced into this Parliament standards by which Ministers could be judged in determining whether or on what basis people should approach them. It thought that was a very bad idea. But now the Opposition has had a latter day conversion so it can excoriate the Prime Minister on these grounds.

Let me make a couple of points quite clear, because it is not only the Opposition but members of the Press who have sought to introduce the letter and spirit of the lobbying guideline rules for Ministers to observe when being approached by former members of parliament or whoever. Those rules are breached in neither letter nor spirit by anything that has happened to this point. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has not approached, as he said, anybody on the basis that what he wishes to do is to facilitate an opportunity for somebody to set up a lobbying exercise. He has simply provided a recommendation. This whole issue has become overstated. Of course, if Mick Young were subsequently to set up a lobbying operation he would be obliged to register himself, and Ministers would be obliged to deal with that matter. What the Prime Minister has provided is more in the nature of a reference. Does the Opposition seriously expect us to believe that its Ministers never provided anybody with a reference, that the Prime Minister of the day never provided a reference for someone who was seeking employment with a company, a government, a government agency, or whatever?

The Leader of the Opposition now seeks to imply-and he did on the steps of Parliament-that in the seven years he was Treasurer, when he was approached, as he would have been, by constituents, friends, former party members, or whoever, seeking employment, he never provided them with a reference. If the Opposition expects us to believe that it never did that when it was in government, or even now while in Opposition, it expects us to stretch credulity too far. Of course that is exactly what the Opposition has done in times when it has been in government. To suggest otherwise is absurd. If the Leader of the Opposition did it as Treasurer, are we then to come in here when Mr Murgatroyd, former Liberal Party branch member in whatever constituency it is he holds, has applied for a job with a accountancy firm, and say that because the Treasurer has provided him with a reference the Treasurer has perverted that grand high office he holds; that he is indicating to that accountancy firm that if it were not to employ Mr Murgatroyd it might expect hostile treatment from the Commissioner of Taxation when it comes to dealing with submissions it puts to him on behalf of its clients? Are we expected to believe that somehow or other, operating in the mind of the average accountant, is the thought that coercion will be applied and that the former Treasurer would have intended that to have been the effect on whoever it was who was receiving the reference? What a load of nonsense. What a load of overstated garbage has been spoken about this matter since the Prime Minister yesterday said that he had effectively provided the reference for Mick Young to a couple of companies. What overstated nonsense.

If we are going to go on the criteria of the Leader of the Opposition, all of us as members of parliament had better start having very strict hands-off relationships with absolutely everybody we have ever known who might reasonably want us, as members of the community placed in some position of trust, to speak on their behalf. We had better make it known to them that we will never do that.

So overdrawn unction is basically the argument of the Leader of the Opposition, arguing principles which it must be said we set and which those opposite opposed when they were in government. The Leader of the Opposition went through it again. He introduced his broader jobs-for-the-boys framework, and indeed it is that framework in which he has sought to have this whole thing argued. He was doorstopped today and he said: `No, the Prime Minister occupies a unique position of power in this country, a special position. He has to wield that power carefully and sensibly. It has to be wielded in the public and not in the private interest'. He was asked whether a Liberal Prime Minister had done that. The Leader replied, `I don't know but I'm not answerable for them. If they did, they were wrong too. I am dealing with the present. The past is irrelevant'. He was asked whether he did anything like this-it was taken out more broadly-when he was Treasurer. He replied, `Oh, no'. As Treasurer he would have recommended the appointment to the Reserve Bank Board of the former Liberal Party Senator, Bob Cotton, and his subsequent replacement by Phil Lynch.

We do not suggest that appointments of former Ministers to boards and to embassies are inappropriate or improper, but the way in which the Opposition has conducted itself over the last two weeks in this place is that it certainly believes that those sorts of appointments are in some way improper and inappropriate. It believes that it is a case of jobs for the boys. It has been arguing that about Hurford. Members of the Opposition have been wandering around the place saying, `Hurford's appointment constitutes jobs for the boys. That is what the Labor Party has engaged in here-jobs for the boys'. They have suggested that a totally independent decision by Qantas Airways Ltd to employ the former member for Port Adelaide is jobs for the boys, but the appointment by the then Treasurer of two Liberal Party ex-Ministers to the Reserve Bank Board was not jobs for the boys. Members of the Opposition say, `That is something different because we do it'. That is the essential moral criterion that is established. `If we do it it is okay: if the other side does it it is jobs for the boys and the other side will do it only because it must, by dint of that, be out of touch in some way with the Australian public'. We have heard not only cant in this place from the Leader of the Opposition when he came in here doing his backbenchers' jobs, but we also heard galloping hypocrisy from the Leader of the Opposition when he presented his argument.

I return to the point that has been made about where Mick Young stands in relation to the appointments he has received and the approaches that have been made on his behalf, and whether they bear any relation to either the spirit or the letter of the rules and guidelines for lobbyists. He has not established a lobbying position. It was not on the basis that he sought a lobbying position that the Prime Minister held discussions with the relevant private businessmen; it was on that basis that he was available generally for work. There is no requirement in that regard to register in any way. The issues that are raised for Ministers when lobbyists approach them are simply not raised by them. The Leader of the Opposition has come in here and soiled his hands with a grubby little effort on behalf of his mate in New South Wales.
