That piece of rubbish will be properly rejected by the people of Australia, and they will be ashamed for him, ashamed that he has had to stoop to the rank of muck-throwing backbencher in the presentation of his case here today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —How sad it is that the man who succeeded as Leader of the House the man about whom much of this debate this afternoon is concentrated has presented to this House such a paltry defence of what is a fundamental principle of Australian democracy. There have been three instances this week in which I think all members of this place have felt disappointed in the morality not just of the Government but of the man who is Prime Minister. I remind the House of them. The first is that, there having been presented to this House and to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a legal opinion from a former Solicitor-General and a former Attorney-General regarding the culpability of the man who is today the Labor Minister for Health and Community Services (Dr Blewett), as far as we are aware this matter has not yet been referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions, and the Minister was in this House today.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite might laugh-it does not matter to them. There being from a senior law officer of the Commonwealth an opinion which so many in the profession have belittled, and a contrary opinion having been tendered, at the very least the matter should be submitted to the Director of Public Prosecutions.
—Rubbish!

—It is not a matter of the honourable member just laughing and saying `Rubbish', for that is the problem. As I tear this paper, so the Government regards the whole concept of private interest and public responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The second instance, and I think equally to be condemned, is the fact that from the whole of the unwinding of the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd affair, a matter which is still before the Australian Federal Police, a matter which is still before the Director of Public Prosecutions, there has emerged a second and really quite deplorable chapter. This chapter relates to the intervention of the Prime Minister. This is quite aside from anything that might have happened in the manipulation of financial donations to the Australian Labor Party, in an apparent contravention of laws introduced by the man who was the Leader of the House, a man who has now retired as the member for Port Adelaide and the man who only this week resigned as President of the Labor Party. What has happened is that the Prime Minister has intervened on his behalf and intervened, we are told, in the matter of a testimonial. As my colleague the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, `Where the devil have these leading businessmen been in Australia for the past 10 years?'. None of us thought that the former Leader of the House, Mr Mick Young, was exactly a blushing violet. He certainly did not hide his virtues when on three successive occasions on this side of the House we felt he should have resigned, and resigned permanently.

The first case, we all recall, was the Combe-Ivanov affair. And how correctly the Leader of the Opposition described it; an affair for which nobody in the Government can really hold his head high. Do members of the Government laugh at the concept of a senior judge of the Federal Court damning this man as committing a potential breach of national security? Yet the Prime Minister brought him back and allowed him to remain a member of his Cabinet for four years. Then we had the Paddington Bear affair, where this former Minister conveniently avoided the obligations of a Customs declaration form. This man still returned to the Hawke Ministry, still remained to perpetrate breaches of what he said were laws necessary for the people of Australia. One of those laws happened to be that which set down the Register of Pecuniary Interests, and I will come back to that in a moment.

The third contravention of the Prime Minister's responsibility and the Government's responsibility to put public duty and principle above private interest has occurred in the document which, for the benefit of the present Leader of the House (Mr Beazley), I should say, we learned about for the first time today. Because the Leader of the House has made so little of the findings, I refer him to the Violation Report, for I regard it, quite apart from guilt or innocence, as reflecting better the nature, manner and form of the way in which the man who temporarily is Prime Minister carries out his private life and, one would suspect, his public duty.

In the Casino Control Committee Violation Report, reference No. 017/86 of 16 November 1986, the time of the violation is put down at 0030 hours, 12.30 at night. The nature of the violation incident states:
The sole player on BJ87 (Prime Minister Hawke) was observed on a number of occasions to wager on one box only. At 0025 hours . . .
name deleted-
rang the pit and spoke to . . . on the matter . . . indicated that he would call back.
At 0030 hours, the . . . rang the Division's Surveillance Room. He stated Mr Hawke had requested to be allowed to play one box occasionally throughout the night.
Mr X-
. . . indicated that he had agreed to this.
When . . . informed him that this was contrary to rule 4.8 of Blackjack . . . replied that it was a private game behind closed doors. He further indicated that he would not rectify the situation.

Honourable members opposite might well guffaw, but the point of all this is that the Prime Minister, quite in contravention of the laws that are laid down for members of the public in the casino, was quite prepared to play in violation of those laws. Like so many of the laws that this Government has introduced, we do not like them either, but members of the public, the ordinary public, the people with whom the Prime Minister and these Ministers are totally out of touch, are required to comply with those laws. Can those opposite tell me if any other players in the casino had breached the casino's laws in this way whether they would have been allowed to continue to play? Of course not. But this man is the Prime Minister. This man, as Prime Minister, requested that he play one box occasionally through the night. Because he used his influence, the casino management allowed him to do that and, as I quote, `indicated that he had agreed to this'. What is more, the casino management indicated that `he would not rectify the situation'.

Now, Mr Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), that is our concern about the Prime Minister's telephone calls this week. What happened this week was that the Prime Minister, as Prime Minister of Australia, as the head of this Government, as a man who has some muscle as head of the Government, if for no other reason, rang a couple of this mates and said, `I have got another mate, Mick Young. I want you to find a job for him'. We were told yesterday that he had reason to believe that his telephone calls would lead to that application being successful. I put to honourable members: if the casino was prepared to vary the rules for players of blackjack simply because it was Prime Minister Hawke, who was the sole player playing blackjack, how can they expect leaders of business to be able to say to the man who is Prime Minister, `No, we are not going to find a job for Mick Young. We do not believe that in the present circumstances we should employ him.'?

Let us recall that this whole affair arose because the Australian Labor Party, on the occasion of its last biennial conference, set down in its Platform Resolutions and Rules, in the economic section, rule 10 relating to the concept of privatisation. We all know that Mick Young has been employed, at what is reputed to be a salary of $3,000 a week-he then being President of the Labor Party-to subvert the laws of the Labor Party with respect to privatisation. Rule 10 of the Labor Party's rules, which he, as President, presumably was committed to uphold, states:

Labor rejects the concept of privatisation and will preserve and develop public enterprise and public investment so as to integrate the policies of public enterprises with broad social and economic objectives.

We all know why Mick Young went to Qantas Airways Ltd. He went to get that law overturned. He went to Qantas so that, as President of the Labor Party, he would be able to get the numbers in the New South Wales Right, in Barrie Unsworth's group, along with the Centre Left and a few independents, and they would be able to roll those idiots on the Left for they do not matter. It was their resolution that introduced privatisation, and it was their resolution which their President was employed to ensure was reversed.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I put to you that this whole week has shown a succession of occasions when the Prime Minister has put his private interests above his public duty; when the Prime Minister has totally contravened the circumstances which any man exercising that high office should use in ensuring that he is above any suggestion of undue interference. He did it with blackjack. He did it, as we have seen, with Mick Young. He did it in his telephone calls. He has done it in refusing to require the resignation, or at least the standing down, of the Minister for Community Services and Health. On no account does the Prime Minister deserve to get away with his abuse of his office.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The right honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —One has learned to expect everything in this House. I never thought I would see the day in this House when the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) would talk about public interest, probity and conflict of interest. That is a joke, and it shows how tenuous this matter of public importance is. The Leader of the National Party speaking about conflict of interest, of public duty, of probity, is like putting Dracula in charge of the blood bank. It is a joke to hear him speaking on those matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made it very clear in Question Time today that he totally rejects the proposition that in contacting two leading businessmen on behalf of Mr Young that in any way amounted to a breach of the Government's guidelines on dealings with lobbyists. The Prime Minister went on to explain that approaching the two businessmen concerned to facilitate possible employment for Mr Young was simply by way of general testimonial to his abilities. The Prime Minister further in his answer made clear that to the extent that Mr Young may subsequently engage in lobbying activities, the guidelines will be scrupulously followed.

I find it ironic, I find it contradictory to say the least, that members of the Opposition should base their premise for this matter of public importance on public duty and conflict with guidelines for the registration of lobbyists that this Government introduced. It is this Government that introduced those guidelines because it wanted to ensure there were guidelines to govern properly and effectively issues of public duty and possible conflict. They were not guidelines that the Opposition supported; they were guidelines the Opposition opposed. Yet now members of the Opposition seek to stand proud on those guidelines and base a case against the Prime Minister on conflict of interest. That is a tenuous case to say the least.

In all these areas of public duty and conflict of interest this Government has taken the lead, taken the responsibility for setting appropriate guidelines to measure and ensure that proper concern is paid to questions of public duty and conflict of interest. It was this Government also that introduced into this House legislation requiring the registration of pecuniary interests by all government backbenchers. It was this Government that proposed that legislation; it was this Government that introduced it. We did it with no support from the Opposition, which totally opposed that procedure for registration. We now have in this House-we are one of the few countries of the world to have this-a registration of pecuniary interests for members of Parliament so that members of the public can make their own assessment about whether any member of this Parliament acts in breach of the public interest and public duty. It is interesting to note, is it not, that such registration of pecuniary interests does not exist in the Senate? It does not exist in the Senate because the Opposition parties voted against the establishment of such a pecuniary interests register.

So, in all these important issues that safeguard and protect democracy and the public interest, this Government has been a forerunner in reform. It is this Government that introduced guidelines for the registration of lobbyists, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) knows full well. It is this Government that introduced the pecuniary interests guidelines for every member of this Parliament. I find it absolutely remarkable that members opposite are mounting a case today of breach of public duty on the basis of guidelines that this Government introduced.

The Government is prepared to stand before the bar of public opinion on all matters of propriety. We are prepared to do that. I contrast that with so many of the policies of the previous discredited Fraser-Howard Government which was not prepared to stand before the public, was not prepared to stand at the bar of public opinion as we have done.

I refer to the question of tax avoidance. I do not know how the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) can speak in this place about apparent conflicts of public duty and private interest when for years and years he was the Treasurer who received memo after memo about the unfettered floodgates that were haemorrhaging away the tax system in Australia through tax avoidance. For him to speak about probity and public interest makes a total mockery of the procedures of this place. He has no respect or credibility at all in this place. Earlier today the Leader of the Opposition held a Press conference at which he was asked about this matter. He suggested:
When we are talking about the Prime Minister of Australia heavying people and potentially creating an obligation, that is dangerous stuff.

The Leader of the Opposition is also the master of exaggeration. How absurd to beat up the story of a Prime Minister talking to two businesses on the phone and say that the Prime Minister of Australia was heavying people. I have never heard anything so preposterous.

It has been said by members of the Opposition that we did not need guidelines for the registration of lobbyists before this Government came to office. We did not need them because outside Ministers' offices there were long queues of all the old Liberal apparatchiks waiting to see their mates in government. That was the way the system used to work. It was a system of courtship and friendship that members opposite promulgated in government. It was this Government that had the decency to introduce guidelines to protect the public interest.

Let me conclude with the key piece of evidence that was brought into the House today by the Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the House, the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), made the point that the Leader of the Opposition had made a bad mistake by bringing into this House a smutty little document designed to help his friends in the New South Wales election, in particular Mr Greiner. The Leader of the House is quite right because the Opposition in this matter is right down in the gutter and he will pay the price in the future. Let me get to the question of the smutty little document the Leader of the Opposition brought into the House today. He has crawled into the gutter. Every member of the Opposition knows that in relation to this question of blackjack on some occasion during the blackjack game the Prime Minister asked to play one box. Every member of the Opposition knows that was permitted. No-one suggested to the Prime Minister that this was against the rules. The Opposition knows that the rules vary from State to State. On a subsequent visit to the casino the rule on playing one box was for the first time drawn to the Prime Minister's attention and he quite readily and happily accepted that. The matter in question, this secret missile, this smutty little document that the Leader of the Opposition has brought into the House today, originated some 15 months ago but he brings it into the House now, three days before the New South Wales election. No official reports on the matter have been drawn to the attention of the Prime Minister since then. So far as I am concerned, and so far as every member on this side of the House is concerned, the matter was finished then and there. Every member of the Opposition knew that no flagrant breach of any regulations applied and that the matter was minor. What I have explained in this House shows that that is so. The Opposition is desperate. Its leader is under further pressure and its members are forced to come into this House producing smutty little documents that put the Leader of the Opposition down in the gutter where he rightfully belongs.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF HIGH CAPACITY FIRE HYDRANTS: PARLIAMENTARY ZONE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House approves the following proposal contained in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House presented to the House on 10 December 1987, namely: The construction of high capacity fire hydrants within the Parliamentary zone.

The National Capital Development Commission (NCDC), on behalf of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Fire Brigade, proposes to install 12 high capacity fire hydrants at various locations within the parliamentary zone. The installation of these hydrants will enable the fire brigade to extract from existing underground mains sufficient water to fight major building fires within the zone. The design of the hydrants has been developed jointly by the NCDC, the Australian Capital Territory Fire Brigade, and the ACT Administration for use in Canberra. The fire brigade requires the hydrants to be located within six metres of hardstanding to enable connection to the fire tender. The hydrants are also sited in visually prominent positions and coloured for quick and easy identification in emergencies. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have heard the explanation of the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch), which he would normally provide two hours before he spoke in this place, of this particular resolution. The explanation throws some light on the motion. As I understand it, the motion seeks the Parliament's approval for the construction of fire hydrants for the protection of the new Parliament House. Of course, the Opposition supports the need for such protection for the new Parliament House. The Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House has apparently discussed this need with the fire brigade and with fire brigade experts. According to a report tabled in this House on 10 December 1987, the experts are satisified with the arrangements that have been made.

SPEECH.PARA: The outstanding issue is why on earth appropriate fire fighting equipment was not incorporated earlier in the overall design of the new Parliament House. If there were some disagreement about the exact nature of the hydrants, that matter should have been resolved, in my view, in the building stages so that the hydrants could have been included as an integral part of the construction rather than, as is now being requested of the Parliament, to have these fire hydrants put in place as a late addition only a month or so before the opening of the new Parliament. I repeat that I should have thought such protective equipment was an essential and integral part of the building of the new Parliament House and should have been included in the original construction proposal. Nevertheless, the coalition supports the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: BOUNTY AND SUBSIDY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to various bounty and subsidy Acts. The major proposals contained in the Bill are; first, the implementation of the Government's decision announced in the 1987-88 Budget to terminate the Bounty (Agricultural Tractors and Equipment) Act 1985 as from 15 September 1987; and, second, the amendments to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986, to effect changes to the book bounty scheme as a result of the Government's consideration of the report of the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries. In addition, the Bill makes a number of technical amendments to clarify certain eligibility criteria and administrative features in other bounty and subsidy schemes, as well as repealing certain expired bounty schemes. These amendments are set out in detail in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill, which has been circulated.

I shall now briefly outline the two major proposals that are contained in the Bill. First, I refer to the Bounty (Agricultural Tractors and Equipment) Act of 1985. There is something in this Bill for everyone: readers and non-readers. This is for the National Party. When the agricultural tractors and equipment bounty scheme was introduced in mid-1985, the Government believed that it would assist the local agricultural tractor industry to strengthen its position in the domestic market and become economically viable in the longer term. However, since that time, production by the major manufacturer in Australia has virtually ceased, and it has become clear that the scheme has not been effective in maintaining an internationally competitive tractor manufacturing industry in Australia. In the circumstances, and balanced against other budgeting constraints, the Government decided in the context of the 1987 Budget to terminate the scheme as from Budget night last September. I should like to emphasise that tractors and parts in stock at the time the decision was made are eligible for bounty payments in the usual way, provided applicants can demonstrate that the goods satisfy the normal end use preconditions of the legislation.

Finally, I should like to point out that agricultural tractors and equipment are incorporated in the reference on mining, construction and agricultural equipment currently with the Industries Assistance Commission. It is therefore open to people to put forward their views to the Commission on what they consider to be the appropriate level of assistance for this industry sector.

I shall now refer to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986. This Bill also proposes amendments to the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 which will extend bounty assistance to the book producing industry to 31 December 1993, and implement various related administrative arrangements as a result of the Government's consideration of the Industries Assistance Commission's report No. 401, dated 25 February 1987, on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries. Bounty has been paid on certain Australian book production since 1969 in order to assist the Australian printing industry compete with overseas book printers. This particular industry is assisted by means of a bounty because, although not a signatory, the Government adheres to the spirit of the Florence agreement, which precludes the imposition of tariffs on books containing educational, scientific and cultural material.

In its 1987 report, the IAC concluded that the book producing sector should continue to be assisted by bounty until at least 31 December 1991. It recommended that the bounty of 20 per cent of net selling price be phased to 18 per cent after one year and to 13.5 per cent after two years. Further, it was recommended that no changes be made to the bounty criteria which applied from 1 January 1987.

The Government accepted the IAC recommended reduction in book bounty rate to 13.5 per cent, which is equivalent to a 15 per cent tariff. However, as the industry has already suffered rapid bounty reductions over recent years, it was decided to phase in the reductions over four years rather than two years with an extension of the scheme to 31 December 1993, thus producing a more stable assistance environment allowing the industry to confidently make long-term plans. Accordingly, the book bounty will remain at 20 per cent until 31 December 1988. Bounty will then be reduced to: 18 per cent from 1 January 1989; 16 per cent from 1 January 1990; 14 per cent from 1 January 1991; and 13.5 per cent from 1 January 1992. The Government will again review assistance to the book industry prior to the 31 December 1993 expiry of the existing scheme.

The Government has also decided that although existing administrative procedures should generally continue, certain changes should be made to facilitate more efficient administration of the scheme. In brief, the Government has decided that a minimum claim of $500 per title per production run will be introduced for all claims for book bounty, replacing the current $200 minimum claim limit. Bounty will be paid on a production run of 1,000 copies or more which includes more than one type of eligible binding of the same book, so that hardback and paperback editions of the one book produced together will be treated as having been printed in the one production run. Packaging used for promotional purposes and sold with a book eligible for bounty will now be bountiable. All children's books over 16 pages when the text is not less than 3 mm, irrespective of whether or not the book contains pictures, will be bountiable. Self-financing government publishing enterprises producing and marketing books in substantial competition with the private sector will now be eligible to receive bounty.

With regard to these proposed administrative changes it is considered that raising the minimum claim from the existing $200 per title per production run to $500 will assist administrative efficiency by reducing the number of book bounty claims while not disadvantaging small bounty printer claimants. The National Book Industry Review Committee has maintained that claims between $200 and $500 account for less than 5 per cent of these claimants' output, and usually involves specialist work not subject to overseas competition.

The proposed change relating to the binding of books will remove the present provision in the Act which prohibits variations to book binding material when the production run of a particular book is assessed for eligibility. This means that the same book printed in both casebound and paperback form cannot be combined in the same production run. Representations from the industry argued that this discriminates against casebound books. Production runs of casebound books are often less than 1,000 copies, and therefore ineligible for bounty.

The exclusion of these books because of binding variation represents too fine a distinction and defeats the intention of the book bounty. The Government has therefore decided that a production run be defined as including more than one type of eligible binding of the same book. This change is proposed to be made retrospective to 1 January 1987, the date of commencement of the current Act.

Similarly, the proposed amendment relating to packaging will remove an impediment under the existing Act which allows packaging for the purpose of transport to be eligible for bounty, but not if the packaging is used for promotional purposes. Packaging for an imported book is not dutiable as it forms part of the imported product. The use of packaging for promotional purposes is common in the book industry, and when used in this way for an imported book does not attract duty. To draw a dichotomy between this packaging and packaging used in advertising a book which is locally produced is therefore inconsistent and discriminates against the local book production industry. For these reasons the Government considers it appropriate that bounty be now paid for packaging used for promotional purposes.

The proposed amendments relating to children's books are intended to remove both an anomaly in the present legislation, and an administrative problem which has arisen. The Act provides for children's picture books over 16 pages to be eligible for bounty while other children's books are required to have a minimum of 49 pages to become eligible. Children's picture books containing a continuous narrative are also excluded unless the minimum size of the text is not less than 3mm, and the pictures form the principle interest in the book. It is anomalous that children's picture books are eligible for bounty while other children's books are not. It is considered that administration problems relating to children's story books and adult story books can be resolved by establishing a standard minimum text size for children's books. It is generally accepted within the industry that 3mm is an appropriate minimum size. By allowing all children's books over 16 pages when the text is no less than 3 mm, and children's books over 16 pages with pictures only to be eligible for bounty, it is considered both the anomaly and administration problems will be resolved.

Finally, the proposal to make bountiable certain work produced by a government instrumentality is intended to address two problems being encountered in the present legislation. Currently, when an eligible process is subcontracted to a government printer this renders the book ineligible for bounty. The Tasmanian Government Printer has requested that as bindery facilities are only available in Tasmania through the Government Printing Office, private sector printers be permitted to subcontract bindery work to the Tasmania Government Printer without forfeiting their eligibility to claim book bounty. In order to solve this difficulty, the Government has decided that when an eligible process is subcontracted to a government printer or other authority of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory, this will not render other eligible processes undertaken by the private sector for that book ineligible for bounty.

Bounty will continue to not be payable to the Commonwealth, a State or Territory or an authority of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory for book production. However it has been decided that self-financing government publishing enterprises-for example, the Australian Broadcasting Commission-when they are producing and marketing in substantial competition with the private sector, should not be unduly disadvantaged relative to the private sector. Accordingly, it is proposed by this Bill to give the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce the power to determine exemptions from bounty exclusion for such self-financing government enterprises. The detail and mechanics of this exemption process, together with the previously mentioned administrative changes, are further discussed in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Financial Impact Statement

Bounty payments to the book industry under the Bounty (Books) Act 1986 will be $18.4m during the 1987-88 financial year, and are expected to be $21.4m during financial year 1988-89 and $19.3m in financial year 1989-90. The termination of the agricultural tractors scheme is expected to save $900,000 in the 1987-88 financial year. The other proposed amendments in the Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921, to incorporate into that Act various excise tariff proposals tabled in this Parliament during the last sittings and early in this sittings. These proposals concern the excise duty on liquefied petroleum gas; adjustments to the excise duties on refined petroleum products following movements in the import parity price; an increase in the excise duty on aviation gasoline; and an adjustment to restrict the total excise duty increases as a result of consumer price index indexations for the 1987-88 financial year to 6 per cent.
Liquefied Petroleum Gas

The excise duty for naturally occurring liquefied petroleum gas is adjusted six-monthly on 1 April and 1 October each year in accordance with the Government's LPG excise policy announced in April 1980. The excise rate is calculated as 60 per cent of the amount by which the realised price for naturally occurring LPG exceeds $147 a tonne. The realised price is based on the weighted average of the prices received from exports and local sales of LPG during the immediately preceding six months. Before 30 June 1987 the excise applied to LPG from all fields in production in August 1977. However, under the new petroleum excise arrangements introduced from 1 July 1987, LPG produced from onshore fields is exempt from excise, so the excise now only applies to offshore fields-that is, Bass Strait. No excise is payable on refinery-produced LPG.

Clause 3 of the Bill will amend the excise rate, with effect from 1 October 1987, from $5.02 to $13.21 a kilolitre, an increase of $8.19 from the previous rate set on 1 April 1987. The increase reflects an increase in export prices of LPG in March 1987 and the stability of prices at the higher level for the 6 month period since then.
Import Parity Price Adjustments

The import parity price adjustments for 1 October 1987 and 1 December 1987, at clauses 4 and 5, reflect movements in world oil prices during the respective preceding month. The reduction in the import parity price for 1 October directly results in a decrease in excise and royalty receipts for crude oil, while the increase in the oil price for December will increase excise and royalty receipts. Since March 1986 the Government's policy has been to fully offset changes in its revenue from crude oil excise and royalty by across the board changes in excises payable on petroleum products. The net result of this decision has been that, as crude oil prices change, Government revenues remain the same overall. Consistent with this Government's policy, excise rates on refined petroleum products were increased on 17 October 1987 and decreased on 15 December 1987.

These changes are expected to be the final adjustments of this kind as the Government has decided, with the deregulation of crude oil marketing from 1 January 1988, to discontinue the practice of offsetting changes in crude oil revenue by changes in product excise rates. In the absence of the import parity pricing mechanism from 1 January, a continuation of the practice would have been difficult and inappropriate in a free market environment. However, the Government will continue to monitor oil prices closely and will consider variations in petroleum product excise rates to counter inflationary or revenue effects in the case of a substantial change in world oil prices.
Aviation Gasoline

Clause 6 of the Bill will increase the amount of excise duty on aviation gasoline, with effect from 1 January 1988, to cover the cost of terminal navigation-that is, air traffic control-and rescue and firefighting services at Essendon, Coolangatta and Launceston airports. Aircraft using avgas ceased to be charged for those services with effect from the 1 January commencement date, and the additional charge of 0.5c per litre will offset the cost of those services. These revised arrangements were introduced after consultation with the aviation industry had revealed that, under the previous charging arrangements which came into effect last July, general aviation avgas operators who used the three airports, and incurred landing charges as a result, were disadvantaged compared with their competitors operating at the general aviation secondary airports, who were not faced with any landing charges in respect of their use of those facilities. The extent of the disparity was not foreseen by either the industry or the Government at the time the changes were made last July.

The Government reconsidered the position of avgas excise charging arrangements in respect of these three airports following its consultations with the major industry associations, and the proposal to replace the Commonwealth's landing charges-that is, the terminal navigation and rescue and firefighting service charges-at these airports with an additional 0.5c per litre surcharge on avgas excise has been introduced to remove the disparity occasioned by the charges which users of these three airports were encountering.
Limitation of Excise Indexation to around 6 per cent

Clause 7 of the Bill will effectively limit the total excise indexation increases for the 1987-88 financial year to 6 per cent. These amendments fulfil the commitment made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during the inaugural Ruby Hutchison Memorial Address at the National Press Club on 13 March 1987. The amendments decrease the rates of excise duty applying immediately prior to indexation on the February 1988 adjustment date, so that when the legislative provisions for indexation are applied, which requires the use of the published consumer price index, the resulting indexation is 2.5 per cent. This increase, when combined with the August 1987 indexation adjustment of 3.5 per cent, yields a total indexation of 6 per cent for the 1987-88 financial year.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT
Liquefied Petroleum Gas
The 1 October 1987 increase in the excise rate for naturally occurring LPG is estimated to result in an increase of $9.5m in excise receipts in 1987-88.
Import Parity Price

The alterations in refined petroleum product excise rates due to the changes in the import parity prices effective from 17 October 1987 and 14 December 1987 are expected to have the following impact on revenue in 1987-88:
The increase in refined petroleum product excise rates effective 17 October 1987 is expected to increase revenue by about $121m;
The decrease in refined petroleum product excise rates effective 14 December 1987 is expected to decrease revenue by about $66m.
These changes in the excise rates following the above changes to import parity prices are intended to exactly offset the forecast changes in revenue from crude oil excise and royalties.
Aviation Gasoline Surcharge

The measure has no direct financial implications, as it has been designed to recover only the revenue which will be forgone by the Commonwealth as a result of the removal of the terminal navigation and rescue and firefighting components of the landing charges levied at Essendon, Coolangatta and Launceston airports; aircraft using aviation gasoline ceased to be charged for these services from 1 January 1988, the date of effect of the surcharge.
Limitation of Total Excise Indexation to 6 per cent
The financial impact of imposing a 6 per cent ceiling on excise duty rate increases for 1987-88 is estimated to result in revenue forgone of $25m for that financial year.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT (SHARE INCREASE) BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 February, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill. The coalition does not oppose this Bill. The purpose of the legislation is to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up an increase in its capital subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which of course is the main arm of the World Bank. This is expected to cost $US1.88m spread over four financial years from 1988 to 1989. In 1984 the World Bank governors agreed to implement a $US7 billion special capital increase to allow the Bank to expand its borrowing on world financial markets so as to fund its activities.

SPEECH.PARA: A country contributes to a special capital increase by subscribing for more shares in the Bank. Australia commenced providing for this increased subscription in 1986. During 1986 the governors also approved a resolution authorising a further phase of the supplementary share allocation. This Bill provides for Australia's contribution. I will not go into the technical details involved in the share raisings as they are non-controversial and were adequately explained in the second reading speech of the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

Previously, when in government, the coalition has supported funding to the World Bank. We recognise the Bank as a fairly effective institution in delivering multilateral aid to developing countries. The capital increase is required because of the ongoing need to aid the development of the poorer and less advantaged countries on this earth. The World Bank, compared with commercial banks, has always been a conservative institution, maintaining a one to one ratio between lending and capital. This is one of the reasons that the bank has been able to operate with few hints of financial problems over its four decades of operation. Indeed, the bank is seen by many as the premier multilateral aid institution. However, like any large organisation, it has suffered in recent years from becoming overly bureaucratic. There have been concerns that programs have wasted scarce development assistance. I understand that the President of the bank, an American, Mr Barber Conable, is putting into effect an internal restructuring plan for the bank.

There have been some disruptions and troubles in this spring-cleaning. In recent times it has meant a certain loss of attention from the key issues before the World Bank. Of course, the key issue standing before the bank like a gargantuan is the so-called Third World debt crisis. Although the calculation of the exact outstanding debt of developing countries is hard to measure, due to so-called definitional problems between countries, the World Bank projects that in 1987 debt for the Third World stood at $US1,080 billion. That represents a 66 per cent increase since 1980. I assume that to most of us it is fairly hard to comprehend the real impact of the size of this figure on the world scene. What is worse is that by far the largest share-over 40 per cent-falls in the South American region.

Many plans have been put forward to help solve these problems through international co-operation. There is the Baker plan, from the United States Secretary for the Treasury, James Baker, to boost commercial bank lending. There is the Lawson plan from the United Kingdom Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson, to improve the rescheduling of debt. There is the Bradley plan, the Kaufman plan and a myriad of other debt solutions. Most, I regret to say, appear to have rested more on rhetoric than on action. Indeed, what is often said but usually is conveniently overlooked in practice in the numerous conferences on debt is the principal need for restructuring by the developing countries. I was for many years the Foreign Minister of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good one too.

—I would agree with the honourable member, but modesty prevents me from developing that at any further length. The World Bank, of course, came under the aegis of the Treasurer. Therefore, I was concerned only in passing with the World Bank, but I was keen to see the manner in which it addressed many of its problems. During my period as Minister Mr Bob McNamara retired from his post at the World Bank. I was an admirer of Mr McNamara before I became Foreign Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The bank, as I said, has undergone many changes. I referred to the myriad of plans that were put before the international community to try to solve the problem of debt. To use the colloquialism, it used to drive me to distraction at international conferences to hear the discussions on debt because very few discussions emanated from those who had placed themselves in great debt. Honourable members should examine my record in seeking to increase aid funds while I was Foreign Minister. Certainly, the proportion of aid under us, as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP), was infinitely larger than under this Government. It is now at one of the lowest levels in the history of this country. But the salient point of countries turning to restructure themselves was a point that was rarely delivered to the Third World. Frankly, if money is to be delivered, some messages ought to be given as well, but rarely were the messages accepted in any vein at all.

I think of the tragedy of Ethiopia. In late 1984 I flew to Ethiopia. It was a stark scene that we had witnessed on our television screens. The responsibility for assisting the Ethiopians rested with the developed world. The Soviets were continuing to assist them with military equipment but in the midst of their need-a need to be fed-we had to get food into the country. The single thing that could have assisted the long term regeneration of growth in Ethiopia would have been a restructuring and an opening up of that Marxist controlled economy. International expert after international expert would pen these thoughts, but no one would seek to coerce the Government, which still continues in power in Ethiopia, to make the fundamental change to its own economy. I see a need for the World Bank to use some of the muscle that the International Monetary Fund can use, when it is called in on occasions to coerce some countries into changing their systems.

The tragedy is that we are being warned daily that Ethiopia is facing yet another problem. The civil war goes on but the restructuring has not gone on. It is obvious to even the most casual observer what has to be done, from reafforestation to freeing up markets. It is a stark and sorry tragedy. It was easy, in a way, to meet the ready emergency last time. One had only to bring in food. But we cannot do that year in and year out. We have to get people to attend to their own affairs in an effective manner, and that is not being done. I regret that even with an institution such as the World Bank the capacity to cajole people into the not only sensible but required changes does not appear to be there.

I started on that little distraction when I touched on the massive amount of debt in the international community and the need for restructuring by the developing countries. This obviously brings me, regrettably, to our own country's plight. After all, Australia is a commodity dependent country with much in common with Third World nations. Our mineral and agricultural products account for around 80 per cent of exported goods. This is typical for a developing country. But the more chilling comparison with the Third World countries is the level of our foreign debt. Unfortunately, we must go back a couple of years to find suitable data to compare Australia with South American countries.

At the end of 1986 a study carried out by the Morgan Guaranty trust company revealed that Australia's gross foreign debt stood at around $101 billion. I go back to 1986, as I said, to get an accurate comparison with other countries, whose figures are not available as our figures are today. That figure represented 42 per cent of GDP, and debt service-that is, interest on debt and repayment of principle-represented over 60 per cent of exports. Some people will say that that is quite acceptable when compared with a country such as Argentina which, at that time, had a foreign debt of 68 per cent of GDP and debt servicing representing around 200 per cent of exports. But there is no comfort in the fact that Australia's debt, at 42 per cent of GDP, was not far distant from the 46 per cent for Colombia and was larger than the 41 per cent figure for Brazil. Both of those countries are well known economic basket cases.

Clearly, the Government should wake up. The reality is-we on this side of the House know it-that debt in this country has quadrupled under Labor. I have talked on and on about what needs to be done, but I will simply say today that we do not oppose the Bill. There is an absolute need, however, for the Government to make up and to shake off its complacency. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) is well remembered for his banana republic threat about the Australian economy. Why does he not warn us about such things nowadays? No, the climate is changing. See you later, mate-there is no more frank speaking like that. The Treasurer says, `I've got a Prime Minister who's got his feet in the gluepot. I've got my eyes on the job. You're not going to hear me talking about the state of the economy. I am going to tell you how good it is and claim that I have brought it about'. He forgets that the underlying structural elements in this economy can be accurately compared with those of banana republics and Third World, debt-ridden basket cases throughout the international community. `No.', he said, `we are going to put a gloss on it now'. At the time he said that we might be headed for a banana republic, it suited him. To hell with it suiting Australia. To hell with the shock it gave some people. To hell with his own credibility. He was a macho man then. But now it does not suit. He wants to assume the mantle of the prime ministership in the dying months of this Government. He is not prepared to rock the boat or even give a hint of the gloomy clouds on the horizon. I have heard some fanciful stuff in my time, but to have this creature sitting at a Press conference yesterday, saying, `We are leading the world with our economy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Down the drain.

—Yes. I suppose that if one used some form of inverse calculation one might, by some sort of tortured logic, be able to reach the conclusion that we are in front. But my God, one would have to be using reverse principles to achieve that. The same thing appears to be happening regrettably, for different reasons perhaps, which Senator Walsh, the man who, along with Senator Button, has periodically raised the bogy of International Monetary Fund intervention and warned the country appropriately that we could be in very serious trouble beyond that with which we are confronted at the moment. After all, it was Senator Walsh who last year, a week after the Budget, told us that we were on the road to Argentina. We are not there yet, but he was on the right track. Even Senator Walsh seems to be going to water. Last week at the Australian Statistics Advisory Council economic forecasting conference in Sydney he was reported as saying that he could see the need to ease up on the expenditure reduction task. Had he been got at by his opinion poll watching mates in the Cabinet? I cannot believe that slasher Walsh, as he became known when he cried for more attacks on government expenditure, could really be advocating such a course.

SPEECH.PARA: When Mr Greiner becomes Premier of New South Wales, as unquestionably he will next Saturday, I trust that the Government will be prepared to knuckle down to the needed adjustment task. The Australian economy is extremely vulnerable to exogenous shocks from the world market place. We not only have a net foreign debt that has nearly quadrupled to almost $87 billion net since this Government came to office; we are plagued by persistently high unemployment. The unemployment rate now sits at around 8 per cent, with youth unemployment at a saddening 20 per cent. Inflation is running at around 7 per cent, more than double that of our major trading competitors. A weak economy such as this puts us right in the middle of the debt crisis.

The Government is content to sit around until May, when we will have yet another May statement, to give us in a mini-Budget what it should have provided in the Budget in September last year. It will be a very interesting May statement. At the moment this Government is raking in enormous amounts of additional revenue. This Treasurer is awash with funds. There is no question that without any policy changes the surplus will be over $1 billion for the current financial year. One can project a surplus, without any change at all, of $3 billion or more in the 1988-89 Budget because of the amount the Government is taking and sucking out from pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers, in particular.

This morning on a similar subject there was an interjection that the fringe benefits tax (FBT) had brought in considerable sums. It has, but they are small beer in the total take compared to what ordinary Australian average weekly earners, paying enormous rates and moving up into ever higher tax brackets, are bringing in. This morning I was talking about the effect of tax creep. One of my colleagues thought I meant the Treasurer. I actually meant the way in which the system works. I must, more accurately, use the phrase `bracket creep' instead of `tax creep' in future.

Honourable members should not assume that all this revenue-indeed, quite the reverse-makes for a sound economy. What it really means is a government continually bludgeoning the ordinary Australian with increased tax. This revenue is not from so-called broad-based measures, such as the fringe benefits tax, as I mentioned and as the Treasurer himself so glibly informs us. Even if the FBT increases somewhat beyond the Budget time estimates, it will represent only around $800m. As I was indicating, it compares with PAYE collections of around $30,000m. It is there that we find the revenue increase, the bracket creep.

The Government should use the mini-Budget to provide tax relief. It can do this and, at the same time, provide expenditure cuts which will provide for a Budget surplus. That Budget surplus is undoubtedly needed. It is the best way to start paying off the large accumulated public sector debt in this country. We should also see in the mini-Budget what was to be the great mark of the third term of the Hawke Government-so-called micro-economic reform. Micro-economic reform is not a phrase, however, we have heard much from the Government in recent months, even though it was supposed to be the main policy focus of the Hawke-Keating Government's third term.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not micro, it is microscopic.

—It is certainly microscopic now. It was to be the substantial task of this third Hawke Government. We have had rhetoric but little action. On privatisation Government members are all over the place. Do honourable members really think that they will deregulate the labour market? Forget it. We will wait and see what they do in terms of protection. In terms of the protective level for the textile, clothing and footwear industries I note that by 1996 there will still be a level of 60 per cent protection. Great micro-economic reform!

SPEECH.PARA: Words are fine, but where is the action? All the aspects I have just mentioned are crucial to strengthening the economy. The reason we are having a mini-Budget is the Government's belated recognition of the effects of the share market crash on the world economy. With the world economy ridden with debt, the stock market crash could have enormous consequences. Two major catalysts that exacerbated the already serious Third World debt crisis during the early 1980s were high interest rates and low commodity prices, both factors that also affect Australia. Uncertainty abounds.

The balance of payments figure came out yesterday. The Treasurer goes to a Press conference and says, `I have done it all. Here it is. Australia is leading the way. I am in charge'. Honourable members will note the heavy use of the first personal pronoun throughout the Press conference, with the Treasurer taking credit for it all. The reality is that the only reason there is an alleged improvement in the balance of payments-I say `alleged' because there was still a deficit of $737m added to our debt once again for the month--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is $25m every day.

—I am indebted to Professor Edwards, a noted economic analyst and commentator. If one is able to go to a Press conference and claim that one is bringing around a significant recovery when one is adding $737m to the country's debt per month one is putting oneself into the basket case of analysts around the world, let alone the basket case economies around the world. The Treasurer claims that he has brought about a recovery when all that has happened is that commodity prices have gone up worldwide and, as a result, a country such as ours is the recipient of much greater funds.

SPEECH.PARA: But what has happened domestically? Where are the attacks on the structural weaknesses within the economy? There are none at all. Where are the incentives for people to invest and work more, such as reductions in taxation? Quite the reverse is the case. The Treasurer claims that we are in an allegedly favourable position because international markets are paying more for our commodities and because the Government is earning more by way of the revenue it is soaking from Australian taxpayers. If the Treasurer alleges that that is good economic management, I will give a garden party.

Last year we heard that the responsibility for the poor state of the economy was the poor terms of trade. Now the terms of trade are turning around and we are getting better prices for our products, but we are still judged to be one of the most vulnerable economies in the world. Why?

Because the Government did not force the pace of adjustment in the face of these external imbalances last year we have wasted nearly a year. In the May statement allegedly we are going to get what should have been done last September. In fact, I will lay tens on that after the New South Wales election the pressure from members of the Left will be exerted on the Government not to cut expenditure. That is why slasher, Senator Walsh, is going quiet on expenditure cuts now because he knows the Left will not let him get away with it. The pressure will come on the Government not to privatise, not to move with further micro-economic reform and not to get government expenditure down. Members of the Left found out that this Treasurer has a vast reservoir of revenue and they will put it on him to use that revenue to prop up all sorts of institutions such as the one we were debating this morning-Australian Airlines-and the like. I mention that because the debt problem facing Australia is massive. If we do not face up to our huge and growing foreign debt and to the current accounts deficits that we have, we will move inexorably further into the line of basket cases that I was referring to earlier on.

We are still a contributor to the World Bank. I would be the last to forecast that we might have to ask it for assistance down the line, but the reality is that we are aligned economically on so many comparisons with so many of the debt ridden Third World countries which exist on capital improvement programs and the like and capital works within their countries as a consequence of moneys paid by the Reserve Bank of Australia. If honourable members think it is going to get better because the man masquerading as an effective Treasurer tells them that he is doing a good job, let me throw in one other scenario. Before the end of this year, the United States of America will elect a new President. He will come in early next year with a great deal of goodwill throughout the country. If he does not want to be a one term President he will need to address the structural problems within the United States as well-similar problems, but not of as great a magnitude as the problems that we have in Australia. He will have to move fast. Unquestionably that will have a somewhat recessionary effect within the United States. Honourable members know the effect it will have on countries such as ours: as we get more depression in commodity prices-all we have had is trumped up rhetoric from the would-be replacement of casino Bob-we will be in a more exacerbated situation than we are today. The duty is profound.

I have introduced this element not only because the indices take us into a comparison but because if we are talking about what this nation can do for the World Bank, what we ought to do, and what I fought for in my years in the Parliament, we will not be in the same position to be able to do it down the line if we allow negligence and mere fear of factions to prevent our taking the measures that have to be implemented to address the structural imbalances in this country. I do not want my country to get into a worse situation than it is in now. I do not want my country to be in a situation where it cannot fund projects and make share allotments to the World Bank. I want to be able to do that. I want us to return to a situation where we hardly have to turn a hair to increase our contributions to the World Bank. But the scenario I paint is one that has plausibility and reality to it. I think we are staring it in the face. The measures the United States will have to adopt will have these sorts of implications for the world economy in 1989.

A further possible scenario could be that following the stock market crash in the shorter term United States interest rates could increase in order to support the United States dollar and fund that country's trade deficit; that is to say because the now weaker United States stock market will attract less foreign investment at a given exchange rate, higher interest rates will be necessary to attract money into the United States bond markets to fund its deficit. This would then translate through various transmission mechanisms to contribute to a dampening effect on world economic growth.

Australia's economic future is undoubtedly in the balance. We need to strengthen the economy now. The Government should be aiming at real structural change through deregulation and reducing the burden on taxpayers. The Government talks about so-called revenue neutral tax changes in the mini-Budget. All that really means is burden neutral. There must be a quickening in the pace of economic adjustment so that we can avoid going further down the Third World path and avoid ever needing to rely on World Bank development assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the somewhat rambling remarks of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) he made a number of comments that I, in turn, would like very briefly to comment on. It was very good to see his concern about the Third World debt crisis, but he tended to lay the blame for that on the developing countries. While it is true that they did borrow the funds, part of the blame therefore rests with them, but part of the blame must also rest with the banks that lent them the money and also with the change in the whole global economic scene since those loans were made. As the honourable member suggested, it is simply not possible for those developing countries to adjust when there has been a massive decline in commodity prices and when their terms of trade turned against them so much. No matter how hard they try to increase their export earnings they are not able to. Numbers of those countries have gone through a process of major structural adjustment. They have increased the volume of their exports only to have the value of their exports stagnate as a result of the decline in the prices that they receive for their exports.

SPEECH.PARA: The change in the economic climate is at least as much to blame for the problems that they now have as those countries must carry themselves. It is also extremely difficult for them to adjust when they have got massive interest payment and repayment problems. Some of those countries are having to pay up to 50 per cent of their export earnings simply on the interest on their debts. When there is such a drain on their export earnings through such debt servicing, it makes it impossible for them to import even the machinery, other kinds of equipment, fuel and so on that is needed for the sort of restructuring that they have to go through. They are in a terrible bind. I will return to this matter in a minute because there are numbers of policies that Western countries could adopt which would assist in the structural adjustment that they have to go through.

The honourable member for Kooyong also made some comments on Australian debt which were not strictly relevant to the subject of the debate at all, but there are some similarities and so it was not worth calling a point of order. The similarities are that Australia is suffering from the same kinds of problems as developing countries because of the collapse in commodity prices. We have had the experience of a sharp deterioration of our terms of trade which has caused us a severe current account deficit. But our situation is very strikingly different because we still have a high credit rating. The surplus countries and the banks in those countries are still willing to lend us all the money we need to cover that current account deficit and, most important of all, we have in place an active, effective adjustment program. We have devalued substantially and that is the most important part of the short term adjustment; we have reduced real unit labour costs; we have reduced our interest rates, which is a great encouragement to new investment; we are going through a process of industrial diversification; and imports are being restrained by a relatively restrained fiscal and monetary policy.

We have a very effective adjustment process under way. That will not work miracles overnight. We are going through a process that will take many years. It would be foolish to pretend, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Kooyong, did, that that adjustment could take place overnight. It will be a difficult and prolonged task to which all Australians will have to contribute. The honourable member suggested that the Government should be restraining fiscal policy even more. If we did that there would be a real danger of cutting off our nose to spite our face, of cutting off the outlays that are needed to make the structural adjustment possible. If we reduced outlays even further we would have to cut public investment, for example, which is absolutely essential to building up the productivity of the economy and increasing our export competitiveness. It simply does not make sense to cut back outlays when the consequence would be a reduction in our long term growth rates. Spending on public investment is not the only form of public outlay that does that. Outlays on education, research and a host of other activities are also very important.

The Deputy Leader of the Opposition suggested that Government debt was a high priority. Perhaps he does not know the facts. The fact is that Government debt in Australia is the second lowest of any Western country. We have the second lowest level of government debt of any industrialised capitalist country in the world. Reduction in government debt, while it would be nice if it were possible, is not a high priority here in the same way as it is in other countries such as New Zealand. Much higher priorities are the reduction of our current account deficit and the reduction of unemployment, both of which are being achieved, and the evidence of the last few months is very encouraging.

I should like to get back to the real subject of this debate, which is the share increase for the World Bank. The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill authorises a small increase in Australia's share in the World Bank. In June 1986 Australia had 12,700 shares in the World Bank. This Bill authorises the purchase of an additional 178 shares of the capital stock of the bank. It is part of a small increase which was proposed in 1984 and adopted in May 1986. Many countries are making small increases in their shares. The importance of this proposal is that it allows the bank to increase its shareholders' equity and that increases the amount it can borrow and so the amount it can lend to developing countries. It would be impossible to argue convincingly against this proposal.

The purpose of the World Bank has been to contribute to longer term development in the Third World; in other words, to promote growth in poor countries. The World Bank, unfortunately, is not quite a world bank in fact because the Soviet Union and several other eastern European countries are not members. It was good to see recently that the United States Administration is thinking of supporting the communist countries in becoming members of the international financial institutions-not only the World Bank but also the International Monetary Fund and other international institutions. This is important for more effective coordination of the global economy. I hope that Australia will also support that proposal when it gets to the councils of the bank. The World Bank now has about 150 member countries. It principally lends to the poor among those countries, disbursing the cash either to governments or to private sector groups undertaking projects guaranteed by governments.

The World Bank is the largest single source of lending for developing countries, and last year lent $14 billion to about 130 projects in its 1987 financial year. It has a subscribed capital of $85 billion and the Bill we are discussing today will make a small contribution to increasing that. The most recent development in the bank is the discussion that took place in February about a proposal to increase massively the shareholders' capital in the bank by about $75 billion, which would nearly double the bank's capital base. This would enable the bank to undertake a major increase in lending in the 1990s. It is important to note that an increase in capital does not have to be paid in entirely by the shareholders. They would be required in this case to pay only 3 per cent of their subscriptions in comparison with the 7 1/2 per cent normally required at present, while guaranteeing availability of the rest. The next step in the process of increasing the capital will be the debate about the increase in the parliaments and governments of member countries. Australia will no doubt be debating a Bill of this kind in due course. It would be useful if the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would comment on this proposed increase in his reply at the end of this debate. The most recent proposed increase in the World Bank's capital should be strongly supported by anyone concerned about development within Third World countries.

During the 1980s there has been a terrible depression in much of the developing world. Whilst industrialised countries went through a recession in the early years of the 1980s, most developing countries have experienced a depression as severe as that in industrialised countries in the 1930s. Living standards throughout Africa and Latin America and in several already severely impoverished Asian countries have been decimated by the combined effects of plummeting commodity prices, grinding debt burdens, natural calamities such as drought through much of Africa and earthquakes in Mexico, and the failure of aid or lending from the richer countries to increase. The consequences have been growing malnutrition, rising infant mortality rates, growing unemployment, deterioration in the extent and quality of health and education services, and so the reversal of trends towards gradual improvement that had been evident during the previous three decades from the 1950s to the end of the 1970s.

Few people in Australia know of the severity of the human problems this has caused. Most of us are familiar with the television pictures of starving mothers and children in Ethiopia, and there has been much generous support for non-government attempts to raise funds to deal with the catastrophe of drought in Ethiopia; but there has not been an adequate response by Western governments generally to the enormity of this human tragedy.

The World Bank does make a useful contribution to the process of development within the Third World. The International Development Association (IDA) in particular which is the low concessional lending arm of the World Bank makes an important contribution. Low income countries receive assistance on terms they can afford, mainly from the IDA and to some extent also from United Nations agencies and bilateral donors, but there are special reasons for wishing to ensure the continued strength of the IDA. Because of its size the World Bank group has become the main focus for development policy discussions between aid giver and recipient. It also helps to co-ordinate a policy among all donors for a number of countries through aid consortia and consultative groups. Because it is relatively free from the foreign policy and commercial pressures which surround national bilateral aid programs, the IDA can give primacy to development criteria in aid allocation in terms of both the nature of its projects and the countries to which it lends. Eighty-one per cent of its lending goes to low income countries and a further 17 per cent to countries with per capita incomes just above the low income boundary. So it is vital that the funds of the IDA be increased.

I do not think there can be any doubts about the value of the contribution to economic development made by lending from the World Bank. It is absolutely essential for developing countries to obtain funds for major infrastructure projects, for agriculture, for health and education, for transport and communications, and for water and power. The World Bank has a fine record of contributing to well planned and prepared projects in these areas. However, it is certainly not above criticism in a number of ways. For example, it is certainly also true that there is quite legitimate cause for criticism about the environmental impact of some World Bank projects. There can be no doubt that some projects have involved environmental destruction which is unnecessary and better planning could have resulted in more effective conservation.

There is absolutely no doubt that the bank has been far too strongly under the influence of the United States Administration. It is true that, during the McNamara years, the concentration on the alleviation of poverty and on basic human needs was a refreshing development of the bank's orientation and this was criticised by the Nixon Administration. However, under the presidencies of Claussen and Conable, Reagan Administration appointees, the bank has become far more acquiescent in the extremely reactionary and in many ways economically irresponsible policies of that Administration. There is certainly far too much acquiescence in the United States Government's policies within the bank. For example, the history of World Bank loans, far from indicating a single minded commitment to economic considerations, reveals a pattern of lending that casts serious doubt on the institution's supposed non-political character.

A look at the major recipients of World Bank funds, as well as at those repeatedly denied access to its resources over recent years, makes it clear that politics are at least as important as economics in shaping decisions. A number of the most mismanaged and corrupt economies in the Third World, such as the Philippines under the Marcos regime, Zaire, El Salvador, Turkey and Chile, have been amongst the largest recipients of bank loans. These loans show that it has been the bank's own biases which have contributed to supportive loans. Those countries which have been prepared to pursue the bank's own development model have received large loans. That model has been based on low wage labour, a reducing place for public intervention, a central role for foreign investment, and a quite naive and simplistic approach to so-called free markets which neglects the fact that most markets are severely distorted and experience market failure. Amongst the reforms of bank policies for which concerned people in the rest of the world should be working is reconsideration of those doctrinaire policies.

It is important that the World Bank adopt policies which are both better informed and more sympathetic to the existing economic, social and political structures of developing countries, as well as policies which show greater imagination about ways of improving both the efficiency and equity of those economies. Many other reforms of the bank are also required. One of the most obvious would be to change the capital borrowing ratio. The previous speaker mentioned that the gearing ratio of the bank is 1 : 1. There cannot be any other major bank in the world which has such a conservative gearing ratio. Many responsible financial experts have been critical of this extremely conservative policy, and it is suggested that at the very least the gearing ratio should be changed to 1 : 2. Even that would be very conservative in comparison with many commercial banks which have a gearing ratio, in some cases, of 1 : 20 or more. That proposal has been criticised by some. The bank was advised by some financial experts in 1982 that, given the shakiness of financial markets, the solidity of the bank's financing should not be disturbed by changing the gearing ratio. Another objection has been that existing World Bank bonds have been issued on the basis of 1 : 1 capital backing and would be affected by change in the gearing ratio.

Neither of those objections is insuperable. Many bankers would not agree with the first and would welcome a larger role for the bank created by changing the gearing ratio to 1 : 2, and the second objection is simply a legal technicality which can be overcome. It is therefore important that the bank's gearing ratio be changed to 1 : 2, and I hope that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who will be responding to this debate, will comment on the Australian Government's attitude to the proposal that the bank's gearing ratio be doubled. A number of other Western countries have supported this proposal, and it is important that the Australian Government do so also, for this would release substantially increased funds for on-lending to developing countries where they are desperately needed.

There is one major problem that is retarding development and to the resolution of which the World Bank could make a major contribution, and that is Third World debt, as the previous speaker commented.
