Given the shortness of time, I would like to draw attention not to the seriousness of that problem, because that is quite clear, but to one or two proposals for reform which should be seriously considered. The Australian Council for Overseas Aid has recently published a book on Australia and the global debt crisis entitled Life after Debt. The book discusses both Third World and Australian debt and the policies Australia might advocate to resolve the crisis. The hesitant efforts at reforms since the crisis began in 1982 have not even stopped further deterioration. Policies so far have concentrated on new lending, rescheduling debt servicing by delaying repayments or lowering interest payments, and debt conversion involving exchanging foreign debts for domestic assets such as equities, securities or even conservation measures.

A number of proposals have been made more recently which could also be important, but the one that I would like to concentrate on, because it seems to offer the best possibility for change, is the idea of establishing a debt management authority. Senator Sarbanes, Chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee, has proposed such an authority, and the idea was approved by the United States of America House Banking Committee, and has been included in the omnibus Trade Bill, which is currently being negotiated. The multilateral debt management authority could borrow funds from surplus countries to buy debt at a discount. Already billions of dollars of Third World debt are being traded in Wall Street at a discount on its nominal value. Such a debt management authority could be established under the International Monetary Fund (IMF) or the World Bank. Substantial funding would be required. A paid in capital subscription of, say, $US3 billion, plus guarantees totalling $US27 billion, would provide total capital of $US30 billion. Subscriptions could be expected to be in proportion to normal IMF or World Bank contributions. A gearing ratio of 10 : 1 would allow the authority to raise $US300 billion from the international financial markets by selling bonds, mainly no doubt to current account surplus countries. If debts were purchased at an average discount on their nominal value of about 30 per cent, about $450 billion of Third World debt could be restructured over a number of years. Debtor countries would benefit through reduced debts and interest rates. Creditor banks would lose part of their assets, but they no longer expect them to be fully repaid. However, they would benefit through renewed liquidity. The United States-Mexican agreement announced on 30 December accepts the principle of sale of debt at substantial discount on its nominal value.

Australia could have an important role in resolving the debt crisis. We have the financial expertise to produce and evaluate practical proposals such as this, through the representation of our executive directors at the IMF and the World Bank. Australia's leadership of the Cairns Group and our strengthened role in international disarmament negotiations are clear indications of our capacity to use our limited influence in international forums effectively. I hope we will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) said in his very thoughtful and concerned speech, we are debating the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill which seeks to obtain the approval of the Parliament for Australia to take up an increase in its capital subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. I take this opportunity to comment on Australia's development assistance program generally to the poor or developing countries of the world. Unfortunately, this program has taken something of a beating under the Hawke Government. Thus the projected total of development assistance for 1987-88 amounts to $1,007.6m. Whilst this represents a small increase in money terms compared to last year, it is actually less than it was for 1985-86, two years back, when the figure was $1,031m. So the cumulative reduction in real terms, that is, corrected for inflation, since 1985 amounts to more than 20 per cent. There have been few, if any, other expenditure cuts of that order. I believe that is an indication of the Government's commitment-or lack of commitment-to this important issue of economic development of the developing countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Mind, I do not suggest that the Government has not got to get on with the job of cutting back expenditure generally, given Australia's vast balance of payments deficit and our frightening overseas debt of about $110 billion. It is not, as the honourable member for Fraser has suggested, of any consequence how much of that is government or private debt. It is the total that is important. In these circumstances it is imperative that, along with other key policy thrusts, such as freeing up our labour market and getting inflation and costs down to levels comparable with those of our major trading partners, these matters are considered very urgently indeed. We are in a very dependent, very vulnerable situation-and we will have to look out when the United States of America (USA) begins really taking on the task of getting its budget and trade deficit down, as my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), stated.

The present level of Australia's development assistance represents 0.36 per cent of gross domestic product. It is the lowest for 20 years, if not ever, for this country. It was 0.5 per cent in 1983 and 1984 and it all but touched 0.6 per cent in the late 1960s. Looked at in this way, there has been a serious deterioration in the Australian development assistance effort. As is well known, the target figure of the United Nations is 0.7 per cent, and Australia is committed to achieving that figure, but we have a long way to go. However, the average figure for the developing countries in 1986 was about the same as our figure, 0.36 per cent. There has been a worldwide declining trend in capital flows and development assistance to the poor and developing countries over the past five years. I doubt whether Western governments will ever really recapture the generosity of past decades. This decline in development assistance is associated with the horrendous Third World debt issue which previous speakers have referred to and it is a very significant factor contributing to the imbalance and difficulties in the world economy. It goes along with the United States budget and trade deficits we hear so much about, the falling US dollar, the German and Japanese trade surpluses, the greatly appreciated Deutsche mark and yen, the adverse effect of European and Japanese farm protection and so on.

Of even more concern are the figures for the final net annual financial resource transfers from the developed, the rich, countries to the developing and poor countries. These are not easy to come by, but one estimate is that whereas in the three years prior to the Mexican debt crisis in 1982 the 18 major developing countries received an annual net transfer in the order of $US40 billion, in the years since then there has been a net reverse flow from the poor countries to the developed and advanced countries at an average of $25 billion to $30 billion. Does the House understand that? In the event there has been a flow from the poor to the rich. That means that the developing world is about $70 billion a year worse off, measured in terms of control over resources, than it was four years ago. Apart from the direct impact of that on developing countries, it has to be a major constraint on world growth.

Without going further into the complexities of these matters, the plight of the developing countries, which contain nearly four-fifths of the world's population, is a matter of urgent and important concern to everyone. To assist them is a matter of humanitarian concern-the starting point is the injunction of Christ that `of those to whom much is given much will be expected.' It is also, however, important to the preservation of world peace. And recognising the great mutual interdependence of the developed and developing world, it is further in our straight-out long term economic self-interest to undertake a significant development assistance program. That involves, on a world scale and in our own case, addressing the $1,000 billion debt overhang of the developing countries, as well as increasing aid and development assistance, increasing trade opportunities including freeing up farm trade, and, very importantly, encouraging the right policies in the developing countries.

When I refer to the right policies I mean much reduced regulation and controls in those economies-in short, freer markets; I refer to a sound overall economic policy including an appropriate exchange rate, not an overvalued exchange rate; I refer to an outward-oriented trade policy; and finally a favourable commercial environment for foreign companies and investors. It is very important, as my colleague the Deputy Leader of the Opposition stated, to encourage restructuring and an effective economic policy in the recipient countries; that is good for both local economic growth and for maximising the benefits of such development assistance as a country receives.
Turning to the World Bank itself, which was established in 1947, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) said in his speech:
The IBRD is an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries, and it plays an important role in the South East Asian region.
He went on:

Projects financed covered all the major sectors of economic development with an emphasis on infrastructure facilities in the transport and communications, industry and energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply. The World Bank and its soft loan arm, the International Development Association (IDA), have a comprehensive and systematic project evaluation system which shows that most bank and IDA projects-85 per cent of those evaluated in 1986, for instance-achieve all or most of their objectives. The estimated average return on projects evaluated in calendar years 1985 and 1986, measured by the flow of net economic benefits over time, was 14.8 per cent.

That is a fairly encouraging account of the activities of the World Bank-but I am not sure it is as clear cut as that. The bank, in what one commentator has referred to as `an extraordinary act of self-indictment' early last year, has itself said, in a largely internal report on how the bank might be re-organised, that it had failed to `chart a clear institutional strategy through difficult times'; that it had failed to provide `intellectual leadership in the debt crisis'; that it had become `soft' in its internal management and had generally `not measured up to its mission'. In the light of those findings by that committee of investigation the then newly appointed President, Mr Barber Conable, set about a process of radical reshaping and re-organising of the bank. How far that self-criticism is justified and just how far the institution has been, or will be, changed is difficult to say. What is clear is that the hitherto major and traditional emphasis on project lending-building roads, dams, steel mills, and so on-will increasingly give way to so-called policy-based lending. That means, in a word, telling developing countries how to organise their economies in return for loans. That is tied in with the increasing emphasis on so-called SALs-structural adjustment loans-which can finance anything from specific physical investment, rationalisation and adjustment programs, to a general budget deficit. It is the reform of economic policy in the direction I referred to a moment ago-less regulation and freer markets, sound overall macro-economic policy, outer-oriented trade policy, including an appropriate exchange rate, and a welcoming commercial environment for foreign investors-which in that context is to be the price of receiving loans. That is the price of the money.

I would say that if that can be done effectively then it is a highly desirable thrust of International Bank for Reconstruction and Development policy. Of course, there would still be plenty of scope for the traditional project type lending. After all, a country could have the best economic policies in the world, but, as Mr Conable pointed out in an interview, if it does not have a functioning road system, an adequate education system or a communications process, it will not achieve much economic growth.

It is suggested also that tied in with the role of policy-based lending would be a role as co-ordinator of private lending. Certainly the bank, other development institutions and governments should be much more active in the role of catalyst in promoting private lending and private initiative in development assistance activity than they have been. I have already touched on one major aspect of that when I referred to the right policies to encourage direct investment from rich countries' multinationals, fund managers and so on. Another aspect is the work of the non-government organisations (NGOs) in the development assistance field. We are all familiar with organisations such as World Vision, Freedom from Hunger, and so on. These are based in Western developed countries. Of course, there are also NGOs in the developing countries which may increasingly become the channels for effective development work supported by Western funding and also, in time, their own.

I have knowledge of one such non-government organisation in the Philippines. It has been sponsored and nurtured by the Maranatha Trust of Sydney, which is recognised worldwide as among the most effective and professional of NGOs. The founder and executive director is Mr David Bussau. I have the privilege of serving as Chairman of its Overseas Aid Committee. The non-government organisation that I refer to, based in Manila, the Philippines, is Tulay Sa Pag-Unlad Inc. (TSPI), a Filipino Christian development organisation which is now in its fifth year of the highly successful fostering of small enterprise development for job and income generation. It does this through the provision of credit and training in small business management skills. In this connection I remark in passing that one criticism of World Bank activities made by James Bovard, in his interesting paper entitled The World Bank Vs. The World's Poor, published by the Cato Institute in Washington, was:
The majority of small-enterprise borrowers from IBRD-financed development finance companies (DFCs) are in arrears in their debt repayments.

In contrast, TSPI, with its indigenous roots and stress on responsibility and accountability, regularly reports repayment collection rates of the order of 90 per cent. I suggest to the House that this Philippines development organisation, TSPI, is something of a model for grass roots development assistance.

I have referred to this organisation at some length because I am aware that TSPI made an application, put forward a proposal to the Australian Government, to participate in the so-called Philippines Australia community assistance program (PACAP) announced last year. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), responding to a request for assistance from the new President of the Philippines, Corazon Aquino, said:

A new program of Community Assistance for the Philippines will aim to create employment opportunities and generate incomes in rural areas in the Philippines. Funds will be provided to the Church and Non-Government groups in the Philippines to assist small scale development and welfare projects and small and micro-enterprise development.

The TSPI request was for a grant of 118.3 million pesos, about $US6m, over six years for a program designed to generate 60,390 jobs in 20,200 businesses with the number of beneficiaries totalling 483,600. Those figures work out at about $US100 a job. I notice that some of the jobs promoted by the World Bank come out at a cost of about $US500,000! I am stressing the efficiency and effectiveness of this type of on the ground work. With the professionalism, integrity, and proven track record of TSPI, one would have few doubts that these outcomes will be achieved. Yet to my knowledge the proposal has not won support within PACAP. If that is correct, I should very much like to know what local NGOs and programs have in fact attracted support, bearing in mind the objective enunciated by the Prime Minister to which I have just referred.

In conclusion, I wish to refer briefly to reports that the Hawke Government is considering the abolition of tax deductibility for donations to charitable and other community organisations, which would include the various Australian non-government organisations I have referred to. This concern arises in part from the decision of the New Zealand Government to abolish such deductibility, which in that country takes the form of a charitable donation rebate, from 1 April 1988. Last week the National Trust issued a Press release drawing attention to these reports, strongly stating that it expressed alarm at suggestions that among taxation measures being considered by the Treasury and the Government was the abolition of tax deductibility for donations to all charitable and other community organisations. The National Trust pointed out, as I would point out, that this surely would be a backward step when, as I have been contending, it is desirable that, increasingly, private effort in the development area should replace public effort. At the grass roots in particular, as the TSPI case amply illustrates, the private sector can do a better job with more efficiency and less bureaucracy, as well as with more compassion, I believe, and is able to foster more meaningful involvement and interest on the part of individuals and private corporations. I urge the Government to think long and carefully before it seeks to follow the New Zealand example in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I follow the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) in economic debates. Usually he follows me and has me at the disadvantage that he can attempt, at least, to pull some of the threads of my arguments to pieces. However, I make this observation of the honourable member: I find him one of the more reasonable debaters in this House on matters economic; certainly he is one of the less angry members. Because of that, I believe, he warrants more listening to than other members on that side of the House. However, the honourable member for Berowra has debased some of his arguments somewhat today by falling for the trap of accepting the invitation of his leaders to join in spreading the gloom and doom feeling about Australia's economic standing in the world.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two matters for which the Opposition so much likes to castigate the Government, without any analysis. At least, Opposition members feel there is a soft underbelly there, in that they believe that the public, without little knowledge of this rather complex subject matter of economics, will swallow some of their lines. The first matter is our foreign debt; the second is the problem we have with our current account deficit. I remind the honourable member for Berowra that, although Australia's foreign debt might well stand at in excess of $100 billion, we should also recognise-as the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) pointed out-that the Government component of the foreign debt is the second lowest of the government component of the foreign debt of any comparable country. We should realise also that, as a percentage of the gross domestic product, our foreign debt is actually falling and is nowhere near the catastrophic levels of 30 per cent and 40 per cent during the Great Depression of the 1920s and 1930s. Yet the Opposition would have the public believe that we are on the very precipice, the verge, of yet another world depression, or certainly an Australian economic depression.

The honourable member for Berowra did admit, however, that the foreign debt was made up of both public and private components, but not once did he suggest ways of curbing or winding back our foreign debt. This Government has put its mind and its energy towards winding back at least that part of the foreign debt for which it is primarily responsible; that is, the public debt. The Government has done this by having the public accept that we do have to lower our standard of living in this nation. We cannot continue to spend at the rate we have been spending. We have analysed the reasons for the mounting debts. For instance, we recognise that the terms of trade have been disadvantageous to Australia. If Australia had purely free trade, particularly in commodity prices-which it does not-we would see that the particular commodities that we produce have been enjoying-or not enjoying-very bad terms of trade. However, they are on the reverse. We now find far better prices for our wool and wheat, and people in the Wimmera where I was born are feeling a little more comfortable about farm incomes at the moment because of the wheat and sheep that predominate production in that area.

Correspondingly, the devaluation of the Australian dollar has largely increased the size of our foreign debt. Although there might be an argument as to the correct level of devaluation, we no longer have a managed float and we no longer manage the currency in this country, but probably we have one of the cleanest floats in the world. If we were to manage it and to listen to the National Farmers Federation, the Australian dollar would be wound back even further to about 40c American. That would more than double our foreign debt. But we do not hear the two sides of the argument. It brings out the complexity of managing international trade and foreign debt. Whatever one does to manage foreign debt by curbing imports, by expanding exports and by currency controls, it is a two-edged sword. One is in a bind. Because of that one has to move carefully, slowly and have a ratchet effect of improvement. For instance, if we were to have a lower dollar, our imports would vastly increase in price. We need those imports, in the same way that the developing countries need them, to increase our technological base. We need the machinery, which we do not produce here, and we need the technology so that we can increase our manufacturing and our value-added components of production and, in turn, rely less on our commodity export income. On the other hand, a devalued dollar would increase the attractiveness of our exports. One can see from that example that whatever one does, one is in a double bind. If one improves one side of the equation, one necessarily disadvantages the other side of the equation. Heaven help us, the developing countries are in a far worse situation, with fewer opportunities for dramatic improvement than Australia. However we must ensure that the balance in the equation is favourable to our own country.

We heard from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) some very comforting news in two successive months, possibly three months, of the movement in our current account. The deficit is going down. Yet despite that good news, despite the concern expressed by the Opposition, the gloom and doom, there have been no questions without notice to the Treasurer recently on those figures. Indeed, there has been no real economic contribution from the Opposition at all. The gloom and doom thesis is an attempt to try to delude or hoodwink the public, particularly with a New South Wales State election due at the weekend and a by-election coming up in South Australia, into thinking that, despite the Government's excellent record in relation to inflation, employment, interest rates and so on, somehow the enormous task of our international economic relationships overshadows all that and warrants a rejection of this Government. What we can be sure of is that in economic management this Treasurer, this Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), this front bench and the present Government, stand head and shoulders over not only the record of the Fraser Government but over any contribution by Opposition members.

To return to the Bill, it relates to the World Bank and to Australia taking up an increase in its capital subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The main task has been dealt with by other contributors to the debate. The main activity of the bank for the last 41 years has been in raising capital and lending it to developing countries. It is just like a domestic bank, but it is a bank on the international stage. The capital increases allow the bank to expand its borrowings on world capital markets and these borrowings largely finance the bank's activities. To be a partner or a shareholder in that bank, as the Treasurer has pointed out, it behoves us to take up the offer that is available to us in respect of extra shares.

The World Bank has been an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries, and plays a particularly important role in the area of our immediate neighbours to the north, that is South-East Asia. I shall turn shortly to one prime example which is often overlooked by honourable members, let alone by most Australians, and that is a country that is on the edge of South East Asia and yet part of it-Burma. To the end of June last year, the bank had lent about $US120 billion to its member countries. This money was largely borrowed from international financial markets. The cost to taxpayers in the member countries was only $US7.2 billion. That should be borne in mind when considering the cost, given the turnover of funds and the multiplier effect of borrowing on the world stage.

The projects themselves are most important. They emphasise infrastructure facilities in the transport and communication industry and energy sectors as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply. In this context I wish to refer to my visit to Burma last year. I went for the reason of visiting war cemeteries, but inevitably I took the opportunity to meet many government leaders on other matters, such as education and agriculture. I must put on record my thanks to our Ambassador, Mr Chris Lamb-no relation-who gave fantastic support in our meetings with the Burmese at decision-making levels. It was clear from our trip that education in that country is most important. I am not talking of education at the same level as that in this country, but at a level that we would take for granted-namely in the secondary level where the greatest effort must be put. It is of no use giving just a few Burmese the opportunity to study at universities throughout the world. Of course that is important, but one must not stop there. We must ensure that the ordinary men and women of Burma have the basic skills and knowledge in areas necessary at their level of development.

A visit to the Moulmein Technical School, not far from the Australian War Cemetery at Thanbyuzayat, indicated to us the poor level of equipment which those students have. The small amount of money necessary for Australia to contribute to upgrade teaching aids in that country in welding, carpentry, automotive engineering and metalwork was evident. Assistance is coming from Australia and from New Zealand. For instance, the Burmese are running out of industrial gases for welding. The tips of welding rods are missing. Some varying size spanners are missing-very small tools such as those that we have in our own backyards at home in the shed, yet because they are poor schools in Burma they are deprived of such items because they are unable to purchase or replace elementary equipment. I was approached by one of the service groups in Wagga which read a report of my visit to the technical school in Burma and which offered to take up that project. That was one of the non-government organisations mentioned by the honourable member for Berowra, which is very important in overseas aid. The group was going to take up the project involving $3,000 to re-equip some of the necessary but elementary equipment at that school. I visited the hospital in the area and I thought I was in an army field hospital without all the modern drugs.

Unless we understand that the aid we give them has to be utilised by people with an education at the subsistence level and with equipment at the subsistence level so they can build up the area of their agriculture in the first instance, our giving them equipment which should be of assistance does not even get us to first base. This is where the honourable member for Berowra is quite correct. He was critical of those lenders who put conditions on their lending to the developing countries. He pointed out that often loans are not made and equipment is not given unless these conditions are met.

Not only is a useful level of aid important to developing countries but also we must remind ourselves that the gifts and the aid are for the development of the recipient country, not ours. Yet if we examine the aid and the loans from donor countries we see that there are great multiplier effects at home in their economies, particularly if the material or the equipment is made and manufactured there and then exported in its finished state. There is then as much benefit to the donor country as to the country receiving the aid.

The way to overcome these conditions is to make sure we have less reliance on bilateral aid and more on multilateral aid, with more assistance through non-government organisations such as the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. It is more likely that here such aid will not be conditional. With aid through the World Bank, United Nations organisations and these non-government organisations such as the International Red Cross and others, we are more likely to have unconditional and more appropriate aid given to these countries.

In Burma the Australian Government is contributing over a number of years $20m for a main northern trunk road to increase infrastructure, including ground communications and transport. The reciprocal benefits to this country are immense because Burma recognises that Australia is a particular friend in the world scene. Burma, wrongly in my view, has closed itself off from the rest of the world. It has attempted to insulate itself from exploitation by the rest of the world by being totally self-reliant, and it has not worked. It is ready now to find a window into the rest of the world, without losing face and compromising its statute. The people of Burma see Australia as a special window into the rest of the world. They are fiercely non-aligned. They recognise that Australia is very independent and, although aligned in many ways with the United States and the rest of the Western world, they see us as ready to stand up to these big brothers, these big nations, and have our say.

The links between Burma and Australia go back to the 1940s, when many Australians lost their lives on the Burma Railway. Those links have been developed by people such as our Ambassador, Chris Lamb. While I was there I was asked to mention to this Parliament that Burma would like Australia to ask that it be invited to more world forums, such as the Inter-Parliamentary Union and world trade forums. They do not want to do it themselves because they believe they might lose face. That attitude is understandable once one gets a glimmer of understanding of the culture of Asian countries. So it is up to Australia not only to give more aid and to continue the aid we now give-$12m a year in the case of Burma-but also to develop more openness between the rest of the world and Burma. I point out to honourable members that Burma is a member of the World Bank and has been offered some 10 shares, and 6 shares in the second parcel, compared with Australia's 117 and 61 on the table, as set out in the explanatory memorandum provided by the Treasurer.

One other disappointing feature of our overseas aid, as the honourable member for Berowra pointed out, is that it is declining. He said it was 0.36 per cent of gross domestic product; I thought it was 0.39 per cent. Whatever it is, it is miserable. It should be well above that level. Our target in the first instance, as a member of the United Nations, is 0.7 per cent. Personally, I would like to see a target of one per cent. But people still contact me in my electorate office saying that charity begins at home. They ask why they, as pensioners, for example, should tighten their belts at home when we are still sending over $1 billion overseas in aid. They would like to cut back on that.

So I find there is an uneasy feeling in the community about overseas aid. Charity beginning at home really means that we must learn the value of charity. It does not mean we stop there; it means we must practise what we preach at home and abroad. I hope that that is what it really means. Unless we tackle the global problems of poverty, environment, defence and security, let alone the global problem of the nuclear power of the Western countries, which is now having its effects-since Chernobyl we are more educated about it-on developing countries, we will not get a global solution. Global solutions are necessary for global problems. I compliment the Australian Government for being more involved through the Development Bank. I compliment it, in particular, on its aid to Burma. I encourage it to increase it, and to revise upwards the total amount of our gross domestic product given in overseas aid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

Our largess and support in this case take the form of direct funding of specific and limited projects, so-called capital and contingent on-call commitments which can be, but not necessarily will be, called up at the discretion of the bank. The various affiliates are listed in a table I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.
