TALK.START.PARA: —While today we are dealing with a Bill which proposes to purchase for some $2.6m a further 178 shares in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), the relevance of the measure to the failings of its parent, the World Bank, is indisputable. The table helps to reveal that simple truth. The table also gives some idea of our total commitment to the IBRD as well as to kindred organisations in the World Bank stable.

SPEECH.PARA: First, let it be known that Australia's contributions to the IBRD and other international financial institutions-IFIs-when described as share capital are no such thing in any accepted sense of the term `share capital'. To so describe them is absolute nonsense. The so-called capital contributions or subscriptions yield no return, earn no interest, do not appreciate in value, or for that matter depreciate in value, and cannot be redeemed or cashed in or traded. These taxpayers' funds are nothing less than a donation to the new breed of international bureaucrats employed by the World Bank to play banker in a way not dissimilar to the way a gigantic game of monopoly might be played.

Furthermore, the roles of the IBRD and World Bank can be likened to a vast money laundering operation of a kind so much out of favour in private industry and of so much concern in matters criminal. The IBRD and kindred bodies launder money provided by contributing countries out of the revenues gathered from taxpayers in a way I hope to demonstrate. In our case, it is foreign aid being laundered and misrepresented as capital contributions to a high-sounding, misnamed group which pretends to be a banker but which behaves and conducts its affairs in ways not compatible with the conduct of a respectable bank. On top of that, as a debtor nation, sinking under the Hawke-Keating regime deeper into debt with every day that passes, Australia is in reality borrowing money so that we can give it away to others. That recipient countries cannot or do not choose to borrow from private banks and rely on the IBRD and other IFIs only adds to the insanity of that circumstance.

Because we are substantially in debt the Government, of course, must borrow some of its needs on world markets, in competition with the IBRD, so that we can give money back to the IBRD. What are we doing? We are heaping stupidity on insanity because our borrowed funding and guarantees given to the IBRD give the self-same IBRD a competitive edge and distort the markets in which we raise loans-to our considerable cost. Talk about a dog chasing its tail!

That is not the only example of canine capers. Australia, by way of this Bill, is about to chip in another $2.6m for the IBRD. I emphasise that that amount is in addition to the amount shown in the table that I have had incorporated in Hansard. The total amount paid will, therefore, be at least $196.8m over the years to 30 June 1991. I say that it will be at least $196.8m because of widely circulated reports that much more is likely to be required before that date. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) failed even to hint that this will not be the last payment in the foreseeable future. That is to be deplored in the strongest possible terms.

It is common knowledge that the World Bank in general, and the IBRD in particular, have announced that further major replenishments, totalling hundreds of millions of dollars, will be required. Given that that is so, surely it was incumbent on the Government not just to inform the Parliament, but to give us some idea of its intentions. Without the benefit of full and complete information from the Government we are left to question its motives for not giving the complete story about further funding for the IBRD in the near future.

The truth is that the IBRD is one of several sister organisations and, in itself, is an integral part of a relatively new bureaucratic empire. The impetus to expand its role has come from within the IBRD, with much more than moral support from the World Bank. Neither could be said to be objective, while each has more than a modicum of self-interest. This has been helped along by the ambitions of many national-including Australian-public servants who regard an international posting to the IBRD or World Bank as the pinnacle of their careers.

More important is the realisation that lending policies of the entire World Bank group have helped to sustain bad governments. Support for foreign government projects which have more to do with the stability of a regime than sound economic or business sense has made some recipient countries less efficient and has helped to prop up governments which have little or no regard for the rights of their citizens. By funding governments rather than businesses the IBRD and its World Bank cohort push out the more efficient private sector and private capital, thereby undermining any legitimate long term development goals. When granting loans to the governments of developing countries it is only because of the concessional nature of such loans that the money is gleefully accepted in preference to funding available from non-government sources. In fact, the World Bank is the first place to be approached for funding, even for attractive investment projects.

As well as the crowding out effects that I have mentioned, the sale of IBRD loans is declining. It is finding it harder to sell its loans on the private market despite a sometimes hard sell approach and very attractive terms. The level of loans sold by IBRD has declined from a peak of 30 per cent in the mid-1960s to about 10 per cent in the 1980s. When it comes to having a say that is commensurate with contributions, member nations have little control over lending policies which might clearly be contrary to the national interest of those countries which, although they provide most of the funds, do not have most of the votes. The United States Government has increasingly questioned and opposed some World Bank loans. There should be a lesson to be drawn from that.

Previously-the last occasion is recorded in the House of Representatives Hansard of 26 November 1987-I have objected strongly to Australia indirectly funding the military might of India in the way which was made possible by this Bill and previous Bills. It is one of those strange quirks born of self-interest that many private sector bankers actually support the efforts of the IBRD to alleviate Third World debt or bail out some countries to protect themselves from their own past folly. In effect, taxpayers of some countries with a large commitment support shareholders and banks which have simply made mistakes in their lending policies.

We should also note the changed emphasis of loans. The move from funding mines and factories-those generators of wealth-to lending money to build infrastructure, housing and even for education and the like, however desirable those projects might be, has wasted available resources. It has put the cart before the horse, because infrastructure does not in itself produce growth or lasting wealth. If mines or factories are producing, private sources will cater for the higher returns that are available to them in providing infrastructure.

It is interesting to record in passing that the World Bank has moved into International Monetary Fund territory by providing general purpose loans to fund, of all things, current account deficits in many recipient countries. That is not a very smart banking practice but it is one which Australia might be able to take advantage of if the Hawke-Keating regime continues to take us down this well-known Argentinean road. Changes in the policies of the IBRD and the World Bank over recent years have been a hindrance rather than a help in the form of constructive aid. By offering subsidies and removing or minimising the risks of failure, the emergence of strong private entrepreneurial sectors has been effectively undermined. This represents a betrayal of the original purposes of the group as spelt out in the respective charters of each.

Initially, the World Bank group was of modest dimensions and had gradual growth. Loans concentrated on specific productive investment and the facilitation of capital flows through guarantees. However, since about 1969 there has been an explosion of loans. As a matter of historical interest, the IBRD was created in 1945, along with the International Monetary Fund. Australia became a member of both of those bodies under the International Monetary Agreements Act 1947. The role of the IBRD then included assisting in postwar reconstruction, promoting private investment and, when finance was not available on reasonable terms, to be involved in finance and promoting growth, development, investment and trade. The noble origins of all of the IFIs have been overtaken.

There is a great deal of evidence that the World Bank has become a sponge, soaking up funds and disbursing them at the bidding of imprudent private American banks and self-serving Third World politicians. Although the bank often pleads its cause by saying that it acts to save the international economic system from collapse, the Third World debt problem worsens rather than improves. As far as being a force for the benefit and advancement of Third World economies and, more importantly, populations, the World Bank group is a failure-certainly, it has been in recent times. It surely does not create wealth and at best it aims only to transfer it around the globe these days. The end result is that it is less effective than bilateral aid programs arranged on a government to government basis.

It seems that the only good reason for the continued existence of the IBRD and kindred organisations is as a launderer of aid money that we provide. The Australian Government, by laundering aid which is sometimes paid out of money appropriated for the Treasury or sometimes for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, escapes the need to explain how the hundreds of millions of dollars dished out are used and which countries benefit. The World Bank volunteers as little public information as it can get away with. The governments of generous donor nations, including Australia, remain unaccountable. It is revealing that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), in his second reading speech-he delivered the speech, I might add, on behalf of the Treasurer-trotted out a standard list of the fallacies about the World Bank. It is very instructive to reflect on the difference between the attitudes of the Treasurer and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) towards funding World Bank agencies. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is on the record as recently as November of last year as signalling an intention to discontinue funding for the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) when the current funding period expires. That is to be applauded. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade demonstrated how his own careful assessment of the IFAD left him quite unimpressed with its performance. He acted accordingly, to his great credit.

I pose the question: Has a careful assessment been made by the Treasurer of the IBRD? I think not. Moreover, a careful assessment of other affiliates of the World Bank is long overdue. If the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, seriously seek to cut government expenditure, fertile ground exists in this area. An objective, careful consideration of the sums we throw into the begging bowl presented to us year after year by the World Bank offers a very fine opportunity to prune expenditure. If it is the wish of the government of the day to allocate all the money that might be saved to direct aid or to bilateral aid, so be it. It would at least get the credit for itself and for this country in the recipient countries. To those who defend the aid which IBRD and kindred institutions give because of the assistance it provides the Third World countries I can do no better than to quote James Bovard, who wrote in an analytical paper for the Cato Institute in the United States recently:

Providing these governments with another dollar for food aid allows them to spend the dollar they would have used to prevent starvation on hiring more bureaucrats or buying more weapons. In this sense, each additional dollar of aid is only as productive as the least useful recipient government's spending of its own money.
An examination of some of the policies and practices of World Bank recipient governments makes one doubt whether any amount of aid would allow these countries to become economically self sufficient.

It is not a question of accepting that and then saying, `We do nothing'. We have our own Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, which administers aid in this country. It could perhaps be developed at some small additional cost to deliver aid which we now subcontract out to the World Bank and its group. It surely can develop the expertise that is needed to deliver aid bilaterally, on a government-to-government basis, if necessary, although that does not necessarily have the desired long term effects to which we all aspire. To continue to engage others in the form of a bloated bureaucracy, which is the World Bank, is wasteful and, worse than that, is totally ineffective.

The careful consideration which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade gave to future funding for the IFAD should be applied to the other World Bank agencies which I have listed. I thoroughly recommend that such careful consideration start now and that the Government might deign to inform this Parliament of its outcome. We lack results. We rely on foreign information and material to debate these issues year after year in this House. It is simply not good enough. In the meantime it might not be a bad idea to think about freezing the bank's capital as far as our contribution is concerned. It also might not be a bad idea to insist upon the bank returning to its lending policies of the past, emphasising the private sector and productive activity. The bank might also look to ensuring a greater role for contributing nations in the scrutiny of where their funds go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather interesting in a debate like this to hear yet another point of view about the World Bank. There seems to be an extraordinary range of perceptions about the nature and orientation of this institution. The early impressions of the Nixon Administration perceived the World Bank as an arm of socialism in some way, shape or form, a viewpoint which, within relatively short order, was put to bed by a United States Treasury report on the World Bank, the conclusions of which were based on `the administration's basic policy preferences and priorities'. On the basis of those policy preferences and priorities, the report arrived at a very favourable evaluation of the World Bank's role. I quote from the report:

SPEECH.PARA: While bilateral aid better serves US short term political interests, multilateral assistance can provide a useful complement. For example, in Egypt, where political interests inhibit US ability to promote economic policy changes economic policy reforms have been fostered in part through the IBRD because of the recipient's perception of the impartiality of the multilateral development banks . . . are better placed to advise LDCs of the benefits of an international system based on trade and capital flows and to elicit market-directed changes in recipients' economic policies.

In other words, the perception in the United States Treasury report is that the IBRD is potentially an instrument to help bring about changes in economic policies in less developed countries which are more attuned to what the United States Reagan Administration regards as appropriate. It is an odd sort of criticism. There is that sort of view, on the one hand. On the other hand, highly critical attitudes are taken towards the World Bank by some members of the Left who see too much similarity between the types of restructuring policies they seek to impose and those that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) seeks to impose, with all the consequences that flow from them in terms of reduced living standards and increased political instability in the countries concerned and so on. So there seems to be a curious range of views on this subject which I will comment on in more detail later in my speech.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill is quite uncontroversial. It is not being opposed by the Opposition. It aims to authorise an additional subscription of capital by the Australian Government to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is the main arm of the World Bank, the other arm being the International Development Agency, the soft loan arm. The World Bank obviously is perceived to have a different role from that of the IMF, the IMF being primarily concerned with short term stabilisation. It is oriented mainly towards relatively short term macro-economic measures involving attempts to improve the balance of payments by suppressing or lowering the level of internally generated demand, and so forth. The IMF also seeks to promote more market-oriented policies in a range of respects. Theoretically the World Bank has a more long term perspective based upon long term development goals. There is some controversy about whether there is a conflict between the short term concerns of the IMF oriented to short term stabilisation on the one hand and the longer term goals which are being pursued by the World Bank on the other. One criticism of the World Bank is that it has been too closely attuned to the IMF's shorter term perspectives but, again, it is something I might talk about a little bit further along the track.

There are some other significant differences between the World Bank and the IMF too. The World Bank is actually engaged in raising significant funds on private capital markets, whereas that is not something that the IMF or a number of the other agencies are engaged in. That has certain implications which I will not elaborate on now.

I will make a few comments on the sorts of adjustment programs that the IMF and the World Bank have been engaged in seeking to impose on a number of countries. There has been considerable criticism of IMF adjustment programs. I have just returned from Africa where I attended the Southern African Development Co-ordination Conference in Arusha. There was quite a bit of discussion about the role of the IMF at that conference. One example of where the IMF has apparently sought to impose a quite unrealistic adjustment program on a country is in Zambia where the IMF was seeking to require effectively the quadrupling of the prices of basic foodstuffs. That meant that the Zambian Government was placed very quickly in a politically untenable situation. There seems to be something of an obliviousness on the part of the IMF to the consequences of trying to impose that very severe restructuring program on a country such as Zambia. There seems to have been somewhat more flexibility adopted recently. I understand that in the IMF's discussions with Mozambique it has been prepared to adopt a rather more sympathetic approach to the problems faced by countries in that region. That is obviously to be welcomed. I do not think there is any doubt that some of the attempts by the IMF to impose its own conception of structural change on a number of Third World countries have been misguided both in terms of their unalloyed belief in the efficacy of market forces, the desirability of trade liberalisation, the desirability of increasing mobility of capital flows and allowing market mechanisms to operate in an unimpeded way.

I accept that a number of the countries in the southern African region have pursued policies which clearly were misguided initially. The Mozambiquans, the Angolans and the Ethiopians have agricultural policies based, to a substantial extent, on collectivisation and artificially low administrative setting of agricultural prices and a number of other facets, particularly their agricultural sector. There is no doubt that those policies produced some seriously adverse results and there needed to be some changes made. But the question is whether the IMF and to a lesser extent the World Bank are right in pushing them too far in the direction of market-oriented policies. I believe that they are pushing them too far in the direction of market-oriented policies and I think that ultimately there will be a price to be paid for that.

If we look at countries in Africa that have pursued market-oriented policies it is interesting to see that it is not necessarily the case that the adoption of those policies will be a complete panacea for those countries. I refer to Kenya which has traditionally pursued more market-oriented policies. Despite that, that country has had very severe economic problems. Let us look at the position there. Kenya's gross national product per capita has declined from something of the order of $US360 per capita as annual GNP in the early 1970s. It has declined steadily since then until most recently where there was a GNP per capita of $US290 in 1986. So it is not necessarily the case that the adoption of more market-oriented policies will be the cure all for all those problems. Although I do accept that some of the countries in that region adopted Soviet style agricultural policies and that those policies did have disastrous results initially which meant that there needed to be some change, I believe that the IMF has been misguided in over-emphasising the benefits that can be expected to flow from more market-oriented policies.

The World Bank has a similar, if you like, broad ideological position to the IMF although, as I understand it, it has been somewhat less stringent in its application of those policies. However, the basic orientation is similar. There have been a variety of criticisms of the World Bank throughout its recent history, partly on the ground, as I said, of its belief in neoclassical economic approaches. There have also been other criticisms. Some related a few years ago to its inadequate attention to the environmental consequences of some of the policies that it has pursued. There seems to have been some redress in that area in recent times, but there seems to be far more. From a reading of the most recent World Bank annual report there seems to be a far greater emphasis on the need to examine the environmental consequences of various development programs and to look at ways in which the environment in less developed countries can be improved.

I might observe that coming back from Africa, having driven a fair distance from Nairobi in Kenya to Arusha in Tanzania, the environmental problems that are besetting that continent are very visible. As one drives through the countryside there is evidence of massive soil erosion and massive overgrazing, with consequent serious problems down the track. There is very little vegetation in evidence even from a cursory glance. That is clearly a major problem for less developed countries. It is pleasing to see that the World Bank is starting to pay rather more attention to those sorts of things.

I also believe that there has been something of a change in the World Bank's orientation to the need to alleviate poverty in recent times. I will mention two contrasting quotations. The first is from Eugene Rotberg who is a long time Vice-President of the Bank. He is quoted in the book by Hayter and Watson from a couple of years ago. He stated:

We are not a social welfare agency committed to making transfer payments to solve the problems of misery or poverty. We are a development bank using the most sophisticated techniques available to facilitate development, while providing unmatched protection and strength for creditors and shareholders.

Incidentally this provides an interesting contrast with the view expressed by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), about the financial practices of the bank. More recently the new President since 1986, Barber Conable, said the following:

Our greatest goal is to reduce the poverty, misery and destitution which blights our world . . . rapid economic growth or the advances of modern technology seem of little consequence if nearly a billion people do not have enough food, clean water or shelter . . . there is little reason to expect that future growth alone will attain the progress against poverty that it has failed to secure in the past.

So there seems to have been significant change of emphasis between those two quotations. I think that change of emphasis is one that can only be welcomed. I certainly welcome that change of emphasis. Notwithstanding criticisms that one might have of the World Bank and its operations-as I said, there are a variety of them-there is no doubt that, on balance, it does provide an essential service. I do not believe that the existing financial institutions would fill that gap in the absence of the World Bank, as the previous speaker seemed to imply. He made a variety of criticisms of the operation of the World Bank. I do not believe the criticisms he made are well founded. The other criticisms I referred to earlier I believe have considerably greater substance and deserve to be taken more seriously.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of preface, let me say that when the debate was interrupted for the dinner break we were addressing the Bill relating to the organisation known as the World Bank. The Bill is given a formal name, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill. I want first to say a little about the purpose of this Bill because many of those who perhaps will pick up the issue later may not be familiar with what the Bill is about. This Bill empowers the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to make necessary agreements on behalf of Australia to purchase 178 additional shares of the capital stock of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). It empowers him to make these agreements on such terms and conditions as he thinks fit and where appropriate to issue securities in payment. The Bill also appropriates the funds necessary to make payments under these agreements. It has a financial impact of some dimension. The cost to Australia of taking up these shares-Australia's subscription-will be $US1.8m spread over four financial years.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech refers to the World Bank, and I think it is timely in this debate to remind the House about this organisation. It was established officially as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development when it opened its doors in 1946 as one of two international institutions agreed to at the Bretton Woods Conference of July 1944 for the purposes of postwar reconstruction. It was designed particularly in the first instance to assist with the external financing of the reconstruction of Europe at the conclusion of World War II, but it quickly became apparent that the resources of the bank were few and that the organisation was too new for that task, and the functions were assumed extensively thereafter by the United States of America. During the bank's formative years bank lending remained fairly limited for the purposes of development and, of course, more recently we have seen that low level of lending increase and the bank itself has grown. It has been criticised at times for being too cautious and insufficiently concerned with the development needs of the poorer members. That is a matter I intend to address today.

I ought to mention also that as part of its operation not only has the World Bank loans that it makes on much more commercial terms, but also through one of its subsidiary organisations, the International Development Association (IDA), using the same offices as the World Bank but with a separate charter it offers loans to low income member countries, repayable at 7.5 per cent interest over 50 years, including 10 years grace. These soft or discretionary loans are made possible by the contributions to the IDA by governments of high income and industrial countries. I guess in those terms Australia is often seen as one of the contributors. So one can see that this organisation has wide implications, particularly where social issues are concerned and in terms of the distribution of income to the Third World nations or developing countries. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones), who introduced the Bill, was quite generous in his comments in relation to the organisation. He said:
. . . it plays an important role in the South East Asian region. This has been recognised by Australian governments over the years since the bank's establishment.
He added:
The IBRD is an effective and efficient institution in the provision of development assistance to developing countries . . .
He also said, and this is a fact of record:

Up to the end of June 1987, the bank had lent about $US120 billion to its member countries. This money was largely borrowed from international financial markets. The cost to taxpayers in those member countries in terms of paid in capital subscriptions was only $US7.2 billion.

He noted that the organisation covered the financing of major sectors of development with an emphasis on infrastructure facilities, transport, communications, industry, energy sectors, as well as projects for agriculture, education and water supply. About the IDA, which I mentioned earlier, he said that it has a comprehensive and systematic project evaluation system which shows that most bank and IDA projects-85 per cent of those evaluated in 1986, for instance-achieve all or almost all of their objectives. He spoke about the average return on those being 14.8 per cent.

He added one other matter to which I draw the attention of the House and that was Australia's membership of the IBRD bringing substantial commercial benefits. On a cumulative basis Australia has received more from procurement by the IBRD, including the IDA, than it has given in contributions to the bank and the IDA. That is a particularly important fact. What he is really saying is that if we look at the way in which consultancies are offered to Australians and the way products are procured in Australia, we will see that there are economic benefits the bank brings to us in relation to a lot of its lending to developed countries.

Those comments are particularly pertinent when one looks at the speech made earlier today by one of my colleagues the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), who questioned, as I recall, our role in continuing to finance the World Bank as it is structured at the moment and the levels of Australia's contribution in terms of the debt we Australians are incurring. I guess he was picking up terms that I heard used by, I think, the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb), who commented on the way in which people in his own electorate look at the World Bank and aid programs generally. He was saying that people argue that charity begins at home and that we should get our own house in order and then we might be able to look further abroad. I must say, and I have said this before, that that has not been my approach. I think the more appropriate statement is that charity begins at home, but it does not end there. We in Australia have some responsibilities in relation to those who are less well off than ourselves. It is a matter of ordering priorities. We ought not escape some of the responsibilities we share with our other colleagues in developed nations in assisting those worse off than ourselves.

I make those statements because a number of members of parliament have over time offered some comments about the bank and its operations. I had the privilege last October, along with my colleagues the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles), the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), Senator Nick Bolkus and Senator Robert Hill, of being one of a number of lead signers of a letter addressed on behalf of members of parliament not only in Australia but also from the United Kingdom and the United States as well as Canada, to the President of the World Bank, Mr Conable. I do not intend to read the letter at length, but it offered comment to Mr Conable in the form of six recommendations on the way in which the World Bank might operate. The comments about the way in which the organisation should function were, firstly, in relation to women in development. This was a matter about which I had to make some personal inquiries to satisfy myself because I saw this matter very often in terms of the feminist debate that we see all too often in our own community. But the issues are not those that we normally hear discussed in feminist terms. Women in so many of these developing countries are at the very bottom of the social ladder, with much heavier demands made upon them, particularly when they are working in agriculture, and some attention in terms of development programs needs to be given to assist them.

In the context of women in development it was noted that women actually produce most of the food that is eaten in poor countries-as much as 80 per cent in Africa-yet they receive the least assistance of any kind, particularly in agriculture. As late as March 1987 only one of the bank's 3,800 professional staff were assigned to women in development, even though Mr Conable himself said in a speech that the bank had not been effective in channelling assistance to women, with the consequence that, along with women, development itself has suffered.

In the area of health and education we noted that according to the United Nations Children's Fund and the World Health Organisation the biggest child killers in poor countries are preventable diseases complicated by malnutrition. They include measles, two million a year; tetanus, 800,000; diarrhoeal dehydration, four million; and common respiratory infections. These diseases will render disabled as many as they kill. We noted that the bank plans to double its lending for health and population nutrition by the 1990s, but it would still then be giving only 2 to 3 per cent of its total lending to those purposes, and that was a matter of concern to us.

On the matter of adjustment lending we noted in our letter that the bank ought to design structural economic policies which not only cushion the poor but actually help improve the services they need most. The poor are usually the first and hardest hit by the present economic adjustment policies. We saw the need for cooperation with indigenous non-government organisations, and many of my colleagues spoke earlier about the importance of that. We noted the bank's own studies and the studies of other development institutions which have shown that carefully targeted small scale projects yield the greatest benefit to the poor, and the success of such projects depends on the involvement of indigenous groups on project planning, implementation and monitoring.

We noted further that the bank's studies show that higher than average economic returns often result from poverty orientated projects. I wish in this context also to draw attention to the matter which I have raised on other occasions in debates in this House, and that is that one of the organisations that has been working particularly in the small scale projects, which greatly benefit the poor, has been the international organisation, the International Food for Agricultural Development (IFAD), which we also support. But we have indicated that we will no longer support that organisation after the second replenishment. After the third replenishment Australia will be one of the first developed countries to withdraw its support for that organisation. I think it is important to look at the World Bank in that context because so often it is argued that it can pick up the role that IFAD has been pursuing. I simply make the point that if we look at the way in which the bank's own studies have commented on this area of activity, it is one in which it could be more usefully involved and there is enormous scope for it to be involved in targeting small scale projects, with the indigenous groups being involved in the planning of them in the same way that IFAD has done so successfully.

In the area of environmental protection we noticed that development projects which have had dire ecological consequences have had their most severe impact upon indigenous people whose livelihoods depend directly on marginal and fragile ecosystems. I mentioned just today that some of us had the opportunity of meeting with Harold Henderson of World Vision of Australia to hear a report on his recent visit to Ethiopia where the degradation of the environment is very significant, leading to greatly increased hardship for the indigenous people, incurring greater difficulty in ameliorating their hardship, particularly when drought affects them, as is the case at the moment.

In the area of poverty lending we noted that a recent World Bank report claimed that 29 per cent of the bank's lending directly helped the poor, but we put the suggestion to Mr Conable that the bank should commit at least 60 per cent of its lending to assist directly the poorest 40 per cent of people. I must say that, while I have not counted all the signatories to that letter, the numbers were very significant. Probably half, if not more, of the members of the Parliament signed that letter to the President of the World Bank. Mr Conable wrote to me in response, as he no doubt did to the other signatories of the letter, on 16 October, thanking me for my comments but making the point that the World Bank has adopted a new, more operational approach to women in development. He noted that I had referred to increasing investments in future productivity and the well being of people in the developing world. He made the point that the bank was also aware that increased bank lending was not enough and that an insufficient use of existing resources often hampers efforts to reach the poor. He commented further in relation to the note that members generally sent, that our approach to adjustment programs is being modified as we learn more about how to protect the interests of the poor.

It was a pleasing response, but I think there is a need for members, while picking up those points, to offer some further comments. I hope we will have the opportunity of doing so further in a new approach to Mr Conable about a number of other matters. The areas in which I hope we will be able to offer positive comments are, firstly, on the use of social indicators to measure development progress. That is an issue which the World Bank ought to be addressing. It ought not to be using, as it appears to be at the moment, simply traditional economic indicators, but social indicators such as the mortality rate for children under the age of 5; life expectancy; access to safe water; adult literacy rates, particularly amongst women; and the proportion of children suffering malnutrition. These seem to me to be important matters that ought to be considered in the context of measuring increased performance as a result of World Bank lending. I believe social indicators of those types, which could measure development progress, could be and would be a useful advance to the bank itself and a matter upon which we members could positively comment.

The second matter I hope we will address is the future of the International Development Association's terms. I mentioned earlier in this address the special terms upon which the fund, using the IDA, makes available special loans on a concessional rate. One of the major factors presently hindering progress in development is the burden of debt. Unlike middle income countries such as Australia and those in Latin American countries whose debt is primarily owed to the commercial banks, the poorest countries, those in the sub-Saharan area of Africa, are mainly indebted to governments and international financial institutions like the World Bank. They increasingly are going to be faced with problems in committing themselves even to the very much lower terms of payment that are presently accorded to them. In regard to further replenishments, particularly the IDA funds, it seems to me, and I hope it will seem to my colleagues, that the proposal to donor countries ought to be that the funds they supply should go to the poorest countries and largely on grant terms.

The final matter I wish to mention is structural adjustment lending, which we addressed on the last occasion. It seems to me that the concerns that we expressed about the effects of structural adjustment programs on some of the poorest sections of populations of developing countries need to be further emphasised, with policies that are tailored to meeting the needs of the poor. Therefore, I think it is important that the bank continue to pay special attention to the needs of these people as it develops guidelines for major aid donor countries to deal with structural adjustment. I certainly would encourage the bank to review these matters further, particularly as it enters into discussions at this time. There is a demand to prepare poverty impact statements on each adjustment loan as part of the loan document which goes to the executive so people can be aware how the poorest people in these developing nations will benefit from the programs the World Bank adopts. I hope these comments and the comments of my colleagues will be helpful to the bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill. I find myself in considerable agreement, as we seem to be on both sides of the House, with most aspects of this Bill. By way of preface I remind honourable members that it is a Bill to obtain parliamentary approval for Australia to take up an increase in its capital subscription to the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. As was pointed out in the second reading speech-a point to which I wish to allude in my contribution, brief though it will be-the major emphasis of projects undertaken by the bank is on infrastructure facilities in developing countries with particular reference to transport and communications, industry, energy, water supply, agriculture and education.

SPEECH.PARA: From time to time comments are made that Australia is not playing a sufficient role in international aid, particularly to developing countries. As the world political situation changes, clearly we have to evaluate the countries and places in which we place our aid and the way in which it is used. I am a great supporter of our assistance via the development bank. To pick up a couple of comments made by my predecessor in this debate, the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock), I think it is important that the injections to developing countries are made with an eye to economic benefit. I well understand the other parameters the honourable member pointed to which ought to be taken into account, and I agree with him. In the last decade, the late 1970s and early 1980s, we have seen almost the exploitation of international financial entrepreneurs who have put loan funds into developing countries based on poor lending principles. In many of these countries the debt burden of repayment to lenders from the traditional Western countries cannot be met. Those debt repayments have placed the whole world financial structure under some strain in that these countries have to forget about the loans that have been made, they have to renegotiate new terms of lending or in one form or other rework the loans that have been made because proper account has not been taken of the principles of lending. I suppose what I am pointing to is that loans that go into countries through the development bank are in the form of aid and assist development of the kinds outlined.

Some loans made through the finance sector encourage development of industry or support a particular regime which might or might not return dividends. In the long term, institutions that have been making those loans without proper regard to the security of the loan, the capacity of the country to repay or even the long term political stability of the country to which the loans are made, suddenly find down the track that those loans cannot be honoured. An example is the United States of America where, in the late 1970s, there was a spree of international lending. It virtually gave money away. Many of those loans now cannot be repaid and some of the institutions making them, in particular some of the private banks, have found themselves on the verge of collapse or, most importantly, governments have had to intervene and pick them up. What I say about these activities is that the proper course by which the lending should be made is through the development bank. It is directed at the kinds of development projects which mean, hopefully, that in the long term these countries will be self-sustaining and we will feel that our money has been put to the best use.

It is important also to reflect for a moment on Australia's involvement in a new part of the world, not only in the south-east Pacific basin but also in our alliance with the 14 countries that we call the Cairns group. That is a group of trading nations that have come together with us in a consortium arrangement to try to bring some sort of balance to the inconsistencies that are occurring in world trade at the moment. Some of these countries are looking to Australia as a financial base in the south-east Pacific to give them a lead as they become wealthier and, as they become involved more in profitable trade, they are looking to Australia to gain a lead as to how they should play their role in assisting countries less fortunate. In my contribution tonight I encourage decision makers in those countries who participate with us in the Cairns group to take up subscriptions through this development fund as they become more profitable and as they have more funds available. We can show a lead in that sort of coordinated group activity and it is what those who are joining with us in world trade are looking for.

I happen to have the very good fortune in my own electorate-in fact in my own home town-to have two people to talk to about some of these matters who are very close to these sorts of activities in countries such as Ethiopia as was mentioned by the honourable member for Dundas. Professor Michael Rand is Professor of Pharmacology at Melbourne University and at the moment is the chairman of the pharmacologists group in Australia, as is well known to my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). That group has just played host to the international conference of pharmacologists in Sydney. One of the key issues they were looking to, as scientists, was the way they can assist developing countries in disease moderation, increasing productivity, life expectancy and food production and in all those issues associated with that. Professor Rand has also been the chairman of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation's world committee on some of these matters. I know from speaking with him that he is very supportive of this kind of approach to world development.

Another person I have talked to about these things is a chap by the name of Allan Carpenter who also lives in my home town of Heathcote. I must be very fortunate to have all these people so close to me because I can wander down to the shops on a Saturday morning and get the answers-it works very well. Mr Carpenter is a world consultant to the Food and Agriculture Organisation. He has recently returned from spending six months in Ethiopia assisting that country with dry land agriculture products and helping to overcome the long term problems of cultivation and food production.

In summary, in this brief contribution, I suppose what I am saying is that it is important for people to note that Australia is playing a significant role in overseas aid and in measures such as this, by taking up our increased allocation with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development. We are making a direct form of lending available to countries such as those I have mentioned. We are, through the development bank, insisting that the lending is done under sound financial principles, and that does not mean screwing these countries for the best possible rate of interest or return. In fact, as was pointed out in the second reading speech, these loans are soft loans, which the means a low interest rate repayable over a long period.

The point is that the loans are accompanied with the best of advice and criteria that we can develop to ensure that the money will be spent in a manner that will benefit these developing countries most in the long term. As I said earlier, given the experience of the international financial community in its almost irresponsible lending process with developing and other countries over the past decade, I welcome the sound economic and lending principles that are encompassed in the activities of the development bank. In supporting the Bill, I reiterate the comments in the second reading speech. I too believe that it is in Australia's interest to continue its policy of support for the development bank by, in this case, taking up in full the increase in our capital subscription to which we have become entitled.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill 1988 I want to take the opportunity to draw the attention of the House to one aspect of the work of the bank that is causing alarm and concern among conservationists worldwide. I wish to put my comments in context. It should be noted that the international bank is part of the World Bank group, together with the International Development Association and the International Finance Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The initial purpose of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development was to promote the international flow of capital for productive purposes and to assist in financing the rebuilding of nations devastated by the Second World War. Lending for productive projects, leading to economic growth in its less developed member countries which will directly assist the poorest people, is now the main objective of the bank. Unfortunately, in pursuing these aims the bank has neglected to consider the environmental consequences of the developments it has been supporting.

The purpose of the Bill presently before the House is to enable Australia to take up an increase in its capital subscription to the international bank. As at 31 March 1987 the subscribed capital of the bank was $US83,541m. As part of the present share increase, Australia will purchase 178 shares at a cost of $US1.88m, spread over the four financial years from 1988-89 to 1991-92. Last year Mr Jim Barnes, a lawyer from the United States based conservation organisation, Threshhold, which is known also as the International Centre for Environmental Renewal, visited Australia to seek support for a proposed review of the activities of the World Bank and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and the associated multilateral development banks, such as the Asian Development Bank.

It is a matter of particular concern that the financial organisations involved in development in the developing nations of the Third World have not provided resources for adequate assessments of the environmental impacts of new development project. Mr Barnes had discussions with me, as Chairman, and several other members of the then Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. He made a number of points that I should like to draw to the attention of honourable members. Examples of developments supported by the multilateral development banks which are in environmentally sensitive areas are: first, transmigration in Indonesia, costing $US1 billion over the past decade with grievous long term environmental consequences; second, a proposed irrigation scheme in India-resulting in the flooding of 200,000 homes- which, because of siltation, will totally fail in seven to eight years; third, a major access road in Brazil which so far has cost $US240m-and I presume these money figures are in American dollars-but which is described as a complete environmental and social disaster and is associated with a major outbreak of malaria.

Finally, an example of one of the serious long-term consequences of World Bank programs is the green revolution in India. Forty per cent of the world's DDT production is used to sustain the program, yet many of the donor countries have banned or restricted the use of DDT. It is quite reprehensible that advice is not sought from a recipient country's environmental or health Ministers, and also that advice is not sought from those communities affected by the development. I wish that honourable members could see the picture I have before me of Amazon Basin indians watching logging operations stripping their hunting grounds bare.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is horrible.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Hotham says, it is horrible. Of course, he is able to see the picture, whereas unfortunately other members cannot. Rainforests are disappearing at the rate of 11 million hectares a year. Since at least half of the world's estimated plant and animal species, of the order of 30 million, live in tropical forests, the loss of the forests is particularly serious. Unfortunately, the rate of clearing is increasing. If current trends continue, an additional 225 million hectares of tropical forests will be cleared by the year 2000, representing about 25 per cent of the remaining tropical forests on Earth.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the loss of tropical forests is only one of the adverse effects of developments supported by the World Bank and its associated multidevelopment banks. Finance has been provided for capital-intensive projects that replace traditional work-intensive economic activities, thus forcing the displaced local peasants onto marginal land in ecologically sensitive areas. Finance is also being provided for projects involving the creation of massive cattle ranches on poor soils previously forested areas. As was mentioned in previously, projects are being financed in places other than in India which involve the spraying of vast areas with huge amounts of hard pesticides that are banned in most Western countries. Other projects involve the construction of huge hydro-power and irrigation schemes, which results in the removal of the local population on to infertile land with inadequate compensation for those displaced people and which will inevitably lead to widespread waterlogging and soil salinisation.

In Australia we have had plenty of experience with environmental problems resulting from such development schemes. It seems to me that it is even more important for us to take into account the possible consequences of developments funded by the International Bank, of which we are an important shareholder. I quote a passage by a visitor to two World Bank funded developments in Indonesia and Brazil which describes the scenes of massive ecological devastation in the Indonesia transmigration project, and the Polonoroeste project. There is a picture taken of the Polonoroeste program in the Amazon, and I have another picture of a typical scene of destruction which my colleague the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) is able to look at.

TALK.START.PARA: —It looks like a Queensland rainforest.

—Indeed, it does look like a Queensland rainforest, after the developers have been in. This Government will ensure that we stop such destruction by making sure that the areas are protected by world heritage legislation. I quote from the article which reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Visiting such areas it is hard to view without emotion the miles of devastated trees, of felled, broken and burned trunks, of branches, mud, and bark crisscrossed with tractor trails-especially when one realises that in most cases nothing of comparable value will grow again on the area. Such sights are reminiscent of photographs of Hiroshima, and Brazil and Indonesia might be regarded as waging the equivalent of thermo-nuclear war upon their territories.
Another classic example is in the Sudan where the World Bank has poured in thousands of millions of dollars over the past decade to promote increased agricultural production. I quote again:

Agricultural experts are not optimistic about the future of Gezira cotton. Many believe that the cotton industry is at the brink of disaster and will collapse unless drastic measures are taken . . . A chief obstacle is failure of the existing pest control scheme that is based exclusively on chemical insecticides. The farmers are spending large amounts of money-25-30 per cent of the total production expenses-for chemical control of the insect pests but are getting very poor results . . . The profit margin (for sale of cotton) in 1979-80 was . . . considerably less than the foreign currency required for purchase of the imported insecticides. Costs of cotton insect control in the Gezira increased at the alarming rate of six-fold between the seasons of 1972-73 and 1980-81 yet, cotton yields declined (from 1970-1975 to 1975-81) by . . . 38 per cent . . . Unacceptable residues of DDT and other persistent, organochlorine insecticides now occur in water, mother's milk, livestock, fish and wildlife.

Those quotations are all taken from a 1985 edition of the Ecologist magazine, volume 15, No. 1/2 but, far from being out of date, the comments are even more relevant today. No doubt it will be argued by some people that the World Bank has recognised its obligations and responsibilities and has taken action. It is true that the World Bank has suspended loan disbursements for the Brazilian project, but it continues to finance the Indonesian transmigration from Java and Bali to Irian Jaya and Kalimantan. This single project, I submit, poses the gravest threats to the environment and the people who live in and depend on tropical forests. It is also true that the World Bank has recently substantially increased the number of its staff engaged on environmental assessment. However, it is now vital that pressure is placed on the World Bank, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and the International Development Association to implement the environmental guidelines which they adopted in 1984, but which have not been implemented by recipient nations such as Indonesia, Brazil and India.

The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) indicated in his second reading speech that the World Bank and the International Development Association have a comprehensive and systematic project evaluation system, which indicated that 85 per cent of all projects in 1986 achieved all or most of their objectives. The average return measured by a net flow of economic benefits was 14.8 per cent. However, I doubt that the net flow of economic benefits took into account any environmental desecration which may have occurred. The problem has been that the World Bank uses consultants in the fields of economics, science and engineering but does not seek advice from environmental scientists. I understand that the United States Government has been discussing with the various member countries of the multi-development banks the development of policies to ensure that future projects will result in truly sustainable developments over a long period of time and to avoid the calamitous environmental consequences such as I have previously described in this speech. I hope that the Treasurer can give the House an assurance that the Government will actively pursue with the World Bank the concerns that I have expressed.

I wish to make it clear that I fully support the present Bill, but I believe that development can only be truly worthwhile, in a world of rapidly declining natural resources, if environmental values are taken fully into account when international development projects are approved. I hope that I receive an assurance from the Minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), that the Government is taking these matters into account and will be asking the World Bank when it makes its share allocation to ensure that environmental values are used and taken up by the recipient nations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am especially pleased to take part in the second reading debate on the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (Share Increase) Bill. The Bill will give parliamentary approval to increase Australia's subscription of shares in the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). In 1986 the bank authorised a further allocation of shares which gives Australia the right to take up an additional 178 shares. At the outset I draw the attention of honourable members to the fact that allocation of shares, therefore the equity and voting rights in the International Monetary Fund (IMF), as well as the World Bank is heavily in favour of the developed industrial countries. Only a glance at the table setting out the members' entitlements to take up additional shares, which is published on page 7 of the explanatory memorandum, shows how disproportionate the allocations are. It is not a coincidence but a deliberate design that 64 per cent of shares and therefore the major say, the decision making, is in the hands of the rich developed countries.

SPEECH.PARA: The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, better known as the World Bank, was established as a complementary institution to the IMF and its membership is conditional on membership of the IMF. Both the International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development-the World Bank-were established at Bretton Woods, after the Second World War, to internationally co-ordinate attempts to deal with world monetary and financial problems. It was envisaged that the IMF should finance short term balance of payments deficits while the World Bank was to finance long term development projects. The idea was that these two institutions should maintain the equilibrium between the surplus and deficit countries by recirculating surpluses and promoting world wide economic growth. However, a number of events, culminating in the oil crisis in the early 1970s changed the intended financial agenda. While the result of the oil crisis imposed heavily on many developing countries, it also poured 80 billion petro-dollars into European and United States banks to recycle. The money was duly lent to developing countries at low interest rates. High commodity prices at the time made many countries that are now in trouble look good and credit-worthy.

It is history now that the situation changed dramatically in the late 1970s and 1980s. As the rich Western countries increased interest rates to fight inflation and slowed down their economies to reduce demand, they imposed a double burden on the indebted Third World-firstly through increased interest rates on their debts, and secondly through reducing the commodity prices by which Third World countries were hitherto servicing their loans. As the world economy shrank, as the crisis deepened, a horrible scramble ensued. The rich, industrially developed First World countries unloaded their problems and troubles onto the Third World, firstly by maintaining high prices for industrial products which they exported, and secondly by reducing commodity prices for the produce of the Third World. Parallel to this, there ensued a scramble inside each country whereby the rich undertook every way possible to unload the burden of hard economic times onto the poorer sections of the population. Nothing illustrates this better than the growing wealth of the 31,000 millionaires in Australia over the last few years, as opposed to the reduced living standards of the ordinary wage and salary earners in this country.

However, the international situation is even worse. In the last decade, the Third World countries have experienced growing poverty manifesting itself in increasing malnutrition and hunger, growing child mortality, increasing food prices and the growing deprivation of masses of the population. On top of all this, IMF and World Bank-imposed conditions of monetarist and New Right-Thatcherite solutions plunged the underdeveloped countries into a further morass of poverty. Not since the slave trade has the North so cruelly exploited the South. Every drop of blood is squeezed out of the poor Third World countries to service their debt. For the first time in history, the flow of capital is reversed and there is a net flow from the developing countries to the industrial countries. This flow was estimated at approximately $US30 billion in 1986. Annually, $US30 billion is flowing from the poor in the poor countries to the rich in the rich countries. Only the inability of the Third World to pay is putting the limit on this scandalous, cruel exploitation of the world poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bleeding them dry.

—As the honourable member for La Trobe says, they are bleeding them dry. It is often argued that the future of this planet depends on the balance of power between East and West. Most people believe that the clash between communist and capitalist ideologies is the biggest danger to our existence. While I do not wish to disregard the dangers of the East-West clash, I am of the opinion that if we do not resolve the world debt crisis, if we do not stop driving the Third World into further poverty, there will be a bigger danger to mankind from a South-North clash, which will manifest itself in the collapse of the world financial system.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not contend that there have been no attempts to resolve the debt problems. Of course there was rescheduling, under strict conditionality, as well as structural adjustment for loans. However, the conditions imposed by the IMF, and to a lesser extent by the World Bank, deteriorated during the last couple of decades into the imposition of strict monetarist measures and severe austerity programs which on occasions provoked riots and political unrest. The condition demanded by the IMF are public expenditure cuts, wage cuts, trade and exchange liberalisation measures, devaluation and so on-a list only too familiar. It seems to me that our Treasurer (Mr Keating) pre-empted any IMF demand; and what goes for the IMF goes for the World Bank. According to Teresa Hayter:
The World Bank and the IMF have been called the police of development.

Other official and private lenders tend to lend or not to lend according to whether the government has the seal of approval of the IMF or the World Bank. Especially now that private banks have become over- extended and fearful of defaults, these two institutions are being called upon to make sure that banks get their money back, and that they can lend in future without fear of losing it.

The World Bank and the IMF are said to work together in complete . . . No conflicts are admitted between them; and they frequently go on joint missions to countries. Although the IMF has been criticised, even in the Brandt report, for example, for excessive `harshness' in the conditions it puts on its lending, and may possibly have responded a little to these criticisms, it certainly has not changed a great deal. The implication is that the World Bank has not done so either, and that the governments of underdeveloped countries are still subject to pressures from these institutions to carry out orthodox monetarist policies.

Of course, to satisfy the World Bank or the IMF, the countries that are exposed to the bank's conditionality are forced to cut public, not private, expenditure. The pattern of advice received from the World Bank and the IMF is inevitably based on right wing monetarist ideology. This is not surprising as both the IMF and the IBRD are dominated by the major industrial powers, promoting the New Right ideology of the sanctity of private investment and private profits and the reliance on market forces. The World Bank the IMF and the United States Agency for International Development in many cases work out detailed programs which the government concerned has to adopt as a condition of getting their money. All three agencies work closely together, even to the extent that they use United States embassies as meeting places, where they co-ordinate their activities in the countries concerned.

The International Monetary Fund and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development became instruments in the hands of the developed nations to oppress and impoverish further the Third World countries. In most countries, increasing debt is paralleled by rising social and political instability. Too often the price of IMF imposed austerity has been the contraction of debtor countries' economies. The consequent soaring unemployment and inflation rates mean that the burden of debt servicing falls on those sections of the community who can least afford to pay. For example, in 1985 prices rose by 56 per cent in Mexico and a staggering 219 per cent in Brazil. In September 1985 President Jose Sarney told the United Nations General Assembly, `Brazil won't pay its debt with unemployment or hunger'. The IMF package places the burden of recovery on the poor, who are severely affected by reductions in social programs and consumer subsidies. With its emphasis on balance of payments, economic indicators and mathematical models, the conditionality package lacks social sensitivity. It ignores the plight of already impoverished people who are driven further below the poverty line.

The political consequences of austerity measures, namely, the combination of economic stagnation and social mobilisation, often lead to the destabilisation of democratic governments and the promotion of authoritarian and repressive regimes. The Minister of Finance of the Dominican Republic has said:
It is not that we do not want to put our house in order, but we do not want to burn it down.

By placing most of their faith in the mystical workings of the free market, the IMF and the World Bank tend to forget that many of the economies of the less developed countries, or LDCs, are dominated by multinational and transnational companies. As Wheelright has pointed out, the traditional concept of a free market is no longer tenable. He says:

. . . private conglomerate transnational enterprise has replaced the private national enterprise and the free market envisaged by Adam Smith and his successors. A few transnationals are the market. For all practical purposes, market forces means what suits them.

This absence of free market forces is exactly the reason why monetarist solutions and prescriptions by the New Right inevitably fail, whether they are imposed by IMF and World Bank packages or by Treasurers of various countries in both the developed and underdeveloped world. The Baker plan introduced towards the end of 1985 was heralded by the Western Press as a solution to the debt problem. The plan included changes to the traditional method of providing funds for specific projects towards a more sectoral approach. It provides for greater control of the World Bank by the United States with an increase of $US9 billion in available funds from 1986 to 1988. It promotes decreased reliance on the IMF for short term finance and facilitates increased lending by private banks. But it also imposes stringent austerity measures on debtor countries seeking new loans. Baker stated:
The fund should give higher priority to tax reform, market oriented pricing, the reduction of labour market rigidities, and to opening economies to foreign trade investment.

In this light, the Baker plan can most appropriately be seen as a solution for private banks, multinational and transnational companies and the US but clearly not for the already impoverished population of the debtor countries. A report by the Development Issues Study Group of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, entitled Life After Debt, states:

In summary the Baker proposal has turned out to be an exercise in rhetoric, but is significant in that it has signalled a more positive attitude on the part of the US Administration. Unfortunately, no concrete actions or even a realistic plan for action have been forthcoming.

As time goes on it becomes more and more evident that the monetarist approach and the New Right free market principles applied by the IMF and the World Bank have failed to resolve the debt crisis and the problems of international finance and trade. So we have to look for another answer. The global economic and monetary crisis affects everybody, North and South alike. Yet until now restructuring and adjustment was always expected only from the less developed countries. It is about time that the rich North also took on the burden.

The large economies of the United States, Japan and Germany should adopt measures to stimulate demand by relaxing monetary and fiscal policy by stimulating global demand and moderate growth. Commodity prices will then improve and thus enable the debtor nations to discharge their loan service obligations while still continuing to develop. The rich nations ought to lower their protective tariff barriers and abandon their non-tariff protection measures to free up their markets for entry of product from less developed countries. In other words, the rich will have to moderate their greed and allow a bit of a place under the sun to the have-nots, or else we are all heading towards total disaster.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

I will be very happy to pass on to the Treasurer the remarks of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) in relation to the environmental issues he mentioned. The Parliament and all of Australia know of his keen interest in environmental issues and I will be very happy to do that on behalf of the honourable member.

SPEECH.PARA: That amendments Nos 1 to 3 be agreed to.

These amendments were moved by the Government in the Senate. Honourable members will be aware that there has been an opportunity to restructure the Family Court of Australia because of the resignation of the Chief Judge, who took up a position with the Australian Law Reform Commission. With the appointment of a new Chief Judge, it was advised that it would be wise-in fact, very meritorious-to have a Deputy Chief Judge and also to create the position of judge administrator.
