TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senate amendment No. 4 be agreed to with the following amendment:
Clause 8b, page 3, omit proposed subsections (3), (4) and (5) insert the following subsections:

``(3) Judges appointed as Judge Administrators or assigned to the Appeal Division before, or not later than 3 months after, the commencement of section 8b of the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Act 1988 have seniority next to the Deputy Chief Judge, and have such seniority in relation to each other as they had immediately before that commencement.

``(4) The remaining Judge Administrators and Judges assigned to the Appeal Division have seniority next to the Judges to whom subsection (3) applies according to the days on which their appointments as Judge Administrators and their assignments to the Appeal Division (whichever first occurred) took effect.

``(4a) Where, because 2 or more appointments as Judge Administrator and assignments to the Appeal Division took effect on the same day, subsection (4) does not determine priority between the Judges concerned, those Judges have such seniority in relation to each other as is assigned to them by the Governor-General.

``(5) The Senior Judges not assigned to the Appeal Division have seniority next to the Judges to whom subsection (4) applies according to the days on which their appointments as Senior Judges took effect.''.

This amendment relates to the seniority provision for judges. It was drafted with the intention that judges appointed as judge administrators and judges appointed to the appeal division would have equal seniority according to the dates upon which those judges were appointed. Some members of the appeal division have already been appointed. Depending on which judges are appointed as judge administrators, there may be a significant consequential disruption of existing seniority.

Yesterday I attended a meeting of the judges. Some of them were concerned as to who would be affected unless this matter was made clear. I understand also that the matter was raised by Senator Durack in the Senate yesterday. He would also have been aware of the judges' concern. The judges regard seniority as an important issue related to their independence. It is important that the new administrative arrangements work well. I have brought forward this amendment to ensure that, in relation to the initial appointments, the existing seniority prevails. The purpose of the amendment is to preserve any existing seniority that a judge subsequently appointed as a judge administrator may have as against members of the appeal division who retain their existing appointments. There will also be one additional appointment to the appeal division.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senate amendment No. 5 be agreed to with the following amendment:
After `other than an order' insert `until further order or an order'.

The Senate's amendment relates to the creation of the position of judicial registrar. It provided that the judges could delegate to judicial registrars all of the powers of the court. No limitation was placed on the power of the judges to delegate authority to judicial registrars in the same way as no limitation has been placed on the power of delegation to registrars in 1983 other than in relation to divorce and approval of maintenance agreements. The purpose of our amendment is to ensure that judicial registrars will be able to provide valuable relief to the judiciary in relation to interim or urgent matters which arise from day to day in each registry and require a prompt but effective response.

The provision will allow the judges to delegate to a judicial registrar the power to make an order until further order. That order is commonly known as an interim order and may operate for a fixed and limited period or until such time as the parties seek to have the matter finalised by a judge. The Government considers that the power to make an interim order of this nature will be a valuable part of the judicial registrar's total jurisdiction. If judicial registrars do not have that jurisdiction the purpose of the creation of the judicial registrar might be substantially negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —To put the matter in perspective, this Bill seeks to make some fairly major changes to the jurisdiction of the Family Court of Australia. One aspect of the Bill is to devolve some of the existing powers of judges to registrars and to the newly-created positions of judicial registrars. Amendment No. 5 relates to the powers of judicial registrars. The Senate's amendment is to the effect that, whilst judicial registrars have a pretty free and wide ambit in terms of jurisdiction, in the Senate's view they should not handle the final contested proceedings in respect of the custody, guardianship or welfare of, or access to, a child. The amendment before the chamber tonight slightly widens the jurisdiction of judicial registrars to say that, whilst there is this one limit on their power, it is not so limited as to exclude them from dealing with matters prior to the final hearing, in other words, an urgent order or some sort of interlocutory proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: This seems to us to be a reasonable proposition, so reasonable that we promoted it in the Senate. It was as a result of the very constructive contributions of Senators Durack and Walters that the Government finally adopted the position and the points of view that were put. I was rather entertained to see the Press release of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) yesterday which talked about this proposal as if it had been a government initiative when, of course, it was initiated by the coalition in the Senate. We have supported the broad thrust of the Government's moves, sometimes referred to as `renovation' of the Family Court. After the Bill was initially introduced the Senate dealt with this issue of the relationship between judicial registrars and registrars. Without going into the details of amendment No. 7, which will be considered by us in a moment, I note that it is, of course, related to amendment No. 5 because, in a sense, when read together the two amendments give us a graded, as it were, hierarchy of jurisdiction for the various officers within the Family Court.

The coalition took the view that it was reasonable for registrars and judicial registrars-I might say that judicial registrars are people with very considerable qualifications-to be the subject of some devolution of jurisdiction. This was on the basis that their exercise of jurisdiction came within the immediate supervision and confines of the Family Court. We thought that on that basis the Government's proposals for devolution of jurisdiction to registrars and judicial registrars was sensible. We support the Senate's amendment. We accept the refinement of that coalition initiative in the Senate-that refinement being introduced by the Attorney-General tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to rise again to support the thrust of the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. I am pleased that the Senate has sent the Bill back with what I consider to be only minor amendments. I am only a little concerned that it has taken this long to get the Bill through; that the Senate took so long to debate it. The Bill represents an attempt, at least by the Government, to provide a speedy resolution of Family Court of Australia proceedings in regard to the more routine and formal matters presently clogging the Family Court system. Whilst I understand that the delays are continually being reduced, I believe that it is imperative that those delays be kept to an absolute minimum for the reasons I will explain later. Of course, the main impact of the Bill is to confer on the Family Court judges jurisdiction in certain areas which at present can be exercised only by the Federal Court of Australia. The jurisdiction can be conferred only by direct reference from the Federal Court. Originating proceedings must be filed in the Federal Court Registry.

—Order! I hope that the honourable member for Bowman is not going to rehearse the second reading speech. What we are dealing with at present is amendment No. 5 circulated by the Attorney-General. This is an amendment to the Senate's amendments. The matter before the Committee at present is consideration of amendment No. 5, which proposes to change certain parts of clause 9 on page 3 of the Bill. We are not debating the ramifications of all the amendments to the Family Law Act which are proposed by this legislation.

—I understand that. The question of the judicial registrars which the amendments refer to is something which I wanted to talk about, particularly in view of the fact that the Attorney-General has suggested an amendment which will give the judicial registrars the power to handle interim orders in emergency situations. SPEECH.PARA: As I said, I believe that in many respects it is a pity that these amendments have come from the Senate after a debate which took into account mainly the question of wigs and gowns. I think I mentioned this matter on the occasion of the last debate on this Bill. I make particular reference to it because it seems to me that an inordinate amount of time was taken up in the Senate debating the question of wigs and gowns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that we are going to have too many references to wigs and gowns; we might have references to access to children and other matters related to clause 9.
—I generally support the thrust of the amendment moved by the Attorney-General. I am quite happy to support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendment, as amended, agreed to.
Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen) proposed:
That Senate amendments Nos 6 to 20 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say a couple of things about clauses 8, 9, 10 and 15. Clause 8 as it has come from the Senate relates to the power of courts of summary jurisdiction-most often referred to as magistrates courts-to grant the dissolution of marriage. Basically courts of summary jurisdiction under this new clause, this amendment to the law, will be able to handle those situations after being prescribed by regulation of the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We have taken the view in the coalition right from the word go that it is inappropriate to transfer divorces into the magistrates court. We believe that there is a role for a specialist family court. Whilst we share the Government's view that it is sensible to expand the matters that might come before judges and before the Family Court of Australia and thereby, to use an often used term, `bring them back closer into the judicial mainstream', and whilst we have a view which is in general to support a closer relationship between the Federal Court of Australia and the Family Court, it is our view that the quickie divorce in the magistrates court is not the way to go and we therefore register our opposition to clause 8-magistrates court divorces.

Clauses 9 and 10 relate to the jurisdiction of the magistrates courts in respect of defended property matters. To put the matter in some perspective, originally the Government had the concept that the jurisdiction would be whatever the jurisdiction was for the magistrates court in regard to a debt. If a person owed somebody $40,000 and he could get it back in the magistrates court, then that would be the limit. That did not seem to us to be a sensible idea because there could be all sorts of jurisdictional problems across State borders and different figures around Australia. So we suggested the sum of $10,000. It seems that what has happened is that the Australian Democrats have come in and tried to find some compromise because after we suggested $10,000, the Government realised the folly of its ways and suggested $20,000. The Democrats said, `Oh, we have got a wonderful compromise to bring the two parties together and the jurisdiction will be $10,000, but $20,000 if you own a car'. I think the whole thing is meaningless because really this jurisdiction is up to $20,000. How many Australians do not own a car? When does a person have to own a car, according to this, to create jurisdiction? If I am an applicant and I want to get into the magistrates court and my property is worth up to $20,000, do I get jurisdiction by going down to the local wreckers, buying a car for $50 and putting it in the front yard of the matrimonial home? The whole thing is just a device. It will be seen as a device and it will be used as a device. If the Government wanted $20,000, I do not know why it just did not go for $20,000. It would be a lot easier instead of all these words about net value and gross value for cars. Quite frankly, I do not think that--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not going to work.

—It will not work. Solicitors will say, `If you want to go to the magistrates court buy a $50 car from the wreckage yard'. That is what they will say. Then they will probably charge $200 for giving the advice to create the jurisdiction. This is just an example where the Government has not got any control as to what is going on. It does not seem to have any firm idea. We have now got amendments on top of the amendments coming from the Senate. When this Bill went to the Senate the Government introduced a lot more amendments. Quite frankly, this Bill is a good example of how not to introduce legislation into Australian law. This is not the way it should be done; it is not being done well. Quite frankly, it reflects very poorly indeed on the Government. I am glad that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is getting some advice on whether what I have said is right or wrong. It is a matter that I have raised before, and I will be interested to hear what he has to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Lastly, I wish to say something about robing. The history of robing is very entertaining. As I understand it, the Attorney-General told Caucus that he had a proposal which would mean that in future Family Court judges would be able to wear robes. The lefties in the Caucus said that they would not agree to it. So the Bill was presented to the House without containing the robing provision. When the Bill went to the Senate the coalition parties said that judges should not be prohibited from robing. In other words, we said that if they want to wear robes they ought to be entitled to do so. The Senate took up the view that we initiated. The Bill has now come back to the House of Representatives. It is very convenient for the Attorney-General that the Senate has amended the Bill in this respect because he will be able to say to Caucus, `It is not me; it is the Senate'. So, in the end, we will be allowing Family Court judges the benefit of robing. It is a sensible measure.

One judge said to me, `If you want a layman's description of why judges should wear robes, let me tell you this very short story. One day when the people came into court to appear before me and we were all set to go, the applicant husband stood up and said, ``I am not starting until the real judge arrives''.' That is the expectation that people have as to how judges should look. Why should they not have that expectation? It is a long tradition of ours that judges be robed. It is just part and parcel of maintaining the authority of the court. I think it would not be a bad idea, either, if at some stage the carpenters were sent in to the Family Court to build a bit of a pedestal on which the judges could sit, because I think when people go into the Family Court they want to look up at a real judge, a person that they recognise to be a judge, and they want to see that judge sitting in a position of authority. It is not just a matter of symbols and signs; it is a matter of providing the proper trappings that go with the authority of that office. It is a very important office.

Many judges in the Family Court-it is a very big jurisdiction-do a very good job and work hard to implement the laws of this land and to look after the interests of those who, for one reason or another, sadly appear before them in a case involving the dissolution of a marriage. So a judge of the Family Court is a person of very considerable influence and authority. I think this robing provision is symbolic and it is important in terms of the authority of the court and the respect that we as a community ought to pay to the Family Court judges. Of course, at the same time those judges are moving into some Federal jurisdiction, and judges of the Federal Court of Australia wear robes. This amendment is part of the matching process.

I understand that when these matters were raised originally the Attorney hoped that he might be able to take his proposals further. However, there were certain blockages to that occurring. At the same time, he did not want to retain the status quo. The coalition agrees with the broad thrust of his proposals. One cannot achieve everything overnight, but one can certainly take some steps in the right direction. I think in broad terms this Bill deals with some of the very difficult issues that face the Family Court. With the recent appointment of Mr Justice Nicholson, which appointment we very strongly support-we give him our greatest possible support and encouragement-I think we will see the Family Court go forward with some very real support from the Parliament for the important work that it does.

I conclude by saying that the Senate, contrary to what was said by the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca), has picked up many of the very significant issues that relate to the jurisdiction of the Family Court. The measures contained in clause 5, which I mentioned briefly today, are the result of a coalition initiative, with the Government coming in with an amendment at the last moment. Be that as it may, I think those measures effect a reasonable compromise in what I regard as a difficult matter but one of great significance. I put on record again my thanks and those of the coalition to those senators who made contributions to the passage of this legislation, but in particular Senator Durack and Senator Walters for the work that they have done on this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating clauses 6 to 20 of the Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Bill. These clauses raise a whole series of questions which are important, despite the fact that emphasis was given last night in the Senate to lesser changes in the Bill-matters such as robing, the limits set on jurisdiction in the magistrates court, and even the use of titles such as `judicial registrar' and `master'. The question of gowns is pretty much in the eye of the client, the person who steps into the court. It has become recognised over time that if a sufficient number of people are impressed by gowning then it is a psychological crutch that ought to be taken into account. For some time the debate has been about bringing the Family Court of Australia closer to the people by having officers of the court not robed. Nevertheless, there is a fuller recognition now that some robing has an impact on those people who enter the court and that is being taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes that will be brought in by this Bill are critical to the more efficient running of the Family Court. The shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), raised the question of whether we will retain a specialist Family Court. I submit that the critical changes, which are that we hand over some matters to the magistrates court, that the Family Court picks up some matters from the Federal Court, and that judicial registrars and registrars are allowed to have certain powers delegated to them are totally in line with all of those things we seek to achieve through the Family Law Act and are entirely consistent with the workings of the Family Court. The problem is-and this has been well acknowledged-that Family Court judges work in an extremely narrow area, an area fraught with a great deal of emotional stress. The intention of the Bill and of the amendments is to attempt to have those judges work slightly more widely by picking up references from the Federal Court-perhaps taxation or consumer affairs matters. That is an excellent move.

There was some debate previously and in the Senate last night that there may be confusion as to how a matter is picked up from the Federal Court and given to the Family Court. The sensible changes proposed by these amendments are that the chief judges of the Federal Court and the Family Court will decide between themselves which matters shall be heard. The critical element that has been raised here is that the Family Court simply cannot pick up new matters from the Federal Court; they must be referred to the Family Court. There is no sense in which the Family Court is encroaching on matters that were formerly dealt with by the Federal Court.

I now move to the jurisdiction of the magistrates court. In my State of Queensland the Family Court has only two operating courts, one in Brisbane and one in Townsville, so it is not easy for people in country areas in a very decentralised State to have easy access to the court. If more matters are able to be picked up in the magistrates court by dint of these changes, I think it would be a marvellous thing for such a decentralised State. I admit that the debate about the monetary value or level which can be heard in the magistrates court almost got to the point of the last dollar and cent and the last hubcap. Nevertheless, an agreement has been made. That agreement certainly satisfies me that sufficient business will now be going to the magistrates court.

The essential notion of a hierarchy of decision makers has been preserved here. There has always been the judge and the registrar, and the court counsellors-although we are not specifically debating the counsellors tonight. That hierarchy has been preserved. We have judges who will now be able to range more widely in their interests, and I predict that that will mean that we will have more applicants for the position, because I suggest that it is not easy to sit as a judge in the Family Court for a decade or two in a very narrow area of jurisdiction. We have solved that problem. However, we now have judicial registrars, who will be delegated a great number of powers. I know that there was concern as to how great or otherwise their powers would be, but I believe that those problems have also been solved. Of course, for some years now the registrars themselves have been delegated a great number of powers and they have been delegated further powers in these changes.

So the hierarchy, as predicted, has been preserved and the magistrates courts are now part of this Family Court system. The Family Court system itself has been preserved but it has been broadened to satisfy the needs of the key operators, that is, the judges; it has been broadened to satisfy greater access by allowing certain matters to be heard in the magistrates court; and it has been speeded up in the sense that so many minor matters can now be picked up by judicial registrars. So I am in complete agreement with the matters raised by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), and I sincerely and firmly believe that the Bill itself, which will soon be passed, will make the Family Court far more efficient and effective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add two or three comments to the debate that has already taken place this evening. I was inspired by one or two matters-firstly, with the preoccupation and the glee that were directed towards the choice of again wearing wigs in the courts. I noticed that my friend the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), who is by profession a lawyer, placed great importance on the fact that the Senate had restored the right of Family Court judges to wear wigs. He also cited the story of a couple who were in the court where allegedly the husband was not prepared to allow proceedings to start-I remind the honourable member for Flinders that the husband would not have had any say in it anyhow-because there was not somebody in the court wearing a wig. I am quite sure that the person who was appearing before the court was only having a go and was by no means serious. When I look at the hairline of the honourable member for Flinders, I can well understand his excitement about the possibility of the restoration of wigs.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make one or two other points on this occasion. We get excited with legislation such as this, which will expand the role of Family Court judges. The thing which continues to disturb, perturb and concern me greatly is the lack of will of this Parliament to come to grips with rewriting the Family Law Act. It is not a matter of whether judges should wear wigs or not that is of concern to the vast majority of Australian people who have to face the Family Court. There is a complete lack of trust in the system, a belief that justice will go one way or the other, but for those who appear before it, half the parties-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is not going to have a wide-ranging debate on the Family Law Act. The Committee has before it a number of amendments relating to specific parts of a piece of legislation, and I think it might be better if we kept to those rather than had a wide-ranging discussion on the Family Law Act.
—I agree with you completely, Mr Chairman.
—I am glad you do, and I will now make sure you continue to do that.

—Thank you, sir. One of the amendments concerns what goes on in front of Family Court judges. That is very relevant to proceedings in the court. I plead, as a layman, that my logic is impeccable. The Minister at the table, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), has given me a sign. I am not sure whether he was indicating that I should speak for only a couple of minutes or whether he was indicating something else. I will keep my comments brief. But I do make this plea: the Parliament has to come to grips with a rewriting of the Family Law Act.
