SPEECH.PARA: I heard the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) say today that the Attorney-General is considering a new career in 1989 or 1990. He made those comments in the Minister's absence foreshadowing his departure before the next election. It is also impeccable logic for a Labor man to be getting out at that time. One of the things that could be emblazoned in the Attorney-General's name--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moreton might stick to the clauses before the Committee. I do not see anything about the future of the Attorney-General in any of these clauses.

—I only wish to mention that he is a reformer and he would cap a remarkable career by coming to grips with the changes to the Family Law Act which I advocate on behalf of many people. Mr Chairman, you are also a lawyer by occupation, are you not? No wonder you are being so protective of your own.
—Order! The honourable member for Moreton will not reflect upon the Chair in such a fashion. The Chair may have been responsible for many sins in his life, but never the sin of being a lawyer.

—That is very reassuring. But the point I would like to make whilst on my feet, and perhaps as chairman of the jury at this point, is that justice for the average person is out of reach financially. It is only the poor who get legal aid, or the rich who can truly afford it, who get justice in this country. The second thing by which the Attorney-General could cap his career with glory, would be to ensure that justice is within reach of people and that when the changes to the Family Law Act come in, the judges are given a framework within which to work so that they can dispatch decisions that will bring more satisfaction to the aggrieved parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) and the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) for their contributions. There is no question of any farewells as I intend to stay. But the point at issue-the honourable member for Moreton is right in saying this-is that this is a difficult jurisdiction. This is a problem for this nation. We have to try to have more conciliation and mediation so that the parties to not have litigation.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Moreton raised a valid point. Most of our legal aid now goes into the Family Court area despite the fact that only about 5 per cent of matters are litigated. Fortunately, after some help by way of conciliation and counsellors, some 95 per cent of parties are able to come to some arrangement about the problems that they have had in their domestic lives. They are parties who have married or who have lived together and naturally have a feeling about each other which is not the same feeling that they had when they were married or first lived together. In other words, there is an irretrievable breakdown. The honourable member should understand the problems of lawyers. They should not be criticised because they are the one group of people who are trying to help solve the problems of families who are in disarray. Further, no blame should be attached to the fact that there has been a breakdown. Those problems to which I refer relate to access, maintenance, custody and property division.

The Institute of Family Studies has clearly shown that where divorce takes place both parties are in a poorer economic circumstance. In other words, the income will not be sufficient to maintain two separate households. Unfortunately, the children pay the penalty for that. I accept what the honourable member is saying. Honourable members will recall the considerable problems the Parliament experienced in trying to agree on the legislation. It almost took years to get it through. All honourable members believed they knew all about divorce and about families. The issues vary, of course. The real issue is that, if the children were asked, they would be happy if the parents could stay together. Unfortunately, as honourable members know, the children do not always get a chance to have their way, and there is that problem and difficulty.

More than $40m is spent on legal aid in the family law area. That is a substantial sum of money. However, I appreciate the remarks of the honourable member for Moreton. I am sure we are all trying to work on the basis of how we can improve the Family Court. These amendments will help considerably because we have an idea of how we can coordinate and enhance the court's ability to deal with matters more speedily, at the same time avoiding, if we can, unnecessary litigation. Perhaps more resources will have to be made available in the form of conciliation and mediation centres where parties can be encouraged to talk about settlement procedures and not resort to litigation. I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his remarks.

The honourable member for Flinders was concerned that what are called uncontested matters could be dealt with by magistrates. I do not want to criticise the honourable member's approach. However, I want to make it clear that 85 per cent of maintenance matters, involving contested issues as to what financial arrangements will be made, are now dealt with by magistrates. They are not trivial matters. On the contrary, they can be difficult. Pursuant to State legislation, magistrates must also deal with neglected children, domestic violence and juvenile delinquency. Magistrates are not incompetent people. Many of them have a very clear understanding of family concerns because they are located in the areas in which the families live. One problem in the family law jurisdiction is to provide people in outlying districts, particularly in remote areas of Queensland and other areas, with the opportunity to have their matter's dealt with expeditiously if there are no contentious issues involved. That is not to say they are quickie divorces. That is a damaging description which suggests that it will not be regarded as a proper hearing of the matter. Magistrates are very experienced and well qualified. They realise what is evidence, and if the evidence is that there has been an irretrievable breakdown, and that satisfactory arrangements have been made about maintenance, custody and property division-that is, where the parties are in agreement-I cannot for the life of me understand why that would be deemed to be a trivial matter or a quickie divorce simply because the parties, after some intelligent discussion, have come to some arrangement that they each agreed to. If the agreement turned out to be not satisfactory from the point of view, despite having consented to it, an appeal mechanism to the Family Court is available.

Family Court judges, on circuit, do not often visit remote areas of Queensland and Western Australia. Parties in such places have an opportunity to have their matters dealt with by magistrates on what I believe is a reasonable basis.

Finally, I turn to the subject of robing. The honourable member for Flinders was right in suggesting that we might be able to accept robing. I am anxious that this court not be deemed to be inferior, although I was not thinking of robing in that sense. I am anxious to move the court toward a Federal jurisdiction where it is deemed to be the equivalent of, and not inferior to, any other Federal court. We do not want this court to have the ability to deal with divorce and to have no legal capacity to deal with any other matter. We want to say that they are fully qualified practitioners who have earned their spurs by being trained as good lawyers and appearing in courts, only in the divorce jurisdiction. Those who have practised know that that is not a jurisdiction one readily gallops into on the basis that there is a big career in it. It is just part of the normal work one has to do. A lot of challenging work is done in equity, in common law, in taxation and in trade practices. Judges of this court are fully qualified to handle those matters, as they have appeared in those courts as counsel. They have the capacity to be involved in the decision-making process because they understand the law.

There probably has been a misunderstanding that, by the use of the title `family law', we have created an apparatus where the family can be put back together. That has been a false expectation. This is the divorce court. We gave it the title `Family Court'. By the time people get to this court there has been irretrievable breakdown. The parties have been apart. It is almost impossible to talk about reconciliation. Because we use the words `compassion' and `particular skills' the profession has a reluctance to accept appointments to the Family Court. I am anxious to see the court moved up in grade to show that judges of the Family Court are well qualified to deal with a number of matters. If they are able to deal with matters of taxation, bankruptcy or trade practices, that would be a good thing; and of course then they would be robed. That is the other factor.

That did not go down too well in some sections of my Party. Some honourable members legitimately feel that it is detracting from the ability, in this family dispute area, to have the parties come to some arrangement unless the judge appears the same as the parties-in other words, is not wearing a wig and gown. The judges do not object to that. The real issue that has not been mentioned is that the judges feel more secure and more anonymous if they are robed. That is their reasoning, and I accept it. I have not challenged the amendment moved in the Senate. I think it will probably work. There has been a real problem with security of this court. At least one judge and the wife of another judge have been murdered. A number of bomb threats have been made. In Sydney there were 26 bomb threats to the court last year. This meant complete evacuation of the premises and closure of the whole building. I do not know why this issue has been bedevilling Sydney, but it has been a problem for us. I think we will avoid that by getting new premises in Sydney. We now propose acquiring a site, but it will take a little time. If the problem can be alleviated by the judges having some anonymity by wearing robes-which they feel is their right-I agree with the proposition. That is why we are doing it. In the long run it will save us a lot of heartache because enormous amounts of money are spent on security of judges.

When the original Bill was debated in Parliament a long while ago no-one dealt with this matter because no-one thought it would be an issue. It has not worried any other court except this one. I can understand that the parties in dispute feel that they are the best judges of who should have the property or custody and who ought to pay maintenance. One will not convince the losing parties with decisions that they feel are not correct. So one gets feelings of anger and revenge and they act against the judicial position. That is why we have to give more support to this court. We need to understand the worry caused to the judges from the evidence given by the parties. We need to understand that this is a court, basically, of hatred and revenge if cases are fought out to the finish. Judges get no marks at all for having to make decisions, yet they have to do it. We have to support their position. We have to do that by encouraging more conciliation, consultation and mediation to try to get the parties to understand that, if a marriage has broken down, some arrangements must be made that require judicial decisions.

Having said that, I turn to the other matter that the honourable member for Flinders raised-I am glad he raised it-concerning an amendment moved in the Senate to make the jurisdictional limit $10,000 and, if a motor car is involved, $20,000. I cannot for the life of me understand why a motor car has to be dragged into the middle of a family law dispute when the question is one of property entitlement. The Government always wanted magistrates-I must emphasise that this matter is related to the jurisdiction of magistrates courts-to have the same jurisdiction in this area as they have in the States for debt resolution. They have a jurisdiction to deal with matters relating to debt, in some cases up to $40,000. We are anxious for the magistrates to have the same jurisdiction over property as they do under their State jurisdictions, which would vary. We suggested $40,000. Some States said, `No, that is too high; we would rather the limit be $20,000'. I can tell the Committee that the State Attorneys-General would agree that $20,000 is a reasonable figure from their point of view because it would not affect the jurisdiction they now give to their magistrates across Australia.

I understand that the honourable member for Petrie would be happy to pick up the real thrust of what has been said here. Why are we bedevilled by an amendment which brings a motor car into consideration and escalates the jurisdictional limit by $10,000? I think it is better to leave out the motor car and provide for the $10,000 escalation. The honourable member for Petrie has been very keen to help us in this regard and proposes to move an amendment, to Senate amendment No. 9-and, as a natural corollary, to amendment No. 20-which would have the effect of omitting the reference to a motor car and deleting the words `$10,000 and, where a motor vehicle is involved, $20,000' and inserting `$20,000'. That would get us back to the figure everybody thinks we could go to if a motor car is involved. I think we ought to forget the motor car and talk about the ability to solve these matters, which are relatively minor in value, in magistrates courts. If we can come to some satisfactory arrangement about that, we will make even more progress as a result of having the matter debated here this evening. I thank all honourable members for their contributions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) coming to that very specific matter, referred to by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), I wish just to say in respect of the magistrates courts jurisdiction that basically the whole country is against the Government on this matter-except for the Australian Democrats. That is why it has been able to get the quickie divorces through the Senate. We have a different starting point on this issue. We can talk about the congestion in the magistrates courts. The honourable member for Petrie said, `We will be right in the magistrates courts'. He ought to go to some of the magistrates courts and see the congestion. There are other means by which that issue can be addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: I just go back to the fundamental issue. The fact is that, we have always followed the principle that, if a person wanted to bring the solemn contract of marriage to an end, it should be dealt with only by a superior court of record. That has been fundamental in the attitude that we as a coalition have adopted to marriage as a fundamental institution in our society. We believe that to take the matter into the magistrates courts is to adopt the wrong stance. Our position is not based on some attack on the capacities of magistrates-of course it is not. Our concern is the way in which we as a society look to marriage as a fundamental institution. It is a fundamental institution; it is a building block upon which this society is based. We say that the Government's practical reasons for the transfer are, quite frankly, transparent and that the basic principle before us is such that the dissolution of marriage should be undertaken by a superior court of record. We have such a court in the Family Court of Australia, and that task ought to be undertaken by it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In relation to Senate amendment No. 9 I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit `$10,000 and, where a motor vehicle is involved, $20,000', substitute `$20,000'.
In relation to Senate amendment No. 20 I move:
Omit `$10,000 and, where a motor vehicle is involved, $20,000', substitute `$20,000'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one query. Does the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) include in his amendments No. 10 of the schedule of amendments from the Senate? That relates to the subsection that defines gross and net values-the equity in the alleged motor vehicle.
—I do not think it applies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall state the coalition's position, so that it is absolutely clear. Our view is that the jurisdictional limit in magistrates courts in respect of property matters ought to be $10,000. The position we are in at the moment with this proposal is that by a device of owning a vehicle or when there is some involvement of a motor vehicle, one can have the jurisdiction raised to $20,000. We attack that provision on the basis that just as a matter of how something is drafted, it is plainly ridiculous, which I think has been the motive behind the sensible further amendment of the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns). We understand the amendment and welcome it to the extent that it finally brings some clarity to the issue as to what the jurisdictional limit should be.

SPEECH.PARA: May I say that the $1,000 figure was introduced in 1975 in the Family Law Bill. That figure has been increased to $3,000 or $4,000 after inflation. From the coalition's point of view we have been prepared to say that the doubling of the figure, and taking inflation into account, to bring the amount to $10,000 is a reasonable compromise to the proposal that was originally brought forward by the Government. In our view the Family Court is a place where matters of substantial dispute, relating to assets that are substantial to the parties, ought to be dealt with by the Family Court. As someone once said, the issue then is not a matter of division of property but the division of poverty.

We see no reason why people who have assets of between $10,000 and $20,000 ought to be treated differently from members of other sectors in the community-treated differently simply because of their level of assets. Once the figure approaches $20,000, quite frankly one is talking about the family home. I think that is where the meat of this matter lies. The Opposition says that once one gets to that level, it becomes too high for magistrates courts. The matter should be taken to the Family Court to be dealt with. In our view, $10,000 is a sensible compromise to the proposal that the Government originally took. I am disappointed that the Government did not take it up, but the amendment now provides, at least, for a clear division of positions for when the matter returns to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) for his assistance in moving the amendments. They will tidy up the issue. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) is still anxious that magistrates be confined to the $10,000 jurisdiction because when one approaches the $20,000 jurisdiction one is dealing with the matrimonial home. I very much doubt that in practice. I would be very surprised that anyone could buy a block of land for $20,000, let alone a matrimonial home. The point at issue is not that we are creating an additional jurisdiction in terms of limit. The States at the present time give magistrates jurisdiction up to that amount.
—It varies.
—It varies and it goes as high as $40,000 in some other cases.
—It is down to $5,000 in some States.

—I make the point that magistrates are also dealing with maintenance cases in these matters. Indeed, 85 per cent of all maintenance cases, which are of some significance, are delegated to magistrates because they have the capacity and ability to understand financial arrangements, particularly from the point of view of dividing income. Nobody objects to their capacity to do that. In the circumstances, I think it is reasonable. The honourable member for Flinders acknowledges that the amendment certainly tidies up the provision. But I think it is drawing a long bow to suggest that it is all right for the amount to be $10,000 but that it is not correct for it to be $20,000. I cannot see merit in what the honourable member says.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Amendments Nos 6 to 20, as amended, agreed to.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 March, on motion by Mr West:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the title indicates, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 1988 seeks minor changes to the procedure for conducting referendums at the Federal level. The legislation is based on a continuing series of changes to the electoral system arising from the Government's efforts to implement the recommendations of reports of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. This gives us an opportunity to consider how related recommendations of the Committee have worked in practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Since referenda are used only in the Federal sphere for constitutional amendment, this Bill should be considered in the light of the possibility that the Government will this year present the Australian public with a series of questions at an unwarranted referendum. The stated aim of this Bill is to ensure consistency between the existing Act and the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Over the past five years, the Electoral Act has undergone significant changes which involve a new system of Senate balloting, an extension of the size of both Houses and the introduction of public funding for political parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is a disgrace.

—That is a disgrace, as my honourable friend reminds me. An integral part of those changes was public disclosure of campaign donations. This is a matter of such embarrassment to members on the other side that I will try right now to refrain from further mention of that topic. However, I do not promise to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party of Australia, as a matter of record, opposed many of those changes. A larger Federal parliament was, and is, an unnecessary burden on taxpayers. It is also pertinent to ask why we, as members of political parties in this place, should vote taxpayers' money to fund the campaigns of our party organisations. The Liberal Party was, and is, opposed to disclosure of campaign donations. However, we have at least the virtue of adhering to the law as it now stands, which is more than can be said for the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales.

Few of the major changes to the Electoral Act offered any real benefits to our electoral system. They were changes for the benefit of politicians and not for the taxpaying public. Nevertheless, this Bill represents less significant but probably more useful amendments to the procedures to be applied to referenda. Despite the suggestions of the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) that this Bill is part of a coherent package of electoral legislation, it is clear that we are still plugging gaps and omissions from previous legislation. The reports of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform have dealt with long lists of suggested changes from the Electoral Commission and other interested parties. Some of these might have value but, when it comes to the electoral system, stability and certainty are of definite value. It should not be necessary to introduce constant changes to the electoral system.

This Bill deals with the procedure for referenda, as I have already indicated. Referenda play a very important role in our Federal political system. They represent the only means of achieving alteration of our Constitution. The overriding guidance for the conduct of referenda is found in section 128 of the Constitution. That section places the responsibility for proposing constitutional changes firmly in the hands of this Parliament. It is a responsibility which, I regret to say, has been abrogated by this Government from time to time. Proposals for constitutional change should be carefully and extensively considered in this place. The Constitution places on such proposals the more stringent requirement of an absolute majority in each House of Parliament before an amendment can be put to the people.

The machinery provisions amended in this Bill could well be tested before this year is out. The Government and some of the dependent zealots with whom it surrounds itself have sought to make the bicentenary year of 1988 the year of constitutional change. We have been assaulted by a barrage of short-sighted, often just wrong, assertions about the supposed failings and shortcomings of the Constitution. What seems to unify these calls for an all-encompassing referendum is that they all suggest that the Commonwealth Government needs more and greater powers, and also that ambiguities in the division of powers with the States should be resolved in favour of the Commonwealth. The only cause for extensive constitutional change rather than sensible alteration come from people who are centralists in the true sense of the word. They seek either powers for Federal Governments which now reside with the States, or powers which no Australian governments have never exercised.

Given the extent and importance of the constitutional amendments suggested by people who are acting with a brief from the Government, it would have been hoped that concrete proposals would by now be before this Parliament. Certainly proper scrutiny of proposed amendments will be extremely difficult in the Budget session of this Parliament. The detailed machinery of the procedure for referenda becomes irrelevant if the Parliament cannot properly consider proposals that are to be put to the people. The reason this has occurred is the use by the Government of an unelected, unrepresentative statutory authority, in the form of the Constitutional Commission, as the vehicle for the Government's plans for so-called reforms. Again, the Government places the Parliament in a marginal role where the constitutional provisions for referenda stipulate that the Parliament is the central body in facilitating alteration of the Constitution. If referenda are to have an important place in Federal politics, then so must the role of Parliament, and debate in this place must become much more the basis of the authority and actions of government.

Clause 6 of the Bill seeks a wider distribution of the Yes and No cases in a referendum. This is a laudable objective. The reason for presenting a Yes and No case has always been to ensure that the people of Australia are as well informed as possible about the decisions they will have to make. People are always cautious when considering things with long term effects, such as changes to the Constitution. The evidence suggests that Australians have always acted prudently when presented with all the available arguments in a referendum case. Sensible change has often been adopted, whilst the extension of the power of the Commonwealth Government has usually been rejected. Even during the heat of war in 1944, the electors refused to grant extensive constitutional powers to the then Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government. Given the opportunity for open debate, electors have discriminated in their judgments of the merits of different proposals presented at that time.

With this Bill the Government slightly extends the availability of information for public debate, yet in its other actions it has attempted to stifle debate about its intentions at referenda. That applies to past referenda and to propositions which were floated but never put to the electorate. This Government has used the most recent report of the Constitutional Commission as an excuse for not laying proposals before the public for debate. Ministers have made it clear that only very few of the dozens of amendments proposed by the advisory committees to the Constitutional Commission will be put to a referendum this year. That begs the question: which amendments? If the Government is, as it claims, genuinely interested in democracy and openness, it will tell us as soon as possible which constitutional amendments it plans to put to a referendum or referenda. It should allow full debate on the subjects of those referenda in this House and that should be given priority over the rest of the Government's legislative program. Such concrete measures would secure the integrity of our electoral system a good deal more than the limited but constructive measures contained in this Bill.

The Federal Government and the Australian Labor Party throughout Australia like to talk about the virtues of electoral reform. The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill reflects some of that interest in changing the electoral system for referenda. But the ALP has often paid only lip service to the integrity of the electoral system. Change is not necessarily reform, and Australian electoral systems have had many changes for the worse.

The gerrymander and malapportionment are as much features of Labor Party State governments tampering with the electoral system as they are of any other government. Examples abound of electoral distributions which do not yield proportionality between the number of votes and the number of seats held. On some occasions this is a consequence of the diversity of the country and on others the advantageous design of the system by political parties. It is because of this that any changes to the electoral and referendum legislation which are not absolutely necessary or clearly reinforce existing provisions can be seen as offering some advantage to one party, group or individual. Small parties saw the changes to the Senate ballot paper as putting them at a disadvantage. It is now clear that public disclosure of campaign donations has disadvantaged the New South Wales division of the Australian Labor Party, which seems to have difficulty adhering to its own laws. No wonder-it was always bad law! It is a textbook example of unnecessary tampering with an electoral system which had served the people of Australia very well.

Changes to the electoral system should be adopted cautiously. They require careful consideration such as that given by the Senate Select Committee on Electoral Reform, but it should not be exclusively the careful consideration of the Select Committee. Changes should not pass through this House without comment, extensive consideration and debate. Similarly, the Australian Electoral Commission, which oversees the operation of the legislation which is amended by this Bill, should be subject to the rigorous scrutiny of the Parliament. Recent suggestions-acknowledged, as I understand it, by the Electoral Commissioner-of inefficiency in the conduct of the last Federal election are very disturbing. At all stages electoral and referendum legislation should strictly reinforce the serious nature of the responsibility which officers and employees of the Commission bear. It is the task of the legislation to provide a fair system for elections and referenda to represent accurately the decisions of individual Australians. We should be careful to avoid legislation simply to make the life of the Electoral Commission, Electoral Commissioners or politicians any easier. Law designed to make the life of parliamentarians easy without benefit to the population generally must never colour our judgment.

In summary, this Bill will be accepted by the Opposition as it completes the work of earlier amendments to the Electoral Act. However, as I have already said, it should be treated with caution. The Government should have, and demonstrate, more respect for the referendum procedure. Above all, it should not subject the voters of Australia to perpetual change of the electoral system. If the electoral system really needs radical changes, the legitimacy of past elections must in some small way be questionable. I hope that this Bill will represent the last of a long series of changes which produce unnecessary turmoil at the foundations of our Australian democracy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of my remarks I will try to answer some of the points made by the learned and honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and by the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), who has also contributed to this debate. Naturally enough I support the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 1988. This Bill has come before the House to remove inconsistencies which exist between the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. Back in December 1986 the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform published its second report entitled The Operation During the 1984 General Election of the 1983-84 Amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation. This was a well researched and well written report, and the Joint Select Committee certainly deserves praise from both sides of the House for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The report contained 156 recommendations. It is to the credit of this Government and to the credit of the Opposition that they in turn accepted many of those recommendations. It was the Government's intention, having agreed that there should be legislation to give effect to the acceptable recommendations, that those recommendations be introduced in stages. As honourable members are aware, the Commonwealth Electoral Act of 1918 was amended prior to the July 1987 federal election to give effect to those recommendations it was considered essential to implement before the election. The Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill 1987, which contained those amendments, did however, as I have said earlier, create inconsistencies between the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. Thus it is to remove those inconsistencies that the Bill before us has been drafted.

I turn to the clauses of the Bill, because it is important to look at least at some of the clauses to find out why these changes are necessary. Clause 4 inserts two new sections after section 3 of the principal Act. The first, 3a, relates to ensuring that overseas polling officials are subject to the same penalties for neglect of duty as officials in Australia. The Opposition agrees with that amendment. The Committee discovered that there was a major problem in the operation of overseas postal voting. There appeared to be a reluctance by assistant returning officers at Australia's overseas posts to heed instructions for the speedy dispatch of votes to Australia after polling day. This led to many votes delivered to assistant returning officers at overseas posts being delayed in reaching Australia.

I believe that one of the problems here is not the incompetence of those assistant returning officers but the other work pressures on them. In an overseas post many duties are placed on the officials working there. There is also a lack of adequate training in the duties required. I certainly hope that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) will take note of the need to train those in overseas posts who are required to perform these duties. Of course, I recognise that some overseas posts will have only a smattering of votes whilst others will have to deal with many more. However, the point of the exercise is to get recorded votes as expeditiously as possible to Australia after polling day.

The proposed new section 3b has the effect of requiring the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments to comply with the Act to the same extent as other participants in the electoral process. The Australian Electoral Commission rightly drew two incidents in the 1984 election which showed the necessity for legislative action to the attention of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. The first concerns an election advertisement by the Queensland Government. Although authorised by the Premier of that State, and to that extent it complied with section 328 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, no return of election expenditure under section 309 was provided. The Director of Public Prosecutions at that time advised against a prosecution, being of the opinion that the section probably did not bind the Crown in the right of Queensland. However, it begged the question of whether the legislation should be made binding on the Crown.

The second incident concerned the then Commonwealth Department of Education's pamphlet entitled Improving Government Schools-1985 and Beyond. The pamphlet was distributed during the 1984 election campaign, although the Department stated that this was not intended. The pamphlet was not authorised in accordance with subsection 328 (1), and no return under subsection 309 (4) was furnished. The Director of Public Prosecutions advised that the pamphlet was an electoral pamphlet and that, if an ordinary citizen had published it, it would have required authorisation under the Act and an obligation to furnish a return. However, it was a Commonwealth Government advertisement and, as the Act did not bind the Crown in the right of the Commonwealth, there was no breach of either section by its publication.

I welcome also the repeal of the requirement that enrolled voters must live within the division at some time during the three months prior to the poll in order to vote. The honourable member for Gilmore in his remarks raised what I feel was a spurious argument when he suggested that a political party might transfer 200 of its supporters into a marginal electoral in order to affect the result. But we are talking about a referendum; we are not talking about a general election. This is a referendum Bill; so 200 votes would not have the impact that he was suggesting.

Unfortunately, it was found that the three-month rule worked only to disenfranchise those voters who had not correctly maintained their enrolments and were honest enough to admit it. I consider that the greater use of habitation reviews should allow for improved accuracy and reliability of the rolls--
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: International Youth Skill Olympics-New South Wales State Election-Mount Remarkable Area: Fire-Apartheid-National Championships for the Blind-Dinner at South African Embassy

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last fortnight of sittings-specifically on 22 February-I spoke about the twenty-ninth Skill Olympics. The honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) was present in the chamber on that occasion, and you were also in the chamber at that time, Madam Speaker. The Skill Olympics were held at the Darling Harbour Exhibition Centre between 18 and 21 February. Honourable members will recall, hopefully, that the Skill Olympics involved a competition in the trades-vocational skills-with 400 competitors aged 18 to 23 years from 19 nations. Regrettably-and I made the point at the time-the Skill Olympics received very little publicity. I have ventured back into the Parliament to give them another kick along because I think it is a very worthwhile event, not only in itself but in what it represents in terms of Australia's future.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Speaker, you will be pleased to learn that we had some considerable success. I would like to bring to the attention of the House tonight the names of the successful athletes-if we can call them athletes-in the Skill Olympics. In the turning trade section Australia was successful in winning a silver medal. Our competitor in that event was Colin Twigg. In the gas welding section we were successful in winning a bronze medal. Our competitor was Roy Lim, who ran third behind competitors from Ireland and Korea. In the electric welding section we also came third. Our representative was Andrew Barnes, again being placed behind a Korean. This time the Taiwanese entrant came second. In the plumbing section we were awarded a silver medallion. Ken Channon was our entrant. He was placed behind a Korean competitor and in front of a Taiwanese and a United Kingdom entrant. In the industrial electronics section we ran second. Our entrant was Maurice De Jersey, who finished behind a Japanese competitor. In the industrial wiring event we were gold medal winners. Our competitor was Russell Cooper and he was awarded the gold medallion in front of competitors from Germany, Ireland and Taiwan.

We were also successful in the bricklaying section. Our gold medal winner was Stephen Perryman, who finished in front of entrants from France and Germany. In stonemasonry we picked up the silver medal. Congratulations must go to Sean Dibben, running behind a United Kingdom entrant and in front of a Japanese competitor. In the jewellery category a female competitor representing our country won the silver medallion. Congratulations go to Celeste Careedy. She came in behind an Austrian competitor and in front of a Korean. In automotive mechanics we finished in equal first place with the United Kingdom entrant. Our contestant in that section was Devin Flor. In the cookery section we ran third. Our entrant was Muoi Trinh, who finished behind entrants from Switzerland and Liechtenstein. We won our third gold medal in the plant mechanics-heavy machinery-event. It was won by Mark Eddison from Swiss and French competitors respectively.

The point of reading the names of these successful skills athletes into the parliamentary record is to try to gain more prominence, not only now but in the future, for the Skill Olympics. There is a general bipartisan attitude towards raising skill levels in Australia and towards raising educational attainment. We must recognise that not all young Australians will go on to universities and colleges. There will still be an enormous employment demand for skilled trades men and women. For my money-and I am sure I speak with universal acclamation on this point-those young Australians are international heroes, international athletes, of whom we should be proud, along with the Pat Cashs, Allan Borders, our Mean Machine and the like. I congratulate those Australian competitors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to pick up the third of a series of speeches I have made during the adjournment debate on the forthcoming New South Wales State election. Tonight I wish to make a few comments, again, about Independents and the role they play. I focus particularly on the Independent State member for Wollongong, Frank Arkell, who is also the Lord Mayor of Wollongong. It is quite interesting to look at the record of that gentleman, who has represented the seat of Wollongong for the last four years. For example, do honourable members know that during his four years as a member of parliament he has made seven speeches that have lasted a grand total of 1 1/4 hours? Do they know that he missed 208 out of 847 votes during those four years? Do they realise that he has attended Parliament for 75 per cent of his time against an average of all members of 92 per cent?

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite interesting to look at some of the issues in relation to which he has missed the vote. He has missed votes on legislation to create the Brandon Park sportsground in my electorate, which he said he totally supported, on the 1986-87 and on coalmining regulation laws. Yet he says that he stands for the working class and had the hide to go on television last week and say that he was more Labor than Liberal. He missed voting on legislation to limit local government rate increases; measures to protect children from sexual assault; tough new action against drug pedlars, plus 202 other votes.

When he did get to the Parliament on a couple of occasions-I have to give him some credit-he opposed and voted against gun control laws; consumer protection laws for home purchasers and tenants; cheaper rent dispute settlement procedures; industrial protection for outworkers and casual labourers; soil conservation and tax evasion measures; equal treatment for men and women in marriage; and child protection laws.

Those facts-they have been checked from the Hansard of the New South Wales Parliament-stand in stark contrast to the record of his opponent, the Hon. Laurie Kelly, who is the Speaker of the New South Wales Parliament and who, in that capacity, has represented the State seat of Corrimal for the last 20 years in a most astute and practical manner. I suggest that criticisms that Alderman Arkell has levelled at Mr Kelly during the election campaign that he has achieved nothing in the last 20 years are absolute nonsense. I would say also that the rubbish that Alderman Arkell has come out with in suggesting that he and he alone was responsible for creating 10,000 jobs in Illawarra in the last four years, that he and he alone got the grain handling facility, for which, incidentally the Federal and State governments are paying, that he and he alone was responsible for the restructuring of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. steelworks and a number of other such outrageous claims, simply belie the fact that he is a man about whom his own Press person Martin O'Shannessy said, `Alderman Arkell attended Parliament only when he had to'.

Honourable members opposite may well laugh and sing out, but this is in their interests also. I am certain that the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) would take interest in this. Independents prove absolutely nothing in parliaments. They provide nothing, give nothing, owe allegiances to no-one and, as a result, contribute nothing to the electorates in which they locate. Despite Alderman Arkell, the Federal Government and the State Labor Government of Barrie Unsworth have done everything that is right for the people of Wollongong, particularly in the seat of Wollongong. They have done so despite Alderman Arkell. They have done it because the people of Wollongong recognise that the only ones who will look after their interests are people such as Laurie Kelly and the other Labor members that are standing for election on Saturday.

I ask honourable members and the people of Wollongong to have a look at those facts once again, at the appropriate time, and to get behind Laurie Kelly, if they want someone who will be part of a government that can deliver and not someone who mouths off and takes credit for things produced in an electorate that obviously he had nothing to do with. I hope that the people of Wollongong get behind Laurie Kelly on Saturday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer to comments that were made in the House of Representatives at Question Time on 17 February this year when the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) brought to the attention of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) some of the problems that had occurred in his electorate following floods in the township of Cooyar. The honourable member for Fisher pointed out that, tragically, those floods had resulted in the loss of two lives. The Minister generously offered to respond. He indicated that the Commonwealth would reimburse the Queensland Government at the level of at least 50 per cent for grants made to relieve personal hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no issue at all with either the honourable member for Fisher or the Minister regarding the matters raised. I commend them both for what they have done. But, in the spirit of that question I bring to the attention of the House a similar tragedy that occurred in the electorate of Wakefield. Although no lives were lost, the trauma faced by the people in the Melrose-Mount Remarkable area of the electorate of Wakefield was no less real than the trauma faced by the residents of Fisher in the Cooyar area.

On 17 January this year in the heart of summer there was a thunderstorm, which is not uncharacteristic of Mount Remarkable. That thunderstorm and the consequent lightning strikes resulted in an enormous fire that swept through the mid north of South Australia. It needs to be appreciated just how unique Mount Remarkable is.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is remarkable.

—I quite agree. Mount Remarkable is the southern tip of the Flinders Ranges. It rises to 960 metres and is part of an ironstone ridge that is the backdrop to the township of Melrose. As honourable members may well guess, given some of the geography known in this House, it is about 300 kilometres north of the city of Adelaide. I notice the honourable member for Moore (Mr Blanchard) nodding wisely. No doubt he spent some time there when he was a South Australian resident. But enough of this frivolity. Because Mount Remarkable is part of an ironstone ridge it is by no means unusual for lighting strikes to occur there. Mount Remarkable has been a conservation park for some time. On 7 January lightning strikes occurred in the part currently supervised by the Department of Woods and Forests in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The fire broke out and spread briefly into the national park. It was thought to have been brought under control by the Department of Woods and Forests and the National Parks and Wildlife Service and was not as closely monitored, one might suppose, as it ought to have been. But I was not there at the time so it would be unfair merely to presume to make the judgment. Nonetheless, a wind blew up, the fire got out of control once again and very rapidly took hold of the Mount Remarkable national park. As a result, all of the country between Murray Town and Wilmington, which runs from well south of Melrose into the Flinders Ranges, is burnt black. If one now drives into the township of Melrose one sees that skyline at the top of Mount Remarkable, once wooded, is now clearly evident because no trees now exist on Mount Remarkable.

For the farmers in the surrounding area there were enormous stock losses, although no homes were lost. As a result of those stock losses, the farmers currently face the reality of having to agist the few remaining stock they have, which is difficult enough in a season like this, and the even more pressing demand of having to sell burnt stock, bury dead stock and ask themselves what they will use as income for the next 12 months, having suffered these stock losses. As for those who are selling stock because they no longer have any grass to feed them, and who will be taxed on that income, what will they then have left to restock with when once again the grass grows?

The final point I want to make is that the need for park management in the coming year will be acute. As a result of the fire having swept through the national park one might expect that this winter the grass will grow to almost the height of an average man or woman and thus will pose an even more frightful fire threat in the coming summer. Therefore, the whole question of national park management ought to be carefully pursued because while everyone would want to retain some conservation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last two days, Australian Parliamentarians Against Apartheid has organised two quite separate meetings in this House-the first with Mrs Sheila Suttner, an expatriate white South African now living in Perth, and the second with Mr Joe Kapanda, information officer for the South West African People's Organisation in Australia. Both persons referred to the growing polarisation between the black majority and the white minority in South Africa. They spoke of the steady shift of the white minority towards an increasingly conservative stance. The South African Government, they said, is more intent on currying favour with the extreme Afrikaner Right than with removing the evils of apartheid. They likewise suggested that the South African Government is completely impervious to world opinion and will carry on with its reign of terror quite regardless of all diplomatic representations and international protest. This is clearly shown by the South African Government's determination to proceed with the execution this Friday of six young black people known as the Sharpeville six.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the complete lack of any evidence to directly connect them with the crime, these six people-a woman and five men-were found guilty of the murder of the black deputy mayor of the township of Sharpeville. They were found guilty purely and simply on the grounds that they were part of a crowd of a thousand angry blacks, some few of whom stoned the deputy mayor into unconsciousness and then set him on fire. A key witness for the prosecution has admitted that he was told by the police whom he should blame when he appeared in court to testify. The trial judge actually accepted the fact that there was absolutely no evidence that established that the six accused had `contributed causally' to the deputy mayor's death. He ruled that, simply by being members of the crowd, they shared a `common purpose' and should therefore be executed.

This case has aroused a storm of protest from many parts of the world-but all in vain. Our Australian Government has appealed to Mr Botha to exercise clemency by commuting the death sentence, as have many other governments throughout the world, but he has ignored all appeals in his total disregard for world opinion. It is ironic that the Sharpeville six will be hanged just three days short of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the Sharpeville massacre when, on 21 March 1960, South African police opened fire on a peaceful, unarmed and non-violent crowd of blacks who were protesting against the pass laws. Sixty-nine innocent blacks were shot dead and hundreds of others sustained gunshot wounds. They were shot in the back as they ran away. The police, of course, were declared innocent and no inquiry was held.

Some people saw the Sharpeville massacre as the watershed in black-white relations that marked the end of any chance for a peaceful settlement. But others said, `No, we must give the South African Government another chance for reform'. Others say the watershed was 1976 when the South African Government ruthlessly suppressed the demonstrations of the young black students of Soweto and other townships. Approximately 1,000 young blacks were murdered by the regime in those few months. Still others say the watershed came the following year with the murder in custody of Steve Biko. Since then, others have pointed to the Government's declaration of a state of emergency and the detention of thousands of people, including Mrs Suttner's son, Ronald Suttner.

I am convinced that, whenever it may have been, the South African Government has long since passed that watershed which marked the end of any possibility of a peaceful solution. In saying this, I would hasten to add that I have nothing but admiration for the courage and heroism of so many South African blacks and whites who, over many painful years, have sought in vain to find such a solution. But I can no longer see any point in Australia having anything to do with a regime as evil as the South African Government. Should the Sharpeville six be hanged on Friday, as now seems certain, I believe we are morally bound to isolate completely that horrendous regime and leave it to its inevitable and bloody fate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contribution by the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) tonight reminded me of this coming Saturday and its importance in New South Wales, particularly in the electorate of Gilmore. The electorate of Gilmore contains several State electorates. We have a number of National Party of Australia candidates running in those electorates. I am sure that the candidates in each of those electorates will be very successful in the election. I will start by mentioning the State electorate of Goulburn which is currently held by Robert Webster who is the shadow Minister for Local Government and Planning in the New South Wales coalition Opposition. Over the past four years Robert has proved himself to be an immensely capable, hard working and energetic member for the seat of Goulburn. I believe that Robert has carried the issues for the people of Goulburn as effectively as anyone could in the State Parliament. I note that the honourable member for Canberra, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), was at the launching of the Labor candidate's campaign less than two weeks ago.
—It was very successful too.

—It was very successful. It lasted about 15 minutes and the Labor candidate asked seven questions. He asked, `Why haven't we got a bypass? Why are the railways in Goulburn starting to run down and people losing jobs?' He asked a whole series of questions. He then said, `We are going to lose Kenmore, the railways are running down, and we have not got a bypass because of the State member for Goulburn, Mr Robert Webster'. Let me just inform the House, and I am sure the people of New South Wales, that, as they would be aware, the administrative decisions in New South Wales are made by the Labor Government. We have seen a massive loss of jobs on the railway at Goulburn because of the Unsworth Labor Government. We have not got a bypass around the city because the Federal and State Labor governments are both denying the funds for that purpose. Kenmore is being closed down by the State Labor Government because of its inability to understand properly the needs of the mentally ill in this State.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to close the Kenmore hospital will knock out 5 per cent of the total work force of Goulburn. When the Premier, Mr Unsworth, last came to Goulburn some few months ago, in response to questioning about the issues of Kenmore he called all the local journalists a pack of troglodytes. He called local businessmen who are concerned about the economic effect the closure of Kenmore will have on the economy of Goulburn a pack of mealy mouthed fools, and so on. So he has endeared himself tremendously to the people of Goulburn. We have not got the bypass, the Goulburn railway workers have been cut back and Kenmore is being closed down because of the Unsworth Government. The only way that that situation will be turned around is if we have a change this coming Saturday and a Greiner-Murray government, a Liberal-National Party coalition government is elected.

Moving from there to the seat of Burrinjuck, we have an excellent candidate, Mr Richard Wood, who has proved himself over the last six months. He has been working hard in that electorate and has shown himself to be the most capable of all the candidates and certainly the most intelligent. This is reflected in the fact that in Tumut recently, which is a Labor stronghold-I think the National Party got 37 per cent of the vote in the last State election-in front of more than 400 timber workers, who would be traditional Labor voters, Mr Richard Wood was endorsed as the preferred candidate of the timber workers in Tumut. I note that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) is in the chamber. He would understand well the reasons why those timber workers will be voting for the National Party candidate. He would understand well why they are sick and tired of Labor and why Mr Richard Wood will be elected as the next member for Burrinjuck.

I will move very quickly to the seat of Monaro, where we have an excellent candidate in Mr Peter Cochran. He is a very active family man, a former military person-the honourable member for Canberra will be interested-and he will make a most effective member for the area. He is certainly interested in the issue of law and order and in reinstating some decent standards into our schools. He is interested in installing decent, commonsense views relating to guns and their ownership in this State. In the seat of Monaro we are going to have a change. Mr Peter Cochran will be the member for Monaro after this Saturday. We all look forward to seeing Robert Webster, Peter Cochran and Richard Wood installed in the government of New South Wales under the premiership of Nick Greiner, assisted by Wal Murray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) lives in his own little dream world and we have to accept that fact. Tonight I am here to talk about an event last Sunday which I attended in the electorate of the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). I am sorry he is not in the chamber to listen.
—I will tell him.

—I am glad. The event was the national championships for the blind and it was held at Bateman in the honourable member's electorate. I was there at the opening to present the national flag and to welcome the delegates to Western Australia, which was a fine venue, and it was a beautiful day for that ceremony. Some 150 competitors are taking part in the championships. Although they have been billed as national championships, in fact they have had very much an international flavour, for representatives from Papua New Guinea and Thailand are in attendance. Those 150 competitors marched past to the music of the Nazarene College band. It was certainly a very stirring sight and one that pleased the several hundred people who turned up to see the opening ceremony.

SPEECH.PARA: I pay tribute to the organisers of the championships because they did an extremely good job in preparing the venue for the championships. In particular, I pay a tribute to Margaret and Ian Wedd, who just happen to come from my electorate and who over the last two years planned for these national championships. The national president of the association assured me that it was the best planned function of its kind ever held in Australia. I pay tribute also to all the participants in these games, which are being held all this week. They have shown a willingness to overcome the handicap of being blind in this modern world. At the same time, I think we all realise that being a sports person merely involves participating in sport. One does not have to be a champion; the mere fact of participation makes one a sports person. On behalf of the Parliament, I wish all the participants in the championships every success in the course of this week. They cannot all be winners but they can hold their heads up high because they have participated.

That the Procedure Committee be asked to examine and prepare recommendations to provide that rules for the election of a Speaker at the first sitting of the Parliament, or at any time when the position becomes vacant, be changed to provide that the member with the longest continuous service not being a member of the Executive or Opposition office holder shall take the chair until such time as a Speaker is elected and shall exercise whilst in the chair all of the powers vested in the Speaker for the conduct of actual sittings of the House of Representatives.
Mr Scholes to move-
That this House-
(1) expresses its disappointment at the selection of recipients of the Companion of the Order of Australia on Australia Day 1988;
(2) is of the opinion that the bulk of awards are issued to machinery positions, that is to persons because they hold the positions rather than because they earned the award; and

(3) notes that on the day of the 200th anniversary of white settlement, the Council has demeaned the Order and failed to give appropriate consideration to the main purpose of the Order of Australia to recognise achievements by Australians as distinct from the position, patronage basis of the imperial honours.
Mr Hawke to move-
That this House, on St. Patrick's Day 1988:
(1) Recognises with thanks the profound contribution made by the Irish over two hundred years to Australian culture, religion, law, politics and the labour movement;
(2) Notes that the Irish community in Australia dates from the First Fleet, that one third of Australians are of Irish descent, and that Australia is the most Irish of nations outside Ireland;

(3) Affirms that the emergence of an Australian national character was due in large part to the creative presence of the Irish, whose passionate love of freedom prepared the way for a society in which people from many ethnic backgrounds live and flourish as equals;

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 16 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the response to the Government's Green Paper on industrial democracy and employee participation.
(2) Is the Government in a position to announce its policy on industrial democracy in the private sector; if not, when can an announcement be expected.
(3) Have all Departments completed industrial democracy plans as required under the Public Service Act, if not, which Departments are still to complete plans and what is the cause of the delay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A substantial number of written responses have been received from the Australian industrial community to the Government's Policy Discussion Paper.

Major submissions have been received from a range of interested bodies, including the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Business Council of Australia, the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, a number of Australia's largest enterprises, and some State Governments.

These submissions, and the results of the process of public consultation, show widespread agreement on the pressing need for changed workplace practices in Australia and recognition that employee participation will be an essential ingredient in achieving that change.

A participative approach is seen by all the parties as an important element in a broader strategy which has, as its main objectives, improved efficiency, productivity and international competitiveness, which are vital to economic prosperity in Australia.

Submission on the Policy Discussion Paper indicated some disagreement about how industrial democracy and employee participation should be promoted but discussions between employers represented by the CAI and the unions through the ACTU seeking to resolve their differences are continuing.

(2) The Government's policy is being developed and that process is taking account of the views expressed in response to the Policy Discussion Paper. It is intended that the policy development process will be completed and the implementation of policy commenced in 1988.
(3) All departments and all but one small prescribed statutory agency have submitted industrial democracy plans as required by the legislation contained in Section 22c of the Public Service Act.

The plan from the Automotive Industry Authority remains outstanding due to a lack of staff resources. In this case both my Department, and the former Public Service Board, have reminded the Authority of its statutory obligation. I understand that the Authority is currently pursuing the process of seeking union and staff comment on its draft plan. The Authority has confirmed its intention to submit a finalised plan to my Department in early 1988.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The VLF band is that band of frequencies between 3 kHz and 30 kHz.
(2) There are 28 stations licensed to operate on a permanent basis in Australia.
(3) (a) The Commonwealth operates 7 transmitters:
(i) Victoria-5; Western Australia-2.
(b) The State authorities operate 1 transmitter:
(i) South Australia-1.
(c) There are no transmitters operated by local authorities.
(d) The private sector operates 20 transmitters:
(i) New South Wales-18; Victoria-2.
(4) (a) Of the Commonwealth operated transmitters, five are at Darriman, Victoria and two are at North West Cape, Western Australia.
(b) (i) The Department does not record the frequency capability of the equipment installed at the stations.

(ii) The Maritime Safety Division and the Royal Australian Navy respectively.

(e) The effective range of the stations is not known by the Department. The range is affected by many factors, which include the efficiency of the transmitting and receiving systems, the path between the transmitting and receiving stations, the type of emission of the transmitted signal and the vagaries of electromagnetic propagation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What sum was provided by the Government for the purchase of the `Penryn' Aboriginal property near Peak Hill, NSW.
(2) For what purposes and when have grants been provided to the property since its purchase.
(3) What persons (a) employed on the property and (b) not employed on the property, including advisers, have received payments in respect of the property.
(4) What sums have each of the persons referred to in part (3) received.
(5) Is he able to say what sum the property has made or lost each year since its purchase.
(6) Who has responsibility to run, and make decisions relating to, the property.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No funding has been provided by the Department of Employment, Education and Training for the purchase of the property.
(2) No grants have been provided by the Department to the property since its purchase.
(3), (4), (5), and (6) A response to these questions was provided by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 24 November 1987.

Thirteen Aboriginal people have been given work experience or on-the-job training under labour force programs administered by the Department at the property since 1980 for periods from 3 months in most cases to up to 12 months in other cases.

In addition, two Training for Aboriginals Program (TAP) Special Projects have been conducted at the property. QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 21 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has ABC TV shown the lawn bowls program ``Jack High'' each year from 1978 to 1987.
(2) Did the ABC give the Australian Bowls Council an assurance at a ``Jack High'' Dinner in Adelaide in March 1987 that the 1988 ``Jack High'' series would be covered.

(3) Has the Minister had drawn to his attention that the Australian Bowls Council, the West Epping Bowling Club and the local government body have made large financial and administrative commitments for the 1988 ``Jack High'' competition at the West Epping Bowling Club, based on the assurance given at the March 1987 dinner.

(4) Did the ABC's Acting Head of Television Services state in a letter, dated 27 August 1987, to the Australian Bowls Council that ``Jack High'' has been a successful program but a decision had been made not to proceed with the telecast of the 1988 series.

(5) In view of the assurances already given and commitments made for television coverage of the 1988 series, (a) will the Minister give the reasons which have caused the ABC not to proceed with this successful sports program, (b) is it unreasonable to give such short notice of its cancellation and (c) would the Minister support a request by the Australian Bowls Council for the 1988 series to be covered by ABC TV, and for the cancellation to take effect from 1989.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The ABC first televised `Jack High' in 1980 and has televised the series each year since, although the 1987 series has yet to be shown in Victoria.

(2) The ABC has advised that the Head of Television Sport at the time, Kevin Berry, indicated at the `Jack High' dinner in March 1987 that the ABC planned to proceed with coverage of the 1988 `Jack High' series. However, there was no formal commitment by the ABC and the final decisions on the 1987/88 sport production plans were not made until August 1987.
(3) I am aware that the Australian Bowls Council and the Royal NSW Bowling Association (on behalf of the West Epping Bowling Club) have made representations on this matter.
(4) Yes.

(5) The ABC has advised that no formal commitment to the television of `Jack High' was provided. The ABC decided to exclude the program in its 1987/88 sports priorities after consideration of the cost involved, the layout strategies, the audience response to the program, other sporting commitments, and in view of concerns about intrusive advertising. The honourable member will be aware that the ABC is an independent statutory authority with responsibility for its own operations and programming. It would be inappropriate for me to intervene in programming decisions taken by the ABC.
