ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Science and Small Business, upon notice, on 17 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) laboratory craftsmen, (b) technical assistants and (c) technical officers are employed by the CSIRO.
(2) What qualifications or certificates are required for each designation.
(3) What recognised institutions issue these certificates.
(4) Have the certification procedures for each designation ever been reviewed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at the end of January 1988 CSIRO employed (a) 376 laboratory craftsmen (b) 832 technical assistants and (c) 1228 technical officers.
(2) (a) A qualification of the standard of an appropriate trade certificate.

(b) The successful completion of 5 years' secondary schooling or a qualification of the same standard. Higher qualifications or, in certain cases, evidence of specialised experience in a relevant technical area would be assessed by CSIRO as equivalent.

(c) (i) At least 6 years' relevant technical experience, and (ii) A qualification of the standard of a certificate from a Technical and Further Education (TAFE) institution (or other institution) recognised by CSIRO, or a pass in a test of knowledge (at the standard of a certificate in the particular speciality) and competence conducted by or for CSIRO.

(3) (a) Trade certificates are issued by the relevant State or Territory apprenticeship authorities. Australian Recognised Tradesman's Certificates are issued by State Local Trades Committees pursuant to the Tradesmen's Rights Regulation Act 1946.

(b) Certificates and higher qualifications assessed by CSIRO as satisfying the educational prerequisite are issued by State/Territory secondary and tertiary educational bodies. (Certificates are not always issued at the end of 5 years secondary schooling).

(c) TAFE institutions. Academic records and higher level degrees and diplomas are issued by higher tertiary education bodies. Overseas qualifications are assessed by the Council on Overseas Professional Qualifications.
(4) (a) The entry qualification to the laboratory craftsmen designation has remained the same since the designation was introduced into CSIRO in 1949.
(b) An education qualification for technical assistant was set for the first time in 1971-72 when the present educational standard was introduced.
(c) The qualification requirements for the technical officer designation were prescribed in Determination No. 267 of 1968 of the Public Service Arbitrator and have remained unchanged since that time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence upon notice, on 23 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the extent and nature of training which members of the Australian Defence Force receive in the international humanitarian laws of warfare.
(2) Is this training adequate and will he undertake a review of the adequacy of that training.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Navy. Law of Armed Conflict training is carried out either by Permanent Naval Force or Reserve Legal Officers at the RAN Staff College in Sydney, the Australian Joint Maritime Warfare School in Nowra, and at Commanding Officer/Executive Officer (Designate) courses. Lectures are based on material from the International Humanitarian Law section of the Manual of Naval Law.

Army. Law of Armed Conflict training is carried out at the Royal Military College, Duntroon, at Army Reserve Schools in all capital cities, at the Command and Staff College, Queenscliff, at One Recruit Training Battalion, Kapooka, at the Apprentices School, Bonegilla, at the School of Military Intelligence, Canungra, at the Military Police School, Ingleburn, at the School of Military Engineering, Casula, and at the Infantry Centre, Singleton. At these locations, lectures are given on the Geneva and Hague Conventions, specifically the conduct of war and the treatment of Prisoners of War.

Air Force. RAAF Staff College (ACT) conducts Law of Armed Conflict training in a series of three lectures, and during course discussions. Combat Survival Training School (Townsville) includes instruction on the application of the Geneva Conventions to Prisoners of War. RAAF Security and Fire School (Amberley) conducts training in the Law of Armed Conflict as it relates to the tasks of an Airfield Defence Guard.

Joint Services Staff College. Lectures are given on broad issues involving International Law, including Law of Armed Conflict. Following this, syndicate discussions of two/three 50 minute periods occur.

Australian Defence Force Academy. First year officer cadets study, for one period, the Law of Armed Conflict. Specifically, they are required to recognise: the importance of the Laws of War to military commanders, the legal dilemmas with which the military commander may be confronted in time of war, and that strict adherence to the Law of Armed Conflict is the most effective means of accomplishing a military mission. Third year cadets are given (relatively) more rigorous training. Three periods are spent in considering the restrictions on conduct in combat, and in applying the Law of Armed Conflict to a variety of military operations.

(2) A syllabus designed to cover basic Law of Armed Conflict training for all members of the ADF has recently been completed. This syllabus will be introduced to all initial entry training units. The Services are also developing syllabuses that will be used to train both personnel attached to operational units and to higher planning/staff positions.

In addition to these three levels, selected ADF personnel regularly attend International Law of Armed Conflict Courses which are conducted in Italy by the International Institute of Humanitarian Law. Attendance at these courses exposes those involved with policy making to foreign views on the Law of Armed Conflict. In addition the ADF is kept abreast of current international developments in the law of Armed Conflict.

Finally, it is CDF's intention to have a joint Service Publication (JSP) on Law of Armed Conflict as a reference for training. This publication will complete a comprehensive ADF training system which will provide for the instruction of personnel at all rank levels in the international humanitarian laws of warfare.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say whether police and RSPCA officials in Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria have investigated the importation and breeding of pit bull terriers for illegal dog fighting; if so, what are the results of these investigations.
(2) Is there a ban on the importation of pit bull terriers; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As far as can be ascertained, police and RSPCA officials in Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria have not specifically investigated either the importation or the breeding of pit bull terriers for illegal dog fighting purposes.

Dog-fighting is an illegal activity under the individual State's/Territory's welfare Acts and it is a matter for State authorities to investigate illegal dog fighting activities. Although many rumours are causing concern that dog fights are taking place, these rumours still remain unconfirmed reports.

However, I am advised that the Western Australian police did carry out investigations into allegations of illegal dog-fighting following media reports eight months ago but could find no evidence to substantiate those reports and their investigations did not lead to any prosecutions. I also understand that the Victorian Government is currently preparing a Companion Animals Act to replace the Dog Act. It will deal, in part, with controls for vicious and dangerous dogs.

(2) The importation of pit bull terriers into Australia is not banned because it is not possible to distinguish between dogs that are imported for legal purposes such as for pets, guard dogs or for showing, or for illegal purposes such as dog-fighting.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his predecessor's answer to question No. 4647, (Hansard, 13 November 1986, page 2953), concerning the adoption of the Hague Visby Rules in relation to the sea carriage of goods, was the review of the options for the adoption of the Hamburg Rules completed by 30 June 1987; if not, why not.
(2) What area the conclusions of that review.
(3) Have those conclusions been discussed with the shipping industry; if not, why not.
(4) What future action does he propose to take concerning the adoption of the Hague Visby Rules and any associated protocols, including any amendments to the Sea Carriage of Goods Act 1924.
(5) Will he make available a copy of the report referred to in his predecessor's answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. Completion of the extended review foreshadowed in my predecessor's answer to question No. 4647 was delayed in order that the outcome of an international meeting, held in Geneva in June 1987, on the Hamburg Rules could be included in the review. This meeting, jointly convened by the International Chamber of Commerce and the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD), canvassed current international industry views on the possible introduction of the Hamburg Rules to replace existing marine cargo liability regimes. A representative of Australian shippers attended the meeting.

(2) The Department of Transport and Communications distributed a report ``Australian Marine Cargo Liability, a Discussion Paper'' in October 1987 which outlined the issues for Australia and included a range of options available to update marine cargo liability regulation in Australia. The relative merits of Australia adopting the Hamburg Rules was further discussed at the International Trade Law Seminar convened by the Attorney General's Department, 16 October 1987. There is no consensus within the Australian industry on which international convention Australia should adopt for marine cargo liability. There is, however, general agreement that the Sea Carriage of Goods Act 1924 requires amendment.
(3) Yes.

(4) The Department is currently analysing the detailed comments that have been received from various shipping industry interests on the issues and the options identified in the Discussion Paper. I will, subsequently, be putting before Cabinet, a recommendation concerning the Sea Carriage of Goods Act 1924.
(5) Yes; a copy of the report has been forwarded to the honourable member's office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the outcome of the consultations between his Department and relevant interests concerning the minor amendments which the Copyright Law Review Committee recommended to the Copyright Act in order to enable Australia to accede to the International Convention for the Protection of Performers, Producers of Phonograms and Broadcasting Organisations done at Rome on 26 October 1961.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In order to enable Australia to accede to the Rome Convention, further protection is required for both performers and foreign broadcasters. Only the former matter, that of protection for performers, was considered by the Copyright Law Review Committee. I have examined the Committee's recommendations in this regard and I intend shortly to put before the Government proposals to amend the Copyright Act which would provide this protection.

Having regard to the extensive consultations with interests the Committee undertook on performers' protection, subsequent consultations undertaken by my Department have focused primarily on the broadcasting aspects of the Convention. The broadcasting interests consulted have indicated that they would have no difficulty with the implementation of those provisions of the Convention.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Crime Authority: Seizure of Papers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 10 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the National Crime Authority (NCA) seized a tape recording and written material from the Mike Willesee Show relating to the meeting between Senator Richardson and Mr F. Dugan.
(2) What is the status of the tape and has the NCA returned the tape; if not, when will it return the tape.

(3) Did the head of the NCA, Mr Justice Stewart, receive a number of tape recordings of foreign language conversations involving Sir Peter Abeles apparently speaking about the Prime Minister and did Mr Justice Stewart not bother to have them translated.
(4) Has the NCA refused to hand the tapes back to the private detective to whom they belong.
(5) Will he take necessary action to ensure the NCA translates the foreign language conversations involving Sir Peter Abeles and release its findings on this matter.
(6) Will he ensure that the private detective to whom the tape recordings belong receives the recordings back from the Authority.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The tape recording and written material came into the possession of the National Crime Authority in accordance with the provisions of the National Crime Authority Act. There has been no request made for the return of the tape or material. Legal advisers to the National Crime Authority advised that the information did not disclose any wrongdoing.

(3) and (5) A number of tape recordings of foreign language conversations were received by Mr Justice Stewart whilst acting as a Royal Commissioner. The circumstances were such that they were not required to be translated. The recordings are now in the custody of the National Crime Authority and the Authority has had them translated.
The National Crime Authority has informed me that they do not disclose any criminal activity.

(4) and (6) As set out in paragraphs 5.28 and 14.14 of his Report, the Royal Commissioner Mr Justice Stewart found that the recording of the conversations was in breach of section 7 of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. In those circumstances the Authority is of the view that the material should not be returned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Crime Authority: Seizure of Papers

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to Question No. 578, can he assure the House that the National Crime Authority (NCA) will not destroy the tape recordings.

(2) Will he ensure that the National Companies and Securities Commission and the Reserve Bank Board receive either authenticated copies of the tapes or transcripts of the tape recordings in order for those bodies to determine whether any codes of conduct relevant to those bodies have been breached.

(3) Will he also ensure that transcripts of English conversations involving Sir Peter Abeles apparently instructing an employee to transfer a large amount of funds out of Australia at short notice are handed on to the National Companies and Securities Commission and the Reserve Bank Board in order for those bodies to determine whether any commercial or other codes of conduct have been breached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) In the light of the fact that the National Crime Authority has stated that the tape recordings do not disclose any criminal activity, I do not see any reason why the National Companies and Securities Commission or the Reserve Bank Board should receive copies of the tapes or transcripts.

(3) I have been informed by the National Crime Authority that the tape recordings in the English language which were taped by the private detective mentioned in Question No. 578 and received by Mr Justice Stewart whilst acting as a Royal Commissioner do not record any conversation in which a person instructed another person to transfer a large amount of funds out of Australia.

I have been informed by the National Crime Authority that those tape recordings record one conversation in which a person requests another person to purchase from American Express US$15000 for the purposes of an overseas trip. It is not clear from the conversation whether cash or travellers cheques were to be purchased.
In those circumstances I do not see any reason why a transcript of that conversation should be handed to the National Companies and Securities Commission or the Reserve Bank Board.
